A way of calculating the value of assets used in the US, in which the value of an asset is taken to decrease quite quickly, over a period of time fixed by the tax authorities, rather than over the period of time in which it actually remains useful to a company. [1]

Writing off the cost of fixed assets such as machinery and other capital equipment more quickly than would normally be required, or by larger amounts in the initial years of use. This practice is allowed by some tax authorities as a means of reducing tax during the period of the write-off and thus encouraging investment. [1]
A payment made when a borrower is forced to pay back a loan more quickly than originally planned, usually because of the danger of default(failure to repay). [1]

Under the accelerated payment rules, the recipient of a follower notice may receive an accelerated payment notice, under which he will be required to pay any disputed tax to HMRC if he decides not to amend his tax return or settle the dispute with HMRC (i.e. the decision is made to continue the dispute). The accelerated payments regime also applies to taxpayers who have entered into tax arrangements that have been disclosed under the disclosure of tax avoidance scheme rules or who have received a notice of counteraction under the general anti-abuse rule. [1]

The principle that when demand for goods rises and falls, investment rises and falls by even larger amounts.When a government uses the accelerator, it encourages demand as a way of controlling the economy. [1]

To take or agree to take something that has been offered. To agree to a plan, idea, agreement etc.  To agree to take goods that have been ordered.  When people accept a new product, they like it and are willing to buy it. [1]
To agree to pay a bill of exchange. [1]
To officially agree to insure something. [1]

A bill of exchange that binds one party (the acceptor) to pay a specific amount to another at a stated time in the future. A type of time draft used particularly in international trade. If it is drawn directly by the seller of goods on the buyer, it is called a trade acceptance or trade bill. Acceptances can also be issued by finance companies or banks and used as a means of financing trade. A banker's acceptance (BA), also called bank bill, is an acceptance drawn on and accepted by a bank. Such bills are sold by banks at a discount (the banker's acceptance (BA) rate), and redeemed with the same or other accepting banks at face value within a relatively short timeframe (typically one to nine months). As such, the paper is effectively a bank-backed, short-term, non-interest bearing note and qualifies as a money market instrument.

A bill of exchange that binds one party (the acceptor) to pay a specific amount to another at a stated time in the future. A type of time draft used particularly in international trade. If it is drawn directly by the seller of goods on the buyer, it is called a trade acceptance or trade bill. Acceptances can also be issued by finance companies or banks and used as a means of financing trade. A banker's acceptance (BA), also called bank bill, is an acceptance drawn on and accepted by a bank. Such bills are sold by banks at a discount (the banker's acceptance (BA) rate), and redeemed with the same or other accepting banks at face value within a relatively short timeframe (typically one to nine months). As such, the paper is effectively a bank-backed, short-term, non-interest bearing note and qualifies as a money market instrument.

A bill of exchange that binds one party (the acceptor) to pay a specific amount to another at a stated time in the future. A type of time draft used particularly in international trade. If it is drawn directly by the seller of goods on the buyer, it is called a trade acceptance or trade bill. Acceptances can also be issued by finance companies or banks and used as a means of financing trade. A banker's acceptance (BA), also called bank bill, is an acceptance drawn on and accepted by a bank. Such bills are sold by banks at a discount (the banker's acceptance (BA) rate), and redeemed with the same or other accepting banks at face value within a relatively short timeframe (typically one to nine months). As such, the paper is effectively a bank-backed, short-term, non-interest bearing note and qualifies as a money market instrument.
Another name for accepting house. [1]
A bonus paid to someone who agrees to join a company, or to an employee who agrees to do a difficult task. [1]
An agreement by an insurance company to provide the insurance asked for. [1]

A way of checking the quality of mass-produced goods, in which a small number of the finished items are examined, and the standard of this sample is used as a guide to the quality of the rest when a small number of documents, records etc are checked to see if they are correct, and the standard of this sample is used as a guide to whether the rest are correct. [1]
Testing by a customer of newly delivered equipment to check that it works correctly. [1]
An old name for one of the London banks that accepted bills of exchange.  [1]
A financial institution that accepts a bill of exchange. [1]
Money paid by a government or insurance company to people who are not able to work because of an accident or an illness. [1]
Insurance against injury or death caused by an accident. [1]
An address that is used by people to receive letters, packages etc, that is not the place where they live. [1]

When the monetary authorities of a country adopt a policy that boosts money supply and lowers interest rates as a means to stimulate economic activity. Also called a loose credit or easy money policy.

When the monetary authorities of a country adopt a policy that boosts money supply and lowers interest rates as a means to stimulate economic activity. Also called a loose credit or easy money policy.

An arrangement between a bank and a customer that allows the customer to pay in and take out money; bank account.  A record showing a particular part of the finances of a business.  An arrangement between a buyer and a seller for payment to be made some time after the buyer receives the goods or services. An organization that is a regular client of a company, especially an advertising agency.[1]
The difference between the total of all the debit and all the credit entries in an account, which is the amount required to make the two sides of the account equal to each other. [1]
An executive who works for an advertising agency and deals directly with clients, communicating their ideas to the company and making sure that their accounts are managed in a satisfactory way. [1]

An account manager is someone who looks after a customer or customers and tries to ensure that they do not leave and go to another supplier. The account manager might work with a sales team to deliver tailored services or goods to the customer he or she is looking after. The account manager might also be a first point of contact for after sales support including technical assistance.   Account manager in the news In September 2013 an FT writer examined whether the staff at Deutsche Bank in Tokyo spent too much money entertaining clients. One interviewee said that when she worked as an advertising account manager she found that socialising with clients was the best way to get to know them, but she never expensed more than 1 per cent of what the client was spending. In January 2014 an FT writer pointed out that the cost of investing was not the only concern for investors, the quality of investor service was also a big issue. Fidelity, a fund platform, was reported to provide a personalised account manager to investors with more than  100,000.
A phrase written on a cheque to show it can only be paid into the account held by the person whose name is written on the cheque. [1]
The profession or work done by accountants in keeping the financial records of organizations and in giving advice to clients on tax and other financial matters. [1]
A professional person whose job is to keep and check the financial records of an organization, or to advise clients on tax and other financial matters. [1]
Statement signed by an auditor following the examination of a company's accounts.
The usual word for the profession of accountancy in the US. The work of keeping a company's financial records, recording its income and expenses, and its business deals.[1]
One of the relationships between assets and liabilities used in accounting. [1]
Footnotes to a company's financial statements.
A period of time to which a particular payment is related for accounting or tax purposes. [1]
A rule or idea used for preparing accounts in a particular company or place. [1]
A set of accounting standards established by local regulators or recognised accountants' associations. GAAP and IAS are accounting principles that are internationally followed.
Profit based on the accounting standards followed by a particular company, which may be different from the profit based on the standards required by tax authorities.
The amount of profit made from an investment, measured as a percentage of the value of the assets used in the investment. [1]
Another word for financial ratio. [1]
An official instruction on how something must be treated and presented in accounts. [1]
An official instruction on how something must be treated and presented in accounts. [1]
The rules used for accounting in a particular company or place a computer system used for accounting. [1]
The 12-month period over which a company's accounts are calculated. In Britain, many companies have the end of March or the end of December as the end of their financial year. [1]
What a company owes to suppliers or other creditors for goods and services purchased.
What a company is owed by customers and other debtors for goods and services it has provided. Also called receivables.
What a company is owed by customers and other debtors for goods and services it has provided. Also called receivables.
When a company borrows money, usually on a short-term basis for working capital, using its accounts receivable as collateral.
The ratio of total revenue over accounts receivable.
Officially accepted as being of a satisfactory or high standard, or permitted to do a particular kind of work. [1]
The growth of a company's asset base through acquisition or internal expansion. A transaction that results in accretion is described as accretive.
See accretion
An increase in an amount of money, usually over a period of time. [1]

Accounting based on the principle that when a business buys or sells something, this should affect the profit for the period of time when it happens, not when the related payment is sent or received, even if the payment occurs in a different accounting period. [1]

An accounting method that takes income as earned even if the money has not actually been received, and costs as incurred, even if the expenses have not actually been paid. This is still the standard method used to prepare accounts.
See zero coupon bond
See zero coupon bond
If an amount of money accrues, or is accrued, it gradually increases over a period of time. If profits or benefits accrue to you, or are accrued, you have the right to receive them.[1]
The value of goods or services bought by a business during a particular period of time, even if it pays for them in a later period. [1]
The value of goods or services that were bought by a business or organization during a particular period of time, even if it pays for them in a later period. [1]
The total amount of money earned by a company during a particular accounting period, whether paid or still owed to them. [1]

The interest that accrues on a security such as a bond or on a deposit between interest payment dates. If you sell a security or close a deposit before an interest payment date, you may in some cases receive compensation for any outstanding accrued interest.
Written abbreviation for account. [1]
To get, earn, or obtain something gradually over a period of time.To increase or develop gradually over a period of time. [1]
The total amounts allowed for depreciation of an asset up to a particular time. [1]
A dividend on a preferred share which is not paid out in each financial year, but allowed to build up. [1]
A fund built up over a period of time, usually for a particular purpose. [1]
The profits a company has made in previous years and held in its reserves. [1]

A tax imposed by some countries on the accumulated profits of a company that are not distributed to shareholders. These profits are sometimes retained specifically to avoid the higher personal income tax that would be imposed on the company's owners if the money were distributed as dividends.
An amount of money held in a particular type of investment trust, in which profit is invested back into the trust rather than paid as a regular dividend. [1]
The accused: the person or group of people who have been officially charged with a crime in a court of law. [1]

An acid-test ratio determines whether a firm has enough short-term assets to cover its immediate liabilities without having to sell any inventory. It is computed as the ratio of (cash + accounts receivable + short term investments) to current liabilities. To compare it to the working capital ratio, which allows for the inclusion of inventory, if the acid test ratio is lower than the working capital ratio, the firm s current assets are highly dependent on its inventory. [1] This is also known as 'quick ratio', since current assets minus inventories (cash, cash equivalents, tradable securities and accounts receivable) are also called quick assets, or 'liquid ratio'.
A letter sent to someone, saying that you have received something from them.A formal statement agreeing that something is correct or true. [1]
An official written statement in which someone agrees that they have a debt and will pay it back. [1]
To buy a company. Acquire a holding/ an interest/ a stake: to buy part of a company.  To get something, especially something important or valuable.[1]

This is when one company takes a controlling  interest in another. [1] When a company (typically referred to as the  acquirer ,  buyer  or  bidder ) purchases a second, usually smaller, company (called the  acquiree  or  target ); the second company can either be continued as a separate legal entity or ceases to exist and the assets of the target are then integrated into the buying company. If both companies cease to exist and a third company is created from the two legacy companies, the term generally used is  merger .  The actual stake that is considered to take control over another company varies according to the legal juristiction. In many cases, it is the minimum of 50% plus one share. There are many occasions where companies acquire either minority stakes or hold a block in another company which might later lead to acquiring additional or remaining shares in the other company. Many strategic investors prefer to take complete (100%) control of the target target while most financial investors prefer to spread the risks and acquire lower stakes.[2]   acquisition in the news Most M&A; deals are structured as an acquisition.  For example, when Kraft, the American food conglomerate, announced in early November 2009 that it would seek to purchase Cadbury, the UK-based confectionary company, Kraft intended to acquire all of Cadbury.  Thus, when the deal was finalised in January 2010, the board of Cadbury agreed to recommend to its shareholders to sell all of their shares to Kraft. Following the deal closing later that year, the Cadbury shares ceased to exist and no longer traded on the London Stock Exchange.  Cadbury shareholders received a combination of cash and Kraft shares in exchange for their Cadbury shares. [3]
An acquisitive company often buys other companies or parts of other companies. [1]
A word made up of the first letters of the name of something such as an organization. For example, NATO is an acronym for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. [1]
When the prices of virtually all the shares in a particular market move in the same direction.
A law that has been officially accepted by the governing body of a country. A written agreement that has legal force. [1]

A natural event such as a storm or an earthquake. No one can be held to be legally liable for damage caused by an act of God, and insurance companies will not usually make payments for such damage. [1]
When someone does something which breaks a condition made by the court when they were declared bankrupt. [1]
Acting head/ chairman/ director etc: someone who does an important job while the usual person is not there, or until a new person is chosen for the job. [1]

When two or more investors join forces, normally to buy shares with the aim of taking over a company. Regulators normally impose strict rules to ensure such alliances are disclosed and not used for share price manipulation.
When someone does something in order to deal with a problem or difficult situation.When important things happen, for example when there is a lot of buying or selling or prices rise or fall.

A method of developing effective management leadership through the integration of evidence-based theoretical concepts and methods with real-world experience and personal reflection. This approach aims to transform managers into strategic 'actors' (leaders) through their work on meaningful projects that are of critical importance to an organisation. Learning happens from and with peers and is applied to solving real world problems. Principled, innovative and resilient leadership is especially enhanced by action learning in organisational settings characterised as entrepreneurial, uncertain, low-resource economic systems, and/or driven by fundamental social purpose to guide significant change. Example A team may be tasked to analyse a small start-up s business strategy. They may do this by studying the company s distribution models, production strategy or finance model. However, it is the insight gained from problem framing, inquiry, and an understanding of an organisation s real commitments and constraints, through a lens of personal reflection, which allows for innovative solutions that lead to systemic change. [1]
A list of the things that you need to do in order to achieve something or to deal with a problem. [1]
Something that you decide must be done, especially after a meeting or after studying something carefully. [1]
Using practical methods which involve doing things to deal with problems, not just talking about ideas, plans, or theories. [1]
If something is actionable, you can bring a case against someone in court about it. [1]

If trading or a market is active, there is a lot of buying and selling. A company that is active is selling products or services.  If someone is active in doing something, they do it.  Taking definite action rather than just giving advice or waiting to see what will happen.  An active bank account is being used.[1]

An active ETF is simply an active management strategy in an ETF wrapper. They differ from traditional ETFs that are passive instruments in that they demand no investment strategy and simply require the ETF provider to track an underlying index. The best known active ETF is Pimco's BOND (BOND is the ETF's ticker) which is an ETF version of its Total Return Fund, which invests in highly liquid bond markets. Active ETFs remain a minuscule portion of the total ETF market.   active ETF in the news Pimco's launch of an active ETF in March 2012 was seen as a game changer. An ETF must publish its holdings daily, and the launch of the ETF would give bond investors a window into the thinking of Bill Gross, seen as a guru in fixed income markets.  In March 2013 it was reported that iShares, an ETF provider, had registered an intention to launch two active US equity ETFs. It had already registered other active ETFs but like some other fund providers had yet to go live with any products.  Industry observers said some fund companies could have been choosing to register products in order to have a seat at the table with the Securities and Exchange Commission in the future of active ETF regulation.
A bond that is actively traded after it is first sold. [1]

When the manager of a fund or portfolio makes proactive trading decisions in order to maximize returns. The opposite is passive management, when a fund or portfolio is tied to an index or basket of securities and the manager's role is limited. [1] Active managers believe they can outperform the market by identifying mispricing through a variety of strategies. For example, they might see a trend whereby companies with high cashflows are being underpriced by the market, so they buy them and wait for that value to be realised. [2]
Heavy volume of trading in a particular stock or in the market as a whole.
A partner who takes an active part in the running of a business.  [1]
All the people who normally work in an area, country etc. [1]
A stock that is being actively bought and sold. [1]

When many shares, commodities (oil, metals, farm products etc) are being bought and sold when a company's shares are being bought and sold on a stockmarket, and have not been suspended (prevented from being traded by the authorities). [1]
A trustee who invests the money they have control over, rather than simply passing it on to someone at the particular time they are allowed to have it. [1]

A person or group holding a significant amount of shares in a public company with the aim of influencing the decisions and structure of the organisation. [1]   activist investor in the news The best examples of the good that activists can do is when they develop theses on how to make the companies they target run differently and better before they take their positions. For example, Bill Ackman, founder of hedge fund Pershing Square, led a proxy fight against Canadian Pacific Railway, took control of the board of directors, threw the management out and doubled the share price for himself and other shareholders in the process. [2] The sweeping victory was just the latest sign that restless shareholders are frustrated with stagnant share prices and increasingly willing to challenge the executives supposed to serve their interests. During 2012 s febrile annual meeting season in North America and the UK, which became known as a  shareholder spring , management at companies such as Citigroup and Barclays were rebuked over executive pay. Even Apple   now the most valuable company in history   was forced to change the way it elects board members. [3]

Activity based costing (ABC) is an accountancy model and a type of management accounting designed to highlight the resources required to undertake a specific element of the production process. Staff costs are attributed to all activities within an organisation, thereby providing a clearer picture of where costs are generated. In essence, ABC is based upon the premise that everyone within an organisation is actually part of the costing process, regardless of whether the individual has a direct relationship with the goods or services provided. An in-depth understanding of where production costs are generated should allow managers to make better and more informed business decisions, including resource allocation. [1]

The activity model indicates the set of activities needed to turn a set of inputs (capital, raw materials and labour) into the firm s value proposition (benefits to customers). Examples of such activities include product development, purchasing, manufacturing, marketing and sales and service delivery. Example For instance low-cost airlines, such as Ryan air and EasyJet, have a simple value proposition - point-to-point travel at cheaper prices when compared to traditional carriers flying on similar routes. The activity model of these budget airlines involves removing some traditional frills to offer cheap ticket prices, for example, they only sell snacks and meals on board, instead of offering meals to all passengers as part of the ticket price. Using secondary airports also means that they pay lower airport fees which can help lower the ticket price. The activity model of airlines also involves generating other revenue streams such as selling advertising space on the exterior and interior of the aircraft.  All this brings extra sources of revenue, which can further help in keeping prices down for customers. [1]
The process of studying the activities of a group of workers or machines over a period of time, in order to find out how much time is spent on each activity that they do.  [1]
Money that a court orders someone to pay to someone else for harming them or their property, to cover the cost of the harm, rather than to punish them. [1]
A real loss of money, not one that is calculated or estimated, nor a paper loss where there is no actual cash loss, for example when an asset falls in value but is not sold. [1]
A price that is really paid, rather than one that was stated or calculated earlier another name for spot price. [1]
A loss where the thing insured is stolen or totally destroyed. [1]
Figures relating to something that has actually happened, rather than what was expected. [1]

The possibility that something that is covered by an insurance agreement will actually happen. Insurance companies have to calculate actuarial risks carefully in order to be sure of making a profit. [1]
Someone whose job is to calculate risks, in order to advise insurance companies or pension funds. [1]
An informal word for advertisement. [1]
A business that gives advice to companies about how they should advertise their products, and produces advertisements for them. [1]
Duty calculated as a percentage of the value of goods, rather than on their weight or the number of units. [1]
A tariff that varies, depending on the value of the goods, rather than one that is a fixed amount. [1]
A tax that changes, depending on the value of the goods it is added to, rather than being a fixed amount. [1]
A product that is sold to be used with another product.A piece of equipment or software that you connect to a computer, usually in order to improve its performance. [1]
Interest calculated only on the principal (the original amount borrowed) of a loan. [1]
An increase in the value of something that has been worked on, combined with other things etc so that it can be sold in a new form. [1]
Something that is added at the end of a report or other document to give more information. [1]
An additional amount of money that a court orders someone to pay as damages. [1]

A rule or principle stating that the money spent by a government on public services such as health and education can be added to from other funds, especially European Union Grants, but cannot be replaced by those grants altogether. [1]

When setting up a project that reduces greenhouse gas emissions, one of the key criteria for eligibility is that a project would not have gone ahead without the extra funds available from the sale of the carbon credits. This rule was meant to guard against companies gaining an additional source of income from an already profitable venture. Companies complain it can be subjective and that it is hard to estimate whether a project would be financially viable without the extra income. To gain private sector funding, companies are often caught in a dilemma. Many are asked to prove that a project would be financially viable without credits, because potential lenders and investors are nervous about their price volatility. Thus companies may end up with one set of estimates for banks and another for the mechanism s board.  [1]
If a meeting or law court adjourns, or if the person in charge adjourns it, it finishes or stops, either for a short time, or until the next time it meets. [1]
To officially decide who is right in an argument between two groups or organizations. Be adjudicated bankrupt: to be judged by a court of law to be unable to pay debts.[1]

To make small changes to something in order to correct or improve it. Seasonally adjusted: seasonally adjusted figures have been changed slightly according to influences that affect them regularly at particular times of the year, so that they can be compared with figures from other times of the year.  To settle an insurance claim.[1]
A way of controlling exchange rates, in which the value of certain currencies is fixed in relation to another currency, with the possibility of changing this arrangement if necessary. [1]

Also known as variable rate mortgage. A mortgage loan agreement under which the lender has the power to adjust the interest rate charged to the borrower according to changes in a national reference rate. This reference rate is normally controlled by a country's monetary authorities. Under such an agreement, the amounts scheduled to be repaid regularly to the lender may vary over the term of the mortgage. The opposite is a fixed-rate mortgage, under which repayments to a lender are the same on each payment date.

Also known as variable rate mortgage. A mortgage loan agreement under which the lender has the power to adjust the interest rate charged to the borrower according to changes in a national reference rate. This reference rate is normally controlled by a country's monetary authorities. Under such an agreement, the amounts scheduled to be repaid regularly to the lender may vary over the term of the mortgage. The opposite is a fixed-rate mortgage, under which repayments to a lender are the same on each payment date.
The total income after other costs have been taken away-used when calculating the amount of tax that you have to pay in the US. [1]
The price of a company's shares after a new share issue (an occasion when new shares are sold). [1]
Claims/ insurance/ loss adjuster: a person or company whose job is to assess the value of loss or damage for someone who has claimed on their insurance. [1]
Claims/ insurance/ loss adjuster: a person or company whose job is to assess the value of loss or damage for someone who has claimed on their insurance. [1]

A change that is made to something in order to correct or improve it. The agreement between an insurer and someone who has claimed on their insurance over the amount that will be paid, or the amount itself.[1]
A record of money spent and received, kept to check that no mistakes have been made in the official set of accounts kept in a ledger. [1]
When calculating something, a figure introduced to balance the effect of something that is not typical or representative. [1]
The advertising industry, and all the companies and people who are involved in it. [1]
Someone who works in advertising. [1]
The activities involved with managing or organizing the work of a company, organization etc. [1]
To manage, organize, and control something and make sure it is dealt with correctly. Administer justice: to punish crimes.[1]
Another word for administer. [1]

The activities involved with managing and organizing the work of a company or organization. The part of a company or organization involved with managing and organizing its work.  The government of a country at a particular time, especially in the United States.  In Britain and some other countries, when a company in financial difficulty is reorganized by an outside specialist with the aim of continuing some of its activities so that it can avoid liquidation (being broken up and sold).[1]
An order from a court that a company in financial difficulty should be put into administration (be reorganized by an outside specialist). [1]
Someone whose job is to help make an organization or department run smoothly by helping other staff to organize their work. [1]
In Britain, a tribunal that deals with special government problems. [1]
Someone who manages and organizes the work of a company or organization. Someone who manages a company that has been put into administration.[1]
Able to be used as evidence in a court of law. [1]
The cost of entrance to a cinema, sports event etc.Permission given to someone to enter a place, or become a member of a group, organization, school etc.
When a person or organization accepts legal liability for something. [1]
To allow someone to enter a place or become a member of a group, organization, school etc. Admit liability: to accept legal liability for something.[1]
If you adopt a new method, process etc, you start to use it.To start using a product, especially a new product, usually with the intention of continuing to buy and use it. [1]
The rate at which people accept a new product. [1]
Done before an event happens.An amount of money paid to someone before the usual time, or before a piece of work has been completed.
A book, magazine, report etc that is sent to someone to look at, before supplies become generally available to the public. [1]
Generally, corporate tax paid in advance.
An amount of money paid for services before they are delivered. [1]

In February 2007, the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation joined forces with the governments of Russia, Italy, Canada, the UK and Norway to pledge $1.5bn for the first Advance Market Commitment (AMC), a pioneering financial mechanism designed to motivate pharmaceutical companies to develop a childhood vaccine for pneumococcal disease in the developing world. AMC is a pool of government funding designed to stimulate the creation of vaccines for the developing world, for which the commercial market is limited.  Italy pledged $635m, the UK $485m, Canada $200m, Russia $80m, Norway $50m and the Gates Foundation $50m.The AMC provides a guaranteed market for pneumococcal vaccines, underwritten by donors but with an agreement that recipient countries will assume an increasing share of the purchase cost over its lifetime until 2020. The AMC marked a new step in efforts to stimulate pharmaceutical companies to devise and distribute medicines and vaccines to boost health in countries where the lack of any significant market means there are scant commercial incentives.Donor nations guarantee purchases from pharmaceutical companies of medicines or vaccines for diseases in countries with limited resources to pay. There are discussions underway to launch AMCs for products to help with other diseases; and ideas to extend the concept to other areas including stimulating green technology in the developing world. [1] ViewVaccines deal to help poor statesGreen stimulus for poorer countries

A payment made before a product is delivered or a piece of work is completed. [1]

The ways that transfer prices should be reached in particular situations are sometimes agreed between tax authorities and taxpayers for a period of time covering more than one year. Most often two tax authorities will reach a bilateral APA in relation to transactions by a taxpayer between the two countries. Sometimes a multilateral APA will cover discussions concluded between three or more countries. [1]
A cheap plane or train fare that must be bought a particular number of days before you travel. [1]

When an entity sells new bonds with the purpose of raising money for the redemption of previously issued bonds. In the case of municipal bonds, the refunding issue can be several years in advance of the issue to be redeemed.
Using the most modern ideas, equipment, and methods. [1]

Shares that increase in value on a particular day of trading on a stockmarket. [1]
Stocks that increase in value on a particular day of trading on a stockmarket. [1]
Something that helps you to be better or more successful than others. [1]
The amount by which a bank account is in debt. [1]
When the value of a country's imports is greater than the value of its exports. [1]
When an independent auditor finds that a company's accounts are not internally consistent or do not conform with the accounting principles governing the company's legal jurisdiction or listing base.

Normally used in the insurance business, when individuals buying a particular policy have a much higher than average chance of making a claim. Companies tend to impose restrictions to avoid such situations, for instance requiring medical examinations before allowing people to buy health insurance, or sharply increasing the cost of insurance for journalists going into a war zone.

To tell people publicly about a product or service in order to persuade them to buy it.To inform people publicly, for example in a newspaper or magazine, that a job is available and invite them to apply for it. [1]
A picture, piece of film, or piece of writing that is used to tell people publicly about a product or service in order to persuade them to buy it. [1]
A person or organization that puts out an advertisement. [1]
Telling people publicly about a product or service in order to persuade them to buy it. [1]

Somewhere that advertising is placed or shown. [1]

Information given to someone, especially by an expert, so that they know what to do and can make the right decision.A document giving someone details about a sale or purchase that they are involved in, for example a note to a buyer giving details of goods that they are being sent. [1]
A document showing that goods have been sent to a customer. [1]
A document sent by the post office telling someone who has sent a letter by recorded delivery that it has been delivered. [1]

Existing to give advice or having the purpose of giving advice.A warning sent out by a government department, a company, or an official organization. [1]

A company that either partially owns or is partially owned by another company. Both companies are described as affiliates, whatever the size of the shareholding. However, in the case of a majority or controlling stake, it is more common to describe the company holding the stake as the parent, and the company in which the stake is held as the subsidiary.
Marketing using other websites in order to market products and services from your website. The other websites receive a payment for providing this service. [1]

Somebody who is in a position to influence the actions of a company, for instance through ownership of a large number of company shares, or through a role on the board or in the management of a company, or simply because they have influence over decision-makers in the company.

Having plenty of money, a nice house, expensive things etc. [1]
Feelings of unhappiness that people have when they work too hard, because they are spending all their time trying to get more money and possessions. [1]
Having enough money to operate or stay out of debt. [1]
Already mentioned on the same page or on a previous page. [1]

Buying and selling stocks, shares, etc after the financial markets have officially closed for the day. [1]
Buying and selling shares, bonds etc after a financial market has officially closed for the day. [1]
After-sales service/ support: help that is given to someone who has bought a product, for example free repairs or help in using the product. [1]
Repairs and advice given to a customer by a company after the customer has bought a product from the company. [1]
Relating to the amount that remains after tax has been paid. [1]
A loss made by a company after tax has been calculated. [1]
A company's profit after tax has been taken away. [1]
The period immediately after the market listing of shares issued via an Initial Public Offering (IPO), when investors can trade in the stock for the first time.
If something is insured against all risks, it is insured against any kind of loss or damage. [1]
Unfair treatment of someone because of their age, especially when they are not given a job because they are too old. [1]
A method of analysing a company's accounts receivable, by classifying them according to the length of time the amounts have been past due.
Treating people unfairly because of their age, especially because they are old. [1]

When one entity, called the agent, represents another, called the principal, in transactions with a third party. Financial institutions may offer agency services to individuals or corporations, for instance in the case of a trust when a trustee acts on behalf of a customer, or to sell or buy securities.
A broker that buys and sells shares for clients without keeping supplies of shares itself, unlike broker-dealers and marketmakers. [1]

A list of the subjects to be discussed at a meeting. A list of things that someone considers important or that they are planning to do.  Hidden agenda: someone's secret plan or aims, rather than the ones that they say that they have.[1]

The term "agflation" stems from a combination of agriculture and inflation.Agflation or agricultural price inflation means a rise in the prices of agricultural commodities leading to broader inflationary pressures, particularly in emerging markets where food stuffs make up larger weightings in consumer price indices.  [1]
The total after a lot of different parts or figures have been added together. One of the measurements used when calculating the amount of money in an economy at a particular time.[1]
The total amount of goods and services demanded in an economy by companies, consumers, and government bodies, including foreign participants. Also known as total spending.
The total amount of goods and services demanded in an economy by companies, consumers, and government bodies, including foreign participants. Also known as total spending.

The number of shares in a put or call stock options contract multiplied by the exercise price (or strike price) at which those shares can be bought or sold. If an employee has a stock options agreement giving him the opportunity to buy 1,000 shares in his company at US$3.00 each, then the aggregate exercise price of those options is US$3,000.
The total amount of goods and services produced within an economy. Also called total output.
The total amount of goods and services produced within an economy. Also called total output.

A per tonne levy that applies to the extraction or importation of sand, gravel and crushed rock (with numerous exceptions) subjected to commercial exploitation in the UK. The levy has for some years been under challenge by the British Aggregates Association through litigation, which has still to be resolved. [1]
When figures are combined to make a total, or the total amount produced.When different things are combined to make a whole, or the whole that is produced. [1]

The practice or science of farming. [1]
Agriculture and food production seen as an industry. [1]
The study, practice, and organization of animal and crop production in farming. [1]

This is the name given by Yvo de Boer, the plain-speaking United Nations climate chief, to efforts by rich countries to rebrand their existing development help to poor countries as climate change-related aid.  [1]
