A course in which the student works at home and sends completed work to their teacher by mail. [1]

In banking, an institution that carries out services on behalf of another, or acts as an agent for another, normally in a country that the latter bank cannot access because of regulatory barriers or cost factors.
Similar to the one you have just mentioned.Resulting from or connected with what you have just mentioned. [1]

Using power in a dishonest or illegal way in order to get money or an advantage of some kind.Information on a computer that is corrupt has been damaged and can no longer be read or used by a computer.

The crime of giving or receiving money, gifts, a better job etc in exchange for doing something dishonest or illegal.When someone who has power or authority uses it in a dishonest or illegal way to get money or an advantage. [1]
Products that are combinations of cosmetics and pharmaceuticals, and the industry that makes them. [1]
Cosmetic changes are small and do not affect the most important parts of something. [1]
The amount of money that you have to pay in order to buy, do, or produce something. Costs: the money that a business or an individual must regularly spend.[1]

An accountant who examines the costs relating to different parts of a business and the cost of producing different products or services rather than doing accounting for formal, legal, or tax requirements. [1]
A type of accounting that focuses on evaluating production and operating costs.
When a business attaches particular costs to particular activities, products etc. [1]

Term used in foreign trade contracts indicating that the price of the goods sold includes the cost of freight, but not insurance, which is borne by the buyer. If insurance is also included, the term used is cost, insurance and freight (CIF), which effectively means the seller is bearing all the risks of delivery.

Term used in foreign trade contracts indicating that the price of the goods sold includes the cost of freight, but not insurance, which is borne by the buyer. If insurance is also included, the term used is cost, insurance and freight (CIF), which effectively means the seller is bearing all the risks of delivery.
Another name for cost allocation. [1]
The costs involved in operating a company or making a product. [1]

The cost basis is the original value of an asset or security at the time it was purchased and reflects a number of items including fees, commissions, stock splits and other adjustments. Used for tax purposes, the cost basis helps determine the capital loss or gain of an asset when it is sold. The process of determining the cost basis is called cost basis accounting. [1]

A part of a business, evaluated separately in accounting terms, which incurs costs and is not expected to make a profit - unlike a profit centre. A good example would be the research and development unit of a biotechnology company.
When an organization keeps costs low, or within a limit that has been planned. [1]
The process of making sure that a company or organization does not spend too much. [1]
The act of saving money by making a product or performing an activity in a better way. [1]
When prices of goods and services increase because of the increased cost of wages, raw materials materials used to produce goodsetc. [1]
The company, product etc with the lowest costs in its industry or market compared with its competitors. [1]

The cost matters hypothesis (CMH) is a term coined by Jack Bogle, the founder of low-cost passive investment specialist Vanguard. In a 2003 issue of CFA Magazine, Mr Bogle wrote that whether markets are more efficient or less efficient, the costs of investing will still matter. He suggests that just as the efficient markets hypothesis has gained wide acceptance, so will his observation that the mathematical expectation of the long-term investor is a shortfall to the stock market's return   a shortfall that is equal to the costs of our system of financial intermediation. In other words, advisory fees, brokerage commissions, transactions costs, custody and legal fees and securities processing expenses all add up to take away from the investor. Mr Bogle estimated that intermediation costs accounted for 3% of the value of the US equity market.   cost matters hypothesis in the news In March 2010, an FT columnist observed that although no one much believes in the efficient market hypothesis anymore, its lesser known cousin, the CMH appears to go from strength to strength.

The cost incurred in owning or borrowing capital, including interest payments and dividend obligations. [1] In order to provide an incentive for those willing to provide capital, the risk-adjusted return on the capital used to fund any given business needs to be higher than the cost of the capital.A company s assets are financed by either debt or equity. Risk-adjusted return on capital is the average of the costs of these sources of financing, each of which is weighted by its respective use in the given situation. By taking a weighted average, it is possible to determine how much interest the company has to pay for each monetary unit it finances. [2]
The cost of an investment position, including the interest paid in financing it.

The cost of debt is the effective rate that a company pays on its current loans, bonds and various other forms of debt. The measure provides an idea as to the overall rate being paid by the company to use debt financing. Riskier companies generally have a higher cost of debt. [1]

The cost of equity is the rate of return required by the company's ordinary shareholders in order for that investor to bear the risk of holding that company's shares. The return consists both of dividend and capital gains. The returns are expected future returns, not historical returns.  There are two formulae commonly used to determine cost of equity. The first is the dividend growth model, which is (next year's forecast annual dividend divided by the current stock price) + the anticipated dividend growth rate. The other formula is the capital asset pricing model, a more complicated formula which includes risk assumptions.   cost of equity in the news In October 2013, an FT writer was considering valuation metrics for Twitter's planned IPO. On aggressive ad sales projections, he wrote, a cost of equity of 22 per cent has to be built-in to reach a valuation of $15bn, the top of the range of estimates for Twitter.
The interest cost a party bears for borrowing money. In the case of a brokerage, it is the interest paid on its inventory of stocks and bonds.
The total variable costs (costs of materials, workers etc) of goods sold in a particular period of time, before other costs are taken into account. [1]

How expensive food, housing, clothing and other basic necessities are in a given city or country. Changes in cost of living can be measured in index form, with many countries using an inflation indicator, such as the consumer price index. This will then act as a yardstick to determine the level of a cost-of-living bonus or wage adjustment, sometimes known as a cost of living adjustment (COLA).

How expensive food, housing, clothing and other basic necessities are in a given city or country. Changes in cost of living can be measured in index form, with many countries using an inflation indicator, such as the consumer price index. This will then act as a yardstick to determine the level of a cost-of-living bonus or wage adjustment, sometimes known as a cost of living adjustment (COLA).
See cost of living.
See cost of living
Money some people receive in addition to their normal pay to cover increases in the cost of living. The amount is related to changes in the cost-of-living index. [1]

An index that shows the rate by which the cost of living is changing. It works by comparing the current price of particular goods, for example food or clothing, against the cost of the same goods in previous years. [1]
Another name for carrying cost. [1]
The expenses incurred in selling a product, such as marketing and distribution.
See overrun.
The cost of an advertisement, divided by the number of times that people see it. [1]
Used to talk about how much a particular form of advertising costs to reach one thousand viewers, readers etc. [1]
The price of something that is sold for what it cost to produce, without any profit for the producer. [1]
See current cost accounting
An organization's different costs and the way they are related to each other. [1]
See cost and freight.
See cost and freight.
See cost and freight.
A means of decision-making that compares the potential benefits of a planned course of action with the costs that would be incurred in the process.
Something is cost-effective if the cost incurred is worth the benefit gained.
The amount of money that you have to pay the owner of a website each time someone visits it and clicks on your advertisement. [1]

Cost-plus product/ price/ basis etc: if something is made or done on a cost-plus basis, it is made or done at an agreed price plus an extra amount. This is done when the cost of making a product etc is not known at the time the agreement to buy it is made. [1]
When the driving force behind rising prices is the increased cost of producing goods, rather than stronger demand by consumers.
Money that a company has saved by deliberately spending less. [1]
The process of calculating the cost of a future activity or product, or the calculation itself. [1]
An industry consisting of people who work from home, making things such as toys or clothes an industry consisting of small businesses operating from home. [1]
A group of people that are chosen to make rules, laws, or decisions, or to give advice.In Britain, the organization that is responsible for local government in a particular region.
In Britain, a tax paid to your local government authority that depends on the value of the house or apartment that you live in. [1]
A lawyer who represents a client in a court of law.A lawyer or group of lawyers who give legal advice to a company or organization. [1]
The process of listening to someone who has a problem and giving them professional advice. [1]
Someone whose job is to help or advise people. [1]
The place where you are served in a shop, bank etc. [1]
A bid that is higher than a previous bid, for example when more than one company is trying to take control of another company. [1]
People who work in shops and serve customers. [1]
When someone who is being taken to court by another person tries to take that other person to court and ask for money from them. [1]
Intended or able to help reduce inflation (increase in prices). [1]
An offer that is higher than a previous one, for example when more than one company is trying to take control of another company. [1]
In international trade, the act of buying goods as part of a countertrade agreement. [1]

Not following the normal pattern of business activity, for example increasing when other activities are decreasing.Countercyclical actions are intended to change the way in which the economy is behaving at different times, for example actions to stop it growing too fast, or to help it grow when it is not growing. [1]

One of the big problems was that banks entered the global financial crisis with weak capital bases, despite years of boom. That failure to retain a decent share of profits and build up reserves is what regulators want banks to reverse: hence the term countercyclical buffering. [1]ViewQ & A: Global body lays down the rules over governance

Stocks whose market value moves in the opposite direction to economic trends. Normally refers to stocks that rise when the economy weakens, for instance because there is constant demand for these companies' goods or services (e.g. food, medicine) or because the economic downturn actually increases demand for particular products (e.g. temporary help firms).
Made to look exactly like something, usually illegally.To copy something so that it looks like something else, usually illegally. [1]
To officially tell people to ignore an instruction, order etc. [1]
Someone or something that has the same job or purpose as someone or something in a different place. [1]
The person or company who you are buying from or selling to, when you buy or sell something such as a bond. [1]
The risk that the other side of a transaction, such as a swap or a credit issuance, will be unable to meet its obligations. [1] See credit risk.
Having the opposite effect from the one that you intended. [1]
Similar to barter, except that the two parties exchanging goods pay money to each other under separate contracts. A type of countertrade.
To sign a document that someone else has signed, for example to show your agreement. [1]
A term encompassing a variety of reciprocal trading arrangements, including barter and counterpurchase.
A duty imposed on imports to offset subsidies accorded to producers in the exporting country.
The part of a large organization that is responsible for looking after money. [1]
The disclosure by a company, either publically or in confidence to governments, of tax figures and, potentially, other financial data on a country-by-country basis. [1]

The extent to which consumers' evaluation of a product is driven by the product's country of origin (the 'made in' label). Such effects can have a favourable or unfavourable impact on consumer evaluations. In many product categories, consumers use country of origin as a cue to judge the quality, prestige or performance of the product. When there is a match between the perceived 'strength' of the country and the desired product features, the country of origin label will have a favourable effect. Consumers prefer German-made cars because of the association of Germany with craftsmanship and engineering. Italy and France enjoy a positive image for design and style. As a result, luxury goods originating from these countries enjoy a favourable COO image. To cope with unfavourable COO images, companies can resort to several strategies including: - building up strong brand equity (eg, Hyundai, Corona beer) - disguising the country of origin (eg, Giordano and Bossini, Hong Kong based clothing brands) - boosting the country image for the category (Chilean wines) - buying brands with a favorable COO image (eg, acquisition of Volvo and Jaguar/Land Rover by Geely and Tata, respectively). Example Herborist is a Chinese skincare brand marketed by state-owned Shanghai Jahwa, one of China's largest personal care firms.  The company aspires to turn Herborist into a high-end global skincare brand. Unfortunately, China has a poor quality image for personal care and food products. To counter that image, Shanghai Jahwa changed the tagline for Herborist to  made in Shanghai . In promoting the brand, it also stresses that the brand is grounded in traditional Chinese herbal science. [1]    See Article: 'Made in China' does not always translate well
The risk associated with investing in a particular country, or providing funds to its government. Also called sovereign risk.
In Britain, a court that makes decisions on legal cases brought by private citizens within a particular area, that are not important enough to be heard in a high court. [1]
Interest paid on a bond through to maturity, expressed as a percentage of the face value.

The term coupon derives from a detachable part of a bond certificate entitling the bearer to interest on a particular date. Bonds issued with such coupons (coupon bonds or bearer bonds) are increasingly rare.
See equivalent bond yield
See Fed pass
The rate of interest paid on a bond. [1]
A number of coupons attached to a bond. [1]

A person or company whose job is to collect packages, documents etc and deliver them somewhere.Someone who is employed by a travel company to help people when they are on holiday, for example to give them information or organize trips to interesting places. [1]
A series of classes or studies in a particular subject. [1]
Computer software designed for educational purposes. [1]

The court: the people in a court, especially the judge, other officials, and the jury (ordinary people who decide certain cases). The phrase is often used when talking about what a judge or jury think or decide about a case. A place where all the information concerning a crime or disagreement is given so that it can be judged. [1]
A place where law cases are judged. [1]
An order from a court of law, telling someone to do something or to act in a particular way. [1]
Provided free to a customer or to the public. (By) courtesy of: if something is provided by courtesy of someone, it is provided for free by them.[1]
A call from a company to one of its customers, for example in order to find out if the customer is satisfied with the service. [1]
A room in a law court where cases are judged. [1]

These are loan agreements which lack, or possess fewer, financial covenants, or stipulations which protect lenders. Cov-lite agreements also allow borrowers to incur additional indebtedness as financial performance improves.  [1]

Clause in a corporate bond agreement in which the issuer makes certain promises designed to protect the bondholder. These could involve commitments on debt-equity levels, dividend payments, cashflow, etc. Sometimes called protective covenant orrestrictive covenant.

Clause in a corporate bond agreement in which the issuer makes certain promises designed to protect the bondholder. These could involve commitments on debt-equity levels, dividend payments, cashflow, etc. Sometimes called protective covenant orrestrictive covenant.

Clause in a corporate bond agreement in which the issuer makes certain promises designed to protect the bondholder. These could involve commitments on debt-equity levels, dividend payments, cashflow, etc. Sometimes called protective covenant orrestrictive covenant.
The assets underlying a security issue, particularly a bond.
An amount of money you have to pay at some restaurants and clubs in addition to the cost of food and drinks. [1]

A temporary document sent to you by your insurance company or dealer, proving that an insurance contract exists. A cover note is usually sent to you when you take out insurance, while the complete contract is being prepared. [1]
The area served by a broadcaster or mobile phone company. The amount of protection given to you by an insurance agreement.[1]
When a securities house's research department begins to follow a particular stock.

A figure used to calculate the solvency and ability of a pension fund to meet its liabilities. A ratio above 100 per cent indicates that the fund is in good health and capable of meeting its payments or liabilities, while a ratio of less than 100 per cent means the fund is in danger of being unable to pay its members. [1]

A bond backed by assets such as mortgage loans (covered mortgage bond). Covered bonds are backed by pools of mortgages that remain on the issuer's balance sheet, as opposed to mortgage-backed securities such as collateralised mortgage obligations (CMOs), where the assets are taken off the balance sheet.

A bond backed by assets such as mortgage loans (covered mortgage bond). Covered bonds are backed by pools of mortgages that remain on the issuer's balance sheet, as opposed to mortgage-backed securities such as collateralised mortgage obligations (CMOs), where the assets are taken off the balance sheet.
See covered bond
See covered option/warrant.
An option or warrant that is backed by the issuer holding at least some of the stock that would be bought or sold when the option or warrant is exercised.

Covered warrants are financial products sold to speculate on rises or falls in underlying assets, for example, shares, indices, currencies and commodities. They are issued by financial institutions, typically investment banks, which maintain the buying and selling prices on the exchange. They give the holder the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an underlying asset, at a specified price, on or before a predetermined date. Covered warrants are only issued by financial institutions, unlike normal warrants which are issued by corporations. Covered warrants provide gearing by only requiring investors to commit a fraction of the price it would cost to purchase the underlying asset directly. Example: - an underlying share price is 100p - a covered warrant on that share may be trading at 20p - an investor buying the warrant at 20p is gaining exposure to price movements in an asset worth 100p, a gearing of five times Investors talking about covered warrants often also mention delta. The delta of a covered warrant measure the sensitivity of the option price to the cange in the price of the underlying asset.  Example: - a delta of 40 per cent means that if the price of the underlying asset increases by  1.00 the price of the covered warrant increases by  0.40. - the higher the delta, the higher the price of a covered warrant (and therefore the less risky the product). Leverage, or effective gearing, is the degree to which the covered warrant's price magnifies the price movement of the underlying asset.  Covered warrants with leverage of four times might be expected to move approximately four times as much in percentage terms as the price of their underlying asset. But leverage can only ever be an approximation because the figure changes constantly with changes to the price of the underlying asset, the warrants and the time to expiry.                                      There are two types of covered warrant: call and put, allowing the holder to benefit from rising or falling asset prices. With a call warrant the holder has the right, but not the obligation, to buy an underlying asset at a predetermined price (the exercise or strike price) on or before a date in the future (the expiry or exercise date). So a call warrant usually rises in value when the underlying asset rises in value, as it gives the right to buy the asset more cheaply and make a profit. Example: - a call warrant gives the right to buy one share at 110p. If the current share price is 100p, the warrant price might start at 5p as there is only limited potential for profit if the share price later rises. If the share price does rise to 130p (a rise of 30 per cent) the warrant price would rise to at least 20p which is an increase of 300 per cent.  With a pull warrant the holder has the right but not the obligation to sell an underlying asset at a predetermined price on or before a date in the future. So a put warrant normally rises in value when the underlying asset falls in value, as it gives the holder the right to sell at a higher price. example: a put warrant gives the right to sell one share at 90p. If the current share price is 100p, the warrant price might start at 5p, as there is only some potential for profit if the share price later falls. But if the share price does fall to 60p, for example, a fall of 40 per cent, the warrant price would rise to 30p (a rise of 500 per cent), as the right to sell at 90p is 'worth' 30p.
A letter that you send with another document or a package, explaining why it has been sent or giving extra information about it. [1]
Someone who is dishonest in business or does bad quality work, usually because they want to make money quickly. [1]
A house builder with no proper training or official qualifications who does work of a low standard. [1]
Written abbreviation for credit. [1]
A job or activity that takes a lot of skill, usually one in which you make things using your hands and special tools. [1]
A trade union whose members all work in skilled jobs that involve making or doing things with their hands. [1]
A skilled male worker in a job that involves making things with your hands. [1]
The special skill someone uses to make something beautiful with their hands.The quality that something has when it is made with a lot of skill or made by a craftsman or craftswoman. [1]
A skilled female worker in a job that involves making things with your hands. [1]
When a company that is bankrupt asks a court of law to decide how its creditors people or companies who are owed money should be paid, rather than trying to reach an agreement with them. [1]
A large tall machine that lifts things and moves them from one place to another, used especially on building sites and for unloading ships. [1]
A rapid collapse in asset prices and/or economic conditions, normally when values as a whole have reached levels that are so high they are no longer backed by fundamentals.
A way of trying to stop a currency losing value too quickly by connecting its value to another currency, but allowing it to change between upper and lower limits. [1]

Creating shared value (CSV) conveys the idea that a business must do two things simultaneously to be successful in the long-term: create economic value for both the company and the society. The CSV definition of the role of business in society has emerged with a clear focus on long-term thinking and aligning the interests of shareholders and societies for mutual benefit. CSV carries the idea that in order to overcome the profound and harmful disconnect between the needs of society and business, a business must create value for society alongside creating value for shareholders in order to be successful in the long term.[1]
A lightly ironic term for deceptive accounting practices that make figures appear other than they really are.
A document which gives details about how a product is to be advertised. [1]

Creative destruction refers to the complete upheaval of the established order in the pursuit of innovation. The term was developed by the Austrian economist Joseph Schumpeter, who argued that only those comfortable with creative destruction could call themselves entrepreneurs. [1]
Someone in a company or advertising agency whose job is to manage the advertising and selling of a product or range of products. [1]
Unusual but not illegal ways of getting or providing finance. [1]

The training, education, or experience that give you the ability to do a particular job or task well, especially in the opinion of other people.A letter or other document that proves that someone is who they say they are or has the ability to do a particular job or task. [1]

Any sum of money advanced as a loan, or available for loan. Also, money received in an account - a positive accounting entry. A balance in the account-holder's favour is a credit balance. The opposite of debit.
An arrangement with a shop that allows customers to buy goods up to a certain value every month and pay for them later within an agreed time. [1]
A note from a bank informing a customer that an amount of money has been put into their account. [1]
See credit bureau.
A check on someone's financial situation to see if it is safe to lend them money. [1]
Person who assesses creditworthiness and, in the case of debt issuers, determines credit ratings.
A check on someone's financial situation to see if it is safe to lend them money. [1]
A balance showing that more money has been received or is owed to a company than has been paid out or is owed by the company. [1]
A bank that lends money to businesses and individuals. [1]

Also known as credit agency. Commercial organisation that makes money by supplying information about the credit history and financial strength of businesses and individuals, normally to credit card companies, banks and other lenders.

Plastic card issued by a financial institution, credit card company or other credit provider which consumers use to buy goods and services on credit. The issuer actually pays for the product and the consumer repays the issuer later. Interest begins to accrue after a specified interval on the outstanding amount to be repaid.
A payment made to buy something using a credit card a regular payment made by the user of a credit card to a credit card company to pay for what they have bought using the card, and any interest. [1]
What is owed to a credit card issuer by its customers.  See credit card.
A check carried out by a lender or employer, looking at someone's record in repaying loans before giving them a new loan or a job. [1]
A co-operative that lends money, collected from its members, at low rates of interest. [1]
A company that lends money to people or businesses. [1]
In a business, the department under a credit controller that is responsible for chasing unpaid debts.
When creditors become reluctant to lend money to businesses or individuals because of the increased risk of default due to adverse economic or political conditions. View Question 2: Credit
When creditors become reluctant to lend money to businesses or individuals because of the increased risk of default due to adverse economic or political conditions. View Question 2: Credit
See credit default swap  CDS

Credit default swaps offer protection against the non-payment of unsecured corporate or sovereign debt. A typical CDS contract features one counterparty agreeing to "sell" protection to another. The "protected" party pays a fee each year in exchange for a guarantee that if a bond goes into default, the seller of protection will provide compensation. [1] ViewTime to outlaw naked credit default swapsThe problems with derivative regulation

Credit default swaps offer protection against the non-payment of unsecured corporate or sovereign debt. A typical CDS contract features one counterparty agreeing to "sell" protection to another. The "protected" party pays a fee each year in exchange for a guarantee that if a bond goes into default, the seller of protection will provide compensation. [1] ViewTime to outlaw naked credit default swapsThe problems with derivative regulation

Credit default swaps offer protection against the non-payment of unsecured corporate or sovereign debt. A typical CDS contract features one counterparty agreeing to "sell" protection to another. The "protected" party pays a fee each year in exchange for a guarantee that if a bond goes into default, the seller of protection will provide compensation. [1] ViewTime to outlaw naked credit default swapsThe problems with derivative regulation

A two-sided contract between buyer and seller that enables them to manage their credit risk.  This over-the-counter derivative is designed to protect the investor against defaults such as bankruptcy.  Types of credit derivatives include credit default swaps (CDS).  [1] ViewThe problems with derivative regulation

The practice in which central banks purchase private sector assets with a view to adding liquidity to a troubled market and so easing the flow of credit and lending in the economy. In 2009, the Federal Reserve undertook credit easing, buying commercial paper and residential mortgage backed securities. The Bank of England and European Central Bank bought corporate bonds. Sometimes the purchases were funded through the creation of money, which links the idea to quantitative easing, sometimes sales of government bills offset funded the purchases, leaving the quantity of money unchanged.  George Osborne announced a programme of credit easing at the Conservative party conference in October 2011. [1] View Credit easing explained (interactive feature)
When elements such as insurance and bank guarantees are added to a debt issue to ensure it gets a high credit rating.
An arrangement that allows a company or person to borrow an agreed amount of money for a particular period of time. [1]
When banks are forced by the government to stop lending completely. [1]
A person's record in repaying loans, which is checked when they ask for a new loan or credit card. [1]
Information about a company's ability to pay its suppliers. [1]
Insurance taken out by borrowers paying back loans, that covers illness, losing their job and other events that may prevent them making the regular payments. [1]
See credit line.

An agreement to lend money up to a specific amount (the credit limit) for a stated period. Unlike a loan the borrower can decide how much of the agreed funding (if any) they wish to draw down. Interest is only paid on the amount that is actually borrowed, not on the amount made available. A credit line, or line of credit can be made between a bank and an individual, but equally, can be made between any other kind of lender or borrower, even on a national level.   credit line in the news At the end of June 2014 fears of a banking crisis in Bulgaria eased after the EU approved a LV3.3bn (1.7bn) emergency credit line from the European Central Bank. The liquidity move followed runs on two of the country's biggest lenders over the preceding week.
A loss made by a financial institution on its lending activities. [1]
A market for borrowing money in the form of bank loans, bonds etc. [1]
A document sent to a customer who is owed money, for example because they have returned goods. [1]

A credit or rating outlook indicates the potential direction of a rating over the intermediate term, typically six months to two years. When determining a rating outlook, consideration is given to any changes in the economic and/or fundamental business conditions. An outlook is not necessarily a precursor of a rating change, and is often used to maintain the stability of long-term ratings. The outlook provides information to investors on the potential evolution of a rating, hence it increases the precision of the rating. ExampleFor rating agencies such as Moody s, Fitch and Standard & Poor's, a positive outlook means that a rating may be raised. A negative means that a rating may be lowered, stable means that a rating is not likely to change and developing (or evolving) means that a rating may be raised or lowered. [1]

A company's policy on when its customers should pay for goods or services they have ordered a government's policy at a particular time on how easy or difficult it should be for people and businesses to borrow and how much it should cost. The government influences this through changes in interest rates. [1]
The financial strength and previous credit record of an applicant for new credit.

Also called debt rating, this is a method of measuring the creditworthiness of a debt issuer. The ratings provided by the main credit rating agencies, Moody's Investors Service, Standard & Poor's (S&P;) and Fitch, evaluate issuers worldwide and are very closely followed. A top rating means there is almost no likelihood of the borrower failing to meet interest payments or full redemption of the issue. [1] Credit ratings are opinions expressed on an alphanumeric scale on the relative ability and willingness of a debt issuer to meet financial commitments. Credit ratings published by the main global rating agencies aim to provide ratings that are objective and transparent, as well as consistent and comparable across instruments, maturities, industries and countries. Some sectors, maturities and countries have their own specific rating scales.The long-term global rating scale at S&P; and Fitch contain nine grades and goes from the highest grade to the lowest grade (in increasing order of riskiness): AAA, AA, A, BBB, BB, B, CCC, CC, C. For Moody's, the scale contains nine grades and goes from the highest grade to the lowest grade (in increasing order of riskiness): Aaa, Aa, A, Baa, Ba, B, Caa, Ca, C.All three global credit rating agencies, for each full grade other than AAA (or Aaa), CC (or Ca), or C, include a positive, neutral or negative modifier for Fitch and S&P; or a numerical modifier for Moody s. This brings the nine point rating scale to a 21 point scale. For instance, for the AA grade there are AA+, AA, AA- or Aa1, Aa2, Aa3. [2] Example Government credit ratings take into account three main elements. These are public debt as a percentage of gross domestic product, the budget deficit (the amount government spending exceeds income) and debt affordability (interest costs as a percentage of revenue). In 2011, Germany with a triple A rating, has a debt-to-GDP ratio of 73 per cent, a deficit of 3 per cent and a debt affordability ratio of 5 per cent. B plus rated Greece has debt-to-GDP at 127 per cent, a deficit of 15 per cent and debt affordability on 15 per cent. [3]

Also called debt rating, this is a method of measuring the creditworthiness of a debt issuer. The ratings provided by the main credit rating agencies, Moody's Investors Service, Standard & Poor's (S&P;) and Fitch, evaluate issuers worldwide and are very closely followed. A top rating means there is almost no likelihood of the borrower failing to meet interest payments or full redemption of the issue. [1] Credit ratings are opinions expressed on an alphanumeric scale on the relative ability and willingness of a debt issuer to meet financial commitments. Credit ratings published by the main global rating agencies aim to provide ratings that are objective and transparent, as well as consistent and comparable across instruments, maturities, industries and countries. Some sectors, maturities and countries have their own specific rating scales.The long-term global rating scale at S&P; and Fitch contain nine grades and goes from the highest grade to the lowest grade (in increasing order of riskiness): AAA, AA, A, BBB, BB, B, CCC, CC, C. For Moody's, the scale contains nine grades and goes from the highest grade to the lowest grade (in increasing order of riskiness): Aaa, Aa, A, Baa, Ba, B, Caa, Ca, C.All three global credit rating agencies, for each full grade other than AAA (or Aaa), CC (or Ca), or C, include a positive, neutral or negative modifier for Fitch and S&P; or a numerical modifier for Moody s. This brings the nine point rating scale to a 21 point scale. For instance, for the AA grade there are AA+, AA, AA- or Aa1, Aa2, Aa3. [2] Example Government credit ratings take into account three main elements. These are public debt as a percentage of gross domestic product, the budget deficit (the amount government spending exceeds income) and debt affordability (interest costs as a percentage of revenue). In 2011, Germany with a triple A rating, has a debt-to-GDP ratio of 73 per cent, a deficit of 3 per cent and a debt affordability ratio of 5 per cent. B plus rated Greece has debt-to-GDP at 127 per cent, a deficit of 15 per cent and debt affordability on 15 per cent. [3]

Also called debt rating, this is a method of measuring the creditworthiness of a debt issuer. The ratings provided by the main credit rating agencies, Moody's Investors Service, Standard & Poor's (S&P;) and Fitch, evaluate issuers worldwide and are very closely followed. A top rating means there is almost no likelihood of the borrower failing to meet interest payments or full redemption of the issue. [1] Credit ratings are opinions expressed on an alphanumeric scale on the relative ability and willingness of a debt issuer to meet financial commitments. Credit ratings published by the main global rating agencies aim to provide ratings that are objective and transparent, as well as consistent and comparable across instruments, maturities, industries and countries. Some sectors, maturities and countries have their own specific rating scales.The long-term global rating scale at S&P; and Fitch contain nine grades and goes from the highest grade to the lowest grade (in increasing order of riskiness): AAA, AA, A, BBB, BB, B, CCC, CC, C. For Moody's, the scale contains nine grades and goes from the highest grade to the lowest grade (in increasing order of riskiness): Aaa, Aa, A, Baa, Ba, B, Caa, Ca, C.All three global credit rating agencies, for each full grade other than AAA (or Aaa), CC (or Ca), or C, include a positive, neutral or negative modifier for Fitch and S&P; or a numerical modifier for Moody s. This brings the nine point rating scale to a 21 point scale. For instance, for the AA grade there are AA+, AA, AA- or Aa1, Aa2, Aa3. [2] Example Government credit ratings take into account three main elements. These are public debt as a percentage of gross domestic product, the budget deficit (the amount government spending exceeds income) and debt affordability (interest costs as a percentage of revenue). In 2011, Germany with a triple A rating, has a debt-to-GDP ratio of 73 per cent, a deficit of 3 per cent and a debt affordability ratio of 5 per cent. B plus rated Greece has debt-to-GDP at 127 per cent, a deficit of 15 per cent and debt affordability on 15 per cent. [3]

The ratings provided by the main credit rating agencies, Moody's Investors Service, Standard & Poor's (S&P;) and Fitch, evaluate issuers worldwide and are very closely followed. A top rating means there is almost no likelihood of the borrower failing to meet interest payments or full redemption of the issue. This brings the nine point rating scale to a 21 point scale. For instance, for the AA grade there are AA+, AA, AA- or Aa1, Aa2, Aa3.
