Written abbreviation for dividend. [1]
Written abbreviation for debt-equity ratio. [1]

Happening or done every day. Connected with a single day.  Also daily paper: a newspaper that is printed and sold every day except Sunday.  A newspaper that is printed and sold every day including Sunday.[1]

The maximum amount, set by the exchange, that the price of a stock, commodity or futures/options contract can rise or fall in a single day. In some cases, trading in an asset is automatically suspended when the daily limit is reached.

A situation in the stockmarket when dealers buy and sell to each other so that investors will think that there is a lot of trading in the market. This will encourage investors to invest and prices to rise. [1]

A bad effect on something that makes it weaker or less successful. Physical harm caused to something.  Damages: money that a court orders someone to pay to someone else for harming them or their property, or causing them financial loss.  To cause physical harm to something.  To have a bad effect on something in a way that makes it weaker or less successful.[1]
An insurance claim for something that has been damaged but not completely lost. [1]
Extra money paid by an employer to a worker, usually one working in the building industry, who is doing an especially dangerous job. [1]

A dark pool  is the romantic   or sinister, depending on your viewpoint   name given to a network that allows traders to buy or sell large orders without running the risk that other traders will work out what is going on and put the price up, or down, to take advantage of the order. They have been criticised for their lack of transparency and because the inevitable fragmentation of trading could lead to less efficient pricing in traditional open stock exchanges. [1]    In dark pools, pre-trade prices   the price at which shares are offered for sale   are not visible to anyone, even the participants in them, and the price at which shares change hands is only revealed after the trade is done. [2]     the purpose of dark pools The primary purpose of dark pools is to minimise market impact. By restricting access to undesired market participants (such as high frequency trading firms), and by not revealing quotes, dark pools enable institutional investors to minimise their information leakage and realise more efficient executions. More specifically, dark trading facilities provide the possibility of price improvement and reduced transaction costs by crossing orders at the midpoint of the quoted best bid and offer prices, thereby saving on both the bid-offer spread and on exchange fees. For these reasons, dark pools have been popular for the execution of large block orders.[3]   the prevalence of dark pools At the beginning of 2013 it was estimated that non-displayed trading accounted for a third of total volume in the US and dark pools about 13 per cent of total volume. A similar volume was said to be taking place in Europe. Rapid growth had been noted of about 50 per cent over the preceding three years in the US, while in Europe, trading in dark pools relative to order-book activity had more than doubled over the preceding two years.[4]   why trading in dark pools has been growing Dark pools have become prevalent due to technological developments that have lowered costs allowing broker/dealers to route more of the order flow they handle to their own private pools first before sending unwanted orders to the public markets.[5]                    dark pools in the news In the US in April 2013, chief executives of NYSE Euronext, Nasdaq OMX and BATS Global Markets argued for regulators to introduce rules permitting transactions to only take place away from a public exchange if a customer is getting a much-improved price. They pointed to similar steps taken by Canadian and Australian regulators to combat the rise of off exchange trading, otherwise known as dark pools. In June 2014, New York's top securities regulator sued Barclays for allegedly favouring high speed traders in its "dark pool". The complaint was set to increase the pressure on other dark pool operators such as those run by Credit Suisse, Bank of America, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley to provide investors with more information about how they operate. In recent months, some dark pools had begun voluntarily publishing more information on how they work.
Information or facts about a particular subject that someone has collected.Information in a form that can be stored and used, especially on a computer. [1]

This is the process by which companies analyse the behaviour of their consumers. Media companies will analyse the trends and profiles of those consuming their content in order to tailor their products better and attract advertising revenue. ExampleRetailers also analyse consumer trends from behavioural data they will collect through loyalty cards, for instance, which can be used to design more effective offers and sales processes. [1] ViewMobilisation gathers pace
A collection of information on a particular subject that is stored somewhere, especially on a computer.A large amount of information held on a computer. [1]
The process or act of putting information, pictures etc into a computer or a computer system. [1]
A building for storing important computer equipment safely, with systems for making the air in the rooms cool, protecting against fire, and preventing the equipment from being stolen. [1]
The part of a database that controls the way the information is stored and the way different pieces of information relate to each other. [1]
A program that protects information held on a computer by putting it into special codes. [1]

A file containing information that a computer program changes into a form that can be used by the user. An example of a data file is a help file that provides the user with information on using their computer. [1]
A computer file in which information has been taken from a file in one program and is held in such a way that it can be moved to a file in a different program. [1]

Data mining involved analysing large amounts of data held on computers. Typically this data will have been collected for another reason and mining the data means that additional uses can be extracted from the database. Data mining has been used on social networks to gather information about potential customer preferences, for example.    data mining in the news In May 2012, the only so-called Twitter hedge fund shut down after deciding to offer its social media indicators to day traders instead. The hedge fund had been analysing tweets from thousands of Twitter users for mood statements. The moves in sentiment tended to predate a move in the markets by about three days. In October 2013, Twitter announced it was planning to mine data on its own platform to help sell advertising on other mobile apps or websites.

Data privacy, or information privacy, concerns the collection, protection and dissemination of personal or private information about individuals or organisations. While legal standards protecting data privacy vary greatly around the world there are some accepted norms, such as the right to cast a vote in a national election without being identified. Many developed nations have adopted specific legislation that relates to privacy in certain parts of public life, such as a person's healthcare records. The increasing scope of the internet has raised many new data privacy issues.   data privacy in the news Data privacy became big news In May 2013 when a former employee of the US Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) and former contractor for the National Security Agency, Edward Snowden, leaked thousands of classified documents to several media outlets. In May 2014, Google lost a landmark case over the limits of data privacy in Europe, leaving it obliged to remove personal information appearing on its search engines under certain circumstances. Essentially the ruling meant that individuals could request the erasure of information about them displayed on Google search engines. The case was brought by a Costeja Gonzalez, a Spanish national, who asked Google to delete links relating to a time when his house was being auctioned because he failed to pay taxes. Google had argued that it was not responsible for information published legally elsewhere.
The use of computers to store and organize data. [1]

Official rules or laws relating to information about a person stored on computer. These laws and rules say how the information can be obtained, how long it can be kept, whether other people or organizations are allowed to see it, and whether the person involved must be allowed to see it. [1]
A place where business information is stored electronically. [1]

Data-driven marketing refers to the marketing insights and decisions that arise from the analysis of data about or from consumers.  The data may be secondary, for example, tracking online social interactions, web browsing behaviour, online search behaviour, or primary such as data collected directly by surveying consumers.With the advent of online consumer panels and resources such as Amazon Mechanical Turk and online survey design tools, such as SurveyMonkey and Qualtrics, companies are able to collect input from hundreds or thousands of consumers within hours and with a very limited budget.ExampleOne popular tool for measuring consumer preferences for specific features of products or services is conjoint analysis.  This is a questionnaire asking consumers to react to various hypothetical products or services defined as  bundles  of attributes.Statistical regression analysis then provides numerical estimates of the value placed by each respondent on each of these attributes. These estimates may be used to forecast market shares for various hypothetical products, to compute the premium that may be charged for various features, and to design products and services that will maximize the company s profit.A rigorous conjoint analysis survey with a representative and significant sample of consumers may now be administered and analyzed in a very limited time, for example in less than a few days and with a very limited budget such as less than a few hundred US dollars. [1]
A large amount of information on a particular subject that is stored on a computer in an organized way so that you can find and use it easily. [1]
The way an organization manages the information held on its computers. [1]
A computer program which organizes the information on a database and allows you to find and use it easily. [1]
Software that allows you to keep a large amount of information and to search easily for the information you want. [1]

The date on which an investor must be holding stock in order to be entitled to that particular company's dividend. If an investor buys the stock after a dividend is declared but before the date of record, the stock is described as being cum dividend; if the stock is bought after the record date, it is ex-dividend.
A security that will be repaid on a fixed date, unless it is called (unless the borrower repays it early). Almost all securities are dated. [1]
When a supplier allows a customer a longer period of credit than they usually give. [1]
A company that is completely or partly owned by another company. [1]

When brokers are instructed by an investor to buy a large amount of shares in a particular company, often at the opening of trade and usually in order to position the investor for a potential takeover bid.  [1] When an acquisitive company buys a substantial number of shares in a target company before the market opens, giving it a strategic stake. [2]
An account book in which goods and services bought on credit and sales are recorded. [1]

Also called morning loan. Bank loan to a broker to finance a stock purchase. This kind of loan would normally be provided in  the morning, before the afternoon settlement. Once the stock has been delivered, it becomes collateral for the loan, which is thereafter treated in the same way as a regular broker loan.
In securities trade, a buy or sell order that expires by the end of the day if not executed or cancelled.
A chart used to help someone plan their activities on a particular day. [1]
The amount paid for someone to do a day's work. [1]
An arrangement in which a worker is allowed time away from work to go to college. [1]
Individual investor who buys and sells the same stock on a single day in order to make a quick profit.
When people buy and sell shares quickly using the Internet, which allows them to take advantage of small price changes. [1]
Someone who uses a computer to trade shares on the Internet, often buying and selling very quickly to take advantage of small price changes. [1]
Really existing, even if there is no formal legal document etc to prove it. [1]
In the US, a corporation that has not been properly formed according to law, but is allowed to exist as if it has been. [1]
Recognized and supported by law. [1]
To give property that has been requisitioned back to its owner. [1]
If the economy or an industry is dead, it is not growing or successful.No longer important, being used, or popular. [1]

Financial market jargon for when the market recovers sharply from a steep fall but the rebound is due more to technical factors, like short-covering, than fundamentals (a dead cat will "bounce" if dropped from a high place). Later the market resumes its downward trend. The derivation of the term is said by some to have come from aFinancial Times story in 1985 in which a broker interviewed about a modest recovery in the Singapore and Kuala Lumpur stock markets described the rise as "dead cat bounce". A similar slang expression is said to exist in some Chinese dialects and could be the origin of the term.   dead cat bounce in the news In December 2012 a Financial Times columnist looked back at his commentary on market events over the preceding year. He said he had been right to identify May's short-lived rally, inspired by the European Central Bank's long-term loan facility as a dead cat bounce.
The time of year when demand for (the number of people wanting) goods, travel etc is at its lowest. [1]
A stock of something that is not selling very well or at all, and which is not profitable to keep. [1]
Time that is not being used. [1]
Someone who does not pay their debts. [1]
A date or time by which you have to do or to complete something. [1]
Deadweight tons or tonnes are a measure of a ship's weight when it is empty. [1]
The weight of goods and fuel that a ship is able to carry when it is floating in water that goes up to a line marked on its side. [1]
Heavy goods such as coal and stone. The cost of carrying deadweight cargo is calculated according to its weight, not according to the amount of space it fills. [1]

The extent to which the direct impact of an increase or reduction in tax (or subsidies) is lessened by its indirect effect. For instance, a corporate tax hike will boost government revenue but may also cause companies to go broke, which would have a negative impact on government finances.
Another name for deadweight (carrying) capacity. [1]
An agreement or arrangement, especially one that involves the sale of something.An offer of a product at a lower price than usual, available only for a limited time. [1]
US jargon for a stock that is sought by speculators because of rumours of an impending deal.

Unlike brokers, who are intermediaries in a transaction, dealers trade securities, commodities or foreign exchange on their own account. In a commercial context, a dealer re-sells a product to a consumer rather than act as an agent for a sale from one party to another.
Things given to a shop by a manufacturer or importer to help show or advertise their product, for example product magazines, models, shelves and price lists. [1]
A market where transactions are effected by dealers rather than brokers.
A product sold in a supermarket or other large shop with a label that shows the name of the shop selling it. Dealer's brands are usually cheaper than other products of the same type. [1]
A business that sells products, especially cars, made by a particular company. [1]
The job or activity of buying and selling stocks, shares, foreign currencies etc on a financial market. Dealings: the business relationships or activities that you have become involved in.[1]
See trading floor.
A service offered by a firm of stockbrokers in which they make deals for their customers but do not offer advice. [1]
Someone who is skilled at arranging business deals. [1]
Costing a lot of money. If money is dear, interest rates are high and it may be difficult and expensive to get loans from banks.[1]
Money that costs a lot to borrow because interest rates are high. [1]
A policy in which a government reduces the amount of money being spent in an economy by raising interest rates, making it more expensive to borrow money. [1]
A lack of something. [1]
A single sum of money paid by an insurance company to the relatives of someone who has died. [1]
In Britain, taxes that must be paid by someone who is left property or money by someone who has died. [1]
Life insurance policies owned by people who are very ill and expected to die soon, and which are bought cheaply by investors as short-term investments. [1]
An amount of money that used to be paid in Britain to the relatives of someone who has just died to help pay the cost of their funeral. [1]
See mortality rate.

Some of an entity's overhead costs are either fixed (in that they remain the same irrespective of the volume of production or service-providing activity) or are semi-variable (in that a portion of the cost is fixed).  Eliminating a product or service can increase the overhead rate used to cost products or services because these fixed or semi-variable costs (the numerator in the overhead rate) remain the same or decrease more slowly than the cost allocation base (the denominator), which is often related to the expected number of products or services offered. The higher overhead rate increases the overhead costed to remaining products or services. If any products or services are subsequently eliminated, the burden rate may increase again.  In theory, the product eliminations and the subsequent increases in the overhead rates could continue until all products become too expensive and are therefore eliminated, resulting in no products left to sell. Example Suppose an airline cancelled a route out of an airport.  The remaining fixed and semi-variable costs associated with maintaining gates at the airport would be allocated to the routes still offered.  If any of those routes became too expensive, they are cancelled, and the remaining fixed and semi-variable costs are re-allocated to the remaining routes at the airport, in theory until a point where the airline no longer offers flights at that airport. [1]
Another name for estate tax. [1]
Written abbreviation for debenture. [1]
A reduction in the value of gold and silver coins, which happened in the past when the coins were dishonestly reduced in weight, resulting in increases in prices. [1]
A person or organization that has lent money to a company in the form of debentures. [1]
Interest payable or paid to lenders on debentures (a type of bond). [1]
A type of stock that pays interest rather than dividends. [1]
A trust made by a company, that holds the company's assets that are security for debenture stock (borrowed capital). [1]
Unsecured bonds backed only by the reputation of the issuer (normally a large, well-known company).
A withdrawal of funds from an account, a negative accounting entry. A balance not in the account-holder's favour is a debit balance. The opposite of credit.
An account with a store or business which allows a buyer to pay for goods or services with money that is already in their account or to pay later, within an agreed time. [1]
A balance showing that more money has been paid out or is owed by a company than has been received or is owed to the company. [1]

A plastic card issued by a bank that allows a customer to immediately withdraw funds from his account, either to make a purchase or to get cash. As opposed to a credit card, a debit card balance is normally settled immediately, though some companies allow a certain time limit.
A written record showing that a customer owes money, for example because the invoice (document showing the price to be paid) was not correct. [1]
A written record showing that a customer owes money, for example because the invoice was not correct. [1]
The difference in value when an option that has been bought is worth more than one that has been sold. The opposite of credit spread.

An amount owed, in money or in kind, by a borrower to a lender. A debt agreement can take many forms, but it normally states a principal amount, an interest component, and a defined term. A borrower can raise money by issuing financial instruments such as bonds, which may or may not be secured. There are active secondary markets in corporate and government bonds and other debt instruments.
When someone in financial difficulty makes new arrangements on when and how they will pay people that they owe money to. [1]
Debt or interest that was not paid when it should have been and is still owed. [1]
When a major financial institution defaults on its debt, causing a negative impact on the whole financial system of a country.
The amount of debt that a business or country has. [1]

Worldwide debt cap rules apply to certain companies and where applicable they can restrict the company s deduction for interest expense. In very broad terms, the tax deduction for the finance expense payable by UK members of a group of companies is restricted to the consolidated gross finance expense of the group. [1]
The possibility that a person or company has for borrowing more, depending on how much has already been borrowed and their ability to repay the debts. [1]
Capital raised by issuingbondsmaking them available for people to buy. [1]

The maximum amount of debt that a person or entity is permitted to run up.   The US debt ceiling explained The US debt ceiling.  The ceiling was originally established during the first world war to allow the US government to raise money without getting approval for each borrowing. Brinkmanship over lifting the debt ceiling brought the US to the edge of sovereign default in 2011, prompting an unprecedented ratings downgrade on the US's debt by Standard & Poor's. By the beginning of 2013 the debt ceiling was again overshadowing US affairs as the the US neared its statutory debt limit. Republicans were looking to extract cost cuts as payback for the tax raises agreed in the US fiscal cliff deal reached on January 1 2013 and were intending to use the requirement for congressional approval to lift the country's borrowing limit as leverage to force the cuts through.   The US debt ceiling in the news Backlash pushes Republicans to seek cuts US debt ceiling   brinkmanship resumes
The activity of making individuals and businesses pay debts, usually ones that they have not paid on time or that they are refusing to pay. [1]
A loan used to pay back a number of existing loans, so that payments are only made to one lender instead of to several. [1]
See debt counsellor.
Someone who helps and advises people who are having trouble paying their debts. [1]
When a company's or country's financial situation is at risk because it is owed a lot of money that may not be repaid. [1]
See factoring.
See factoring.
Borrowing by companies or governments in the form of loans on which interest is paid, for example bonds. [1]

In the context of sovereign debt, when a creditor exchanges its loan to a country for an investment in one of that country's companies. In the context of corporate debt, when a creditor exchanges a loan to a company for a stake in that company's capital. This could be part of a debt restructuring.
The cancelling by a creditor of a debt to a country or a company.
An instrument such as a bond, by which a promise is made to repay borrowed money to the investor. [1]
Another name for leverage. [1]
The amount of debt that a business or country has. [1]
Actions taken to control, reduce, or repay momey that you owe. [1]
When a business or government has so much debt that it is unable to make new investments. [1]
A repayment of a loan, bond etc. [1]
See credit rating
A company's total liabilities divided by its shareholders' equity. Not the same as debt/equity ratio.
See debt collectionSee debt factoring
Raising new funds to repay existing debt.
When poor countries no longer have to pay back loans or interest on loans from foreign governments and banks. [1]
An agreed delay in the repayment of a debt, usually applying to both interest and principal payments, and also often involving a renegotiation of the terms.
A reorganisation of a company's outstanding debt, for instance by converting some of the debt into equity. View Audio guide to restructuring debt
A more technical term for debt repayment.

The amount of a country's interest payments on its foreign debt as a percentage of its exports. [1]  For corporate debt, debt service payments expressed as a percentage of cash flow. In the case of sovereign debt, service payments as a percentage of the country's export earnings.
When a company, government, or person makes regular payments on a debt, or the payments they make. [1]  The payment of interest on outstanding debt plus any principal repayments due.
When a company gives shares to lenders in exchange for loans they have made. [1]
The amount of a company's debt in relation to the amount of share capital it has. [1]
See debt swap.
Having a lot of debt. [1]
Owing a lot of money and having difficulty in paying it. [1]
See budget balance

A company's long-term debt divided by its shareholders' equity. It shows the relationship between funds provided by creditors and funds provided by shareholders, and is an indication of leverage or gearing - the use of debt to increase returns. Not the same as debt ratio.
A person or organisation that owes money. The same as a borrower or an issue (if the debt is in the form of issued paper). The opposite of creditor.
In a Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganisation, when a debtor is allowed to retain control of the business as a trustee.
When a debtor company is allowed to keep possession of its assets while it is given financial help to organize a way to pay its debt. [1]

The first public appearance of a product or service, or the first time that it is available to buy. An occasion when a company issues (makes available and sells) shares, bonds etc for the first time.[1]

Unicorns are companies that quickly achieve a billion-dollar valuation, the term was coined by Cowboy Ventures founder Aileen Lee in 2013. A decacorn is a company that achieves a $10bn valuation.   decacorns in the news Now even unicorns are too common, so a new quest has begun to find companies capable of hitting a $10bn valuation and a new term, decacorn, has entered the small talk at tech industry gatherings in San Francisco and London. In doing so the start-up community has moved beyond the realms of fantasy to spawn a creature that cannot even be found on a Dungeons & Dragons board. [1]

The reduction or removal of carbon dioxide from energy sources. For example: The European Union s leading power companies have set themselves the goal of making their electricity carbon free by 2050, which is, in theory, an achievable objective. A mix of renewables   such as wind and solar power, nuclear power stations and coal- and gas-fired plants that capture carbon dioxide emissions   could provide all the electricity we need with very little output of greenhouse gases. [1]
Behaviour that is intended to make someone believe something that is not true. [1]
To make someone believe something that is not true in order to get what you want. [1]
The placing of a large amount of responsibility with officials situated away from the centre of a large corporate organisation or government entity.
If a large company, organization, or industry decentralizes or is decentralized, responsibility, services, or jobs are moved away from a central place to several different smaller places. [1]
Another word for deceit. [1]
Used in the metric system to mean 'one tenth'. For example, a decimetre is equal to one tenth of a metre. [1]
In a set of variables arranged in order of value, any variable that is equal to one tenth of the amount of the highest one. [1]
A currency whose main unit is divided into a hundred smaller units, for example dollars and cents. [1]

The term decision analysis was coined in 1964 by Ronald A. Howard, professor of management science and engineering at Stanford University. Decision analysis refers to a systematic, quantitative and interactive approach to addressing and evaluating important choices confronted by organisations in the private and public sector. Decision analysis is interdisciplinary and draws on theories from the fields of psychology, economics, and management science. It utilises a variety of tools which include models for decision-making under conditions of uncertainty or multiple objectives; techniques of risk analysis and risk assessment; experimental and descriptive studies of decision-making behaviour; economic analysis of competitive and strategic decisions; techniques for facilitating decision-making by groups; and computer modeling software and expert systems for decision support.   an example of decision analysis in use Decision analysis (DA) has been applied to business problems in management, marketing, operations, accounting, and finance. In addition, it has had an impact on the fields of medicine, law, military science, environmental sciences, and public policy more generally. In 2010, Chevron won the Decision Analysis Society Practice Award for its use of DA in determining whether or not to invest in Gorgon, a multi-billion dollar capital investment project in Australia, involving one of the largest natural gas developments in the world.[1]   decision analysis in the news In a 2004 piece focused on enterprise risk management a professor of decision sciences at Insead explained that decision analysis is one of the techniques used in risk modelling.
A computer system that examines information about a business activity or situation and gives the people who manage a company the information they need to make important decisions. [1]
A mathematical drawing that shows all the courses of action that are available from a particular situation. Decision trees are used in planning. [1]
Someone with a high rank in a company or government who has the authority to make important decisions. [1]
A group of people in a company or other organization involved in making an important decision, especially a decision about buying something. [1]
Someone who makes a declaration. [1]

A statement in which you officially give information, for example about your income or about goods you are importing, which is used to calculate how much tax you will pay.A statement in which you officially give information about yourself.

The date on which a company declares its dividend (announces how much will be paid, in what form, and when). There is normally a brief period between the declaration date and the date of record during which investors can buy a company's shares and still qualify to receive the dividend. After the date of record, the shares go ex-dividend.
On a financial market, the last day on which someone who holds an option may decide whether or not they accept it. [1]

Insurance against loss or damage to goods, where the insured person informs the insurer of the value of these goods every month, and the cost of insuring them is based on their average value during the year. [1]

In Britain, a document in which seven or more people ask to be formed into a company and list the number of shares each one of them will take. The declaration of association is the last part of the memorandum of association. [1]

In Britain, a document stating that all the necessary official actions have been taken to set up a new limited company. The declaration of compliance is signed by a lawyer, director, or secretary and sent to the Registrar of Companies. [1]
An official document stating what a person or group intends to do, but which does not have the legal force of a formal contract. [1]
A statement giving details of the amount of money you earn or have, used especially to calculate how much money you can receive from the state. [1]
A statement in which a trustee officially says that property is held for someone. [1]
To make something known officially to the public. [1]
The value of goods on which duty must be paid when passing through Customs. [1]
If an industry or country declines, it becomes less profitable, productive, wealthy etc.If sales, profits, production etc decline, they become less.
A share that falls in value on a particular day of trading on a stockmarket. [1]
A method of calculating the depreciation of an asset, in which the value of the asset is reduced by the same percentage each year and the amount is charged to the profit and loss account. [1]
An industry that is gradually getting smaller and less important. [1]
Shares that fall in value on a particular day of trading on a stockmarket. [1]
Stocks that fall in value on a particular day of trading on a stockmarket. [1]
A piece of equipment that you need in order to receive certain types of television service. [1]
To destroy a factory, power station, or other industrial building that has closed down, and to remove anything from it that might be harmful or dangerous. [1]
To change the information in a computer document back into a form that can be easily read or used, from information that was stored in a form that used less space on the computer's memory. [1]

Decoupling generally refers to any process where one entity is separated from another but is often used in financial terms to refer to a divergence in performance or behaviour. In this way, asset managers spent some time, particularly in the aftermath of the financial crisis, arguing that emerging markets were decoupling from more mature markets and could expect buoyant returns even when developed markets were experiencing declines. The idea was that emerging markets would better reflect the attractive characteristics of their home countries with favourable demographics, little or no debt and fast economic growth. As time went on, however, it became clear that the fortunes of emerging markets were still strongly linked to the economic fortunes of developed countries.   decoupling in the news In August 2013 an FT columnist argued the emerging market decoupling story had always been over-hyped. He wrote that since the US Fed had started talk of tapering, cutting back its asset purchase programme, that the emerging market independent growth story had become tarnished.
An insurance agreement over a fixed period of time, in which the sum insured gets smaller each year. [1]
A judgement made in a court of law after a civil action. In certain forms of government, an order from a president, minister etc that has the force of a law.[1]
To reduce the number of people working for an organization, for example by no longer employing them or offering them early retirement. [1]
When a company or an organization dismisses employees that it no longer needs. [1]
To change a message or information that was written in computer codeback into a form that can be read and understood by everyone. [1]
Proving who is the legal owner of a property. [1]
The process of taking away an amount from a total, or the amount that is taken away. [1]
A formal written document that is a record of an agreement, especially one relating to property. [1]
In Britain, a formal agreement arranged by a court for the assets of a person or company that owes money to be sold and the money divided between the people who are owed money. [1]
A deed showing an agreement to give an asset to someone else. [1]
A formal document showing change of ownership of land, buildings etc. [1]
In Britain, a formal agreement to make regular payments to a charity so that the charity avoids paying income tax. [1]
A formal arrangement to give property to someone without payment. [1]
A formal agreement to begin a partnership. [1]
A formal agreement relating to change of ownership, or property, or shares. [1]
In the US, a change of ownership of a property to a trustee as security in case the owner of the property fails to do something such as repay a loan. [1]
A type of low-interest bond sold at a substantial discount (more than 20 per cent) to its par value.
A commercial organization or financial institution offering the lowest prices, often offering only a very basic service. [1]
Written abbreviation for deficit. [1]
When someone who has been trusted to take care of money steals it or uses it dishonestly. [1]
The act of writing or saying bad or untrue things about someone, so that people will have a bad opinion of them. [1]
The failure of a debtor to make agreed payments of principal or interest on a loan, a bond or other type of borrowing.
A legal judgment made in favour of someone because the other person involved in the case has failed to do something they should have done. [1]

The solutions that first come to mind, that are most widely used, or that result from an examination of current  best practices  are default solutions.  The use of default solutions is often the result of accepting the problem framing (how the problem is described) that has been given. Example When it is necessary to control material costs, the default solution is often to work various aspects of the economic order quantity (EOQ) calculation to better balance holding/ storage costs with the risks of stockouts (not having certain goods in stock).  EOQ is the ideal amount of goods to order at one time in a cost efficient way, considering all related costs such as delivery and storage of goods. In that context just-in-time (JIT) inventory practices (having the right goods in stock just before they are required to reduce storage costs) can be seen as an alternative to the default solution. [1]
Someone who fails to do something that it is their duty to do, especially someone who fails to pay money that they owe. [1]
A fault in something that means it is not perfect.If the buyer of one product defects to another product, they stop buying the first one and start buying the second one.
If a product is defective, it has not been made properly or it is not working properly. [1]
In Britain, a right of ownership of land which is not recorded with the land registry and so there is a risk that someone else can claim to be the owner. [1]

The things that are said in a court of law to try to prove that someone is not guilty of a crime. The defence: the lawyers in a court of law who try to prove that someone is not guilty of a crime.  Actions taken by a company to prevent a takeover that it does not want.[1]
A company that provides goods, such as aircraft, to a country's armed forces. [1]
A statement by a company which is the subject of a takeover offer giving reasons why its shareholders should not accept the offer. [1]
The industry of making electronic parts and equipment for military purposes. [1]

If a lawyer defends someone charged with a crime, he or she represents that person and argues that they are not guilty of the charge.To do something in order to stop something being taken away or to make sure that something continues. [1]
The person or organization in a court of law that has been accused of doing something illegal. [1]
The American spelling of defence. [1]
A merger where a company joins with another to avoid being taken over (bought and controlled) by a third company. [1]
One of the shares in a company that people think will still make good profits even if economic growth is low. [1]
Stocks that tend to be more stable over time than the overall market (ie they have a low beta coefficient). These are likely to be non-cyclical stocks.
The act of delaying something, or the period of the delay itself. [1]
In health insurance taken out in Britain, a period of time that the insured person agrees to let pass when they are ill before they claim money from the insurance company. [1]
An annuity where the first payment is made by the insurer at a fixed time after it is bought. [1]
Money received for goods to be supplied and for services to be performed in the future, shown as liabilities in the accounts. [1]
Money that a company borrows, for example in the form of convertible loan stock that can later be exchanged for shares. [1]
Income relating to things that will be done in the future for which payment has already been received. [1]
Income tax to be paid by a company in a later tax year on profits made in an earlier year. [1]
A bond that delays interest payments to the latter years of the agreed term. In some cases, the whole of the interest is paid in a lump sum at maturity.
Debts relating to activity in one period of time that will or may be paid in a later period of time. [1]
A loan where interest is not paid in the normal way, but where the lender obtains one big payment when the loan period ends or receives stocks, shares etc in exchange. [1]

One of a class of shares where dividends are only paid in a particular period of time after dividends have been paid on all other classes of shares one of a class of shares which do not pay dividends immediately, but pay them later, for example when the company reaches a particular level of sales. [1] Deferred in this context is usually taken to mean that the shares carry fewer rights than the ordinary shares. Shareholders may not be entitled to vote their deferred shareholdings or receive dividends in respect of them. [2]

Tax that is to be paid at a later date. In corporate accounts, the difference between the cash taxes a company has paid and the tax recognized on its income statement. ViewDelay will not remove sting of deferred tax
Taxation using deferred taxes. [1]
A decision by a court that a borrower still owes money after the security for a loan is sold for less than the amount owed.[1]
In the US, a document from the tax authorities informing someone that they owe more tax than they have paid. [1]
The excess of expenditure over income. The opposite of surplus.

Government policy to run a budget deficit and thus increase the government borrowing requirement. The aim could be to boost economic activity, for instance by cutting taxes, though increased government borrowing will also tend to push up interest rates, which may slow the economy.
When a government spends more than it receives from taxes and other income. [1]
Typically associated with a defined benefit plan, the defined benefit is the fixed regular payment promised to the individual in the plan. [1]

A retirement plan sponsored by an employer in which an employee receives a fixed recurring payment, or benefit, during retirement. The amount of that payment is determined by a formula based on salary history and years of service at the company. In such a plan, the employer assumes all the investment risk and determines investment choices and must pay the employee the defined benefit regardless of the investment performance. [1]

An employer-sponsored qualified retirement plan, a defined contribution (DC) plan allows employees to defer a portion of salary. The funds receive beneficial tax treatment and are placed into an individual account for each participant. The money is invested in mutual funds or individual stocks on behalf of the employee. With such plans, employers traditionally will match a portion of the employee s contribution or contribute an amount equal to a percentage of the employee s salary. Employees bear the investment risk and can typically guide the selection of investments within set parameters. The contributions, plus or minus any investment gains, are used to fund a portion of the individual s retirement. In the U.S., prime examples of DC plans are 401(k) plans and 403(b) plans. [1]

Pension plan that commits to paying a specified amount to each employee on retirement, depending on the years of work and salary level. The employer contributes a regular amount to the plan, normally a percentage of the employee's pay. Employee contributions are mandatory or voluntary depending on the scheme (see non-contributory pension plan). Companies may have to invest the contents of the pension fund to ensure the fund is large enough to meet retirement payments, and carry full liability for investment performance.

Pension plan for which contributions are specified (mandatory or voluntary depending on the scheme), but the amount received by the employee on retirement is not fixed. Instead, it relates to how the funds in the plan have been invested and the return on that investment. The employee normally has the responsibility of deciding how the contributions are invested (though investment choices may be limited by the actual pension fund provider). Companies like them better than defined-benefit pension plans because the pension outlay is gradual and controlled and liability for investment performance is passed onto the employee.

If a government deflates the economy, it reduces the demand for goods and services by raising interest rates and taxes, limiting wage increases, reducing government spending, or a combination of these.If the price of something deflates, it goes down. [1]

A sustained fall in the prices of goods and services, and thus the opposite of inflation. Not to be confused with disinflation, which is a slowing down of price rises (a fall in the inflation rate). Deflation may be the result of government policy (such as a move to raise interest rates and cut money supply) or can be caused by external factors, such as intense trade competition or the collapse of an asset bubble. Deflation may have short-term benefits, particularly if it is the result of greater efficiencies in the economy, but if it lasts too long, or if it is the result of weakening demand, it can be a negative, self-perpetuating influence on economic activity, discouraging consumption, reducing revenue and wage levels, pushing up bad debts and increasing the rate of bankruptcy. The combination of deflation and a sustained drop in economic output is termed an economic depression. Also see recession.   deflation in the news In April 2014 an FT writer argued that for Japan to really rise above its decade of deflation it would need to start awarding higher wages to workers. However, Japan's recovery had thus far not been visible in overall wage data. Meanwhile, in the same month, deflation was looming in the eurozone. A struggle was emerging in the Eurozone over whether the European Central Bank could counter the threat of deflation with a European version of quantitative easing   a course of action viewed with deep suspicion in Germany.
See GDP price deflator
To gain money or goods from someone by saying or doing something dishonest. [1]
Defray costs/ expenses/ charges: to pay someone's costs etc. [1]
When a company starts to get more of the money it needs by selling shares in the company, and less by borrowing in the form of loans or bonds. [1]
A tax where people with low incomes pay a smaller percentage of what they earn than those with high incomes. [1]
When a company or an organization dismisses employees it no longer needs. [1]
When there is less and less manufacturing industry in an area or country. [1]
Someone who agrees to sell goods for another person and who will pay for the goods even if they do not manage to sell them. In exchange for this they usually receive a larger amount as payment. [1]
A delay in the opening of trade in a stock, usually because of a substantial imbalance in buy and sell orders.
If an organization delayers, it reduces the number of management levels it has. [1]
Someone who has been elected or chosen to speak, vote, or take decisions for a group.To give part of your power or work to someone else, usually someone in a lower position than you.
In Britain, rules and laws which are not made by Parliament but by government ministers who have been given authority by Parliament. [1]
A group of people who officially represent a company, organization, government etc.The process of giving part of your power or work to someone else, usually someone in a lower position than you. [1]
To reduce long-term debt as a proportion of shareholders' equity.
Failure to make a payment on a debt by the due date.
Delinquent account/ debt/ payment etc: an account, debt etc that has not been paid at the right time, or has not been paid at all. [1]
Another name for a bad loan. [1]

A document representing tax that has not been paid on a property, which can be bought at a reduced price as an investment. The buyer can then pay the tax and get the money from the owner of the property or, if the owner does not pay, take over the property. [1]

The removal of a company's stock from an exchange. This can be ordered by the regulator, because of a breach of securities rules, or can be arranged by the company itself, because it is being taken private, has merged with another group, etc.
An Incoterm stating that the seller pays for the goods to be taken, usually by road or train, as far as the border of the buyer's country and is responsible for insuring them up to that point. [1]
An Incoterm stating that the seller pays for the goods to be delivered to the buyer, is responsible for insuring them for the whole journey and pays all related taxes. [1]
An Incoterm stating that the seller pays for the goods to be delivered to the buyer, is responsible for insuring them for the whole journey but does not pay related taxes. [1]
An Incoterm stating that the seller is responsible for taking the goods off the ship in a particular port, and making them available there, but not for transporting them anywhere. [1]

An Incoterm stating that the seller will make the goods available on a ship in a particular port, and the buyer is responsible for paying for the goods to be put on land and transported to where they are needed. [1]
A price that includes all charges, for example packing and transport costs, up to the place of delivery. [1]
The act or process of bringing goods, letters etc to a particular place or person.When a seller officially hands over something, for example a document relating to property or shares, to a buyer. [1]
A service provided by the post office where the person who receives a letter or package signs a document to prove to the sender that they have received it. [1]
The date (typically a particular month) on which the commodity or security underlying a futures contract must be delivered (eg: crude oil for September delivery).
An Incoterm stating that the seller pays for the goods to be delivered to the buyer, is responsible for insuring them for the whole journey but does not pay related taxes.
A document showing that goods have been delivered. [1]
A written instruction from the owner of goods to someone who is storing or keeping them to give or take them to another person. [1]

A document that has been signed by the person receiving goods to show that they have been delivered a document sent by the post office, telling someone who has sent a letter by recorded delivery that it has been delivered. [1]
An agreement in a contract between a buyer and seller about when goods will be delivered, how they will be paid for etc. [1]
The amount of time that a company takes to get goods ready for delivery, for example the time it takes to obtain them or make them. [1]
Settlement of a trade (normally institutional) when securities are delivered and cash received on the same day.
A measure of the relationship between the price of an option and the price of the underlying stock.
A hedging method that seeks to take advantage of the difference between the price of an option and the price of the underlying stock.
In Britain, shares in small companies that are not often actively traded and are not listed on SEAQ. [1]
The desire to have or own a good or service, and the amount that individuals, companies or governments are able or willing to buy.
A bank account that you can take money out of without having to warn the bank in advance. [1]
The demand for goods and services in relation to the amount available and the price. [1]

A graph of the relationship between the price of a good and the amount of demand at different prices. Normally demand falls at higher prices, but depending on the product and the market, the reaction to a change in price can be more or less significant.

A graph of the relationship between the price of a good and the amount of demand at different prices. Normally demand falls at higher prices, but depending on the product and the market, the reaction to a change in price can be more or less significant.
Another name for a call deposit. [1]  The balances of bank accounts from which one can draw money without prior notice. A major component in the measurement of a country's money supply.
When an economy is growing, and prices rise because the amount of goods and services being produced does not keep up with the amount of money available to buy them or the demand for them. [1]
Loan that can be called by the lender for repayment at any time.
A written request for payment, for example of taxes a loan which the lender can ask to be repaid at any time. [1]
The price which buyers of a particular product will pay when a particular amount of it is made available for sale. [1]
When the driving force behind rising prices is stronger demand by consumers, rather than the increased cost of producing goods.
Demand-side ideas emphasize managing the economy through changes in interest rates and taxes in order to influence demand and so keep unemployment low. [1]
When different jobs are given to workers belonging to different trade unions. [1]
A disagreement between different trade unions about which workers should do which jobs. [1]
When actions are taken to reduce the amount of demand for a product, for example because it is dangerous. [1]
In trading shares, bonds etc, to change from a system based on certificates (official documents showing ownership) to paperless trading (where records of ownership are kept on computer). [1]
In trading shares, bonds etc, to change from a system based on certificates (official documents showing ownership) to paperless trading (where records of ownership are kept on computer). [1]
See dematerialise
To make one part of a large company into a separate company. [1]
The hiving off of one or more business units from a group so that they can operate as independently managed concerns.
When a property owner rents property to someone, or the rented property itself.If the owner of a property demises it, they rent it to someone. [1]
A computer program that shows customers what a new piece of software will be able to do when it is ready to be sold, to encourage them to buy the complete form of the software. [1]
A system of government in which members of the government are elected by the people of a country.A country that has a government which has been elected by the people of the country.
Someone who believes in, or works to achieve, democracy. Democrat: a member or supporter of the Democratic party in the US.[1]
Controlled by representatives who are elected by the people of a country.Organized according to the principle that everyone has a right to be involved in making decisions. [1]
Information about the population of a particular place, how much they earn, spend etc. [1]
The impact of population trends on the economy or a company's business.
The study of human populations and the way in which they change.The type of people that make up a particular population. [1]
The withdrawal of a coin, note or form of currency from circulation.
An act of explaining and showing how a product works or how something is done. [1]
The idea that people expect or want to buy or have things because they see that other people are able to have them. [1]
A computer program that shows customers what a new piece of software will be able to do when it is available and they can buy it. [1]
A legacy that comes from a particular amount of money or group of things that has been left. [1]
To give someone a job with a lower rank or position than they had before. [1]
To make people less willing to do their job. [1]

When a ship is kept by someone who has chartered it for longer than the time agreed or allowed. Money which someone who has chartered a ship pays to its owner if the ship does not sail at the agreed time.[1]

When an organisation that is mutually owned (profits and ownership are divided among members depending on the business they do with the company) abandons that structure, normally in order to be able to list the company on the stock exchange.
Putting a government-owned entity into private hands.
To officially measure or set the value of something such as a bond or a currency according to the value of a particular currency. [1]
Officially measured or set according to the value of a particular currency.  [1]
The currency in which a security is issued or traded.

One of the parts of a large organization such as a company or university where people do a particular kind of work. One of the parts that a government is divided into, which has a particular area of responsibility.  A part of a large shop that sells a particular type of product.  One of the areas that some countries, for example France, are divided into. [1]
A large shop that is divided into separate departments, each selling a different type of goods. [1]
An act of leaving a place, especially at the start of a journey.An act of leaving an organization or position.
Someone, for example a child, who depends on you for money, food, clothes etc. [1]
Needing another person to provide money, food, clothes etc. [1]
To greatly reduce the amount of something, using up nearly all of it. [1]
The accounting term used for the depreciation of assets such as gas reserves and mines, whose loss of value is linked to the potential use of resources.
Someone who makes a statement in a court of law which they promise is true. A deponent can appear in court as a witness or make a written statement which is presented in court as evidence. [1]

Money placed in an account at a bank or other financial institution.   See demand deposits; time deposit. Or an advance on a payment as assurance that a purchase contract will be honoured. Or a sum placed as security for the payment of regular charges such as utilities bill, rental fees, etc. Or any material in the ground that has been laid down by natural means, such as by rivers, seas and winds (eg: mineral deposits).
A bank account that pays interest, often used for saving money not needed immediately. [1]
Someone whose job is to arrange for money to be paid by one bank into accounts at other banks. [1]
Another name for certificate of deposit. [1]

In many countries, depositors are automatically insured against the risk that their bank will fail to meet payments. Schemes vary however as to the protection limits and how much the banks themselves contribute to the insurance fund, which is normally government-run. In the US, the organisation that guarantees deposits is the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC).
Money that people and companies have put into banks, and that the banks will have to pay back at some time in the future. [1]
Money that a buyer gives to a seller as a first payment to prove that they intend to complete a deal. [1]
In Britain, an amount of money that is paid into a central organization by banks and will be paid to people who lose money if a bank goes bankrupt. [1]
A document showing an amount of money that has been put into a bank account. [1]
Another name for a deposit receipt. [1]
A deposit-taking financial institution is one into which people can pay money so that it can be held there and earn interest. [1]
Another spelling of depository. [1]
See depository receipt
A formal statement that someone makes to a court about facts relating to a court case. [1]
A person or organization that puts money into a bank account so that it can be held there and earn interest. [1]

An organization where the formal documents showing who owns shares, bonds, etc can be kept safely. A place where goods can be kept safely.  Statements and evidence prepared for use in a court case.[1]
A bank or other financial institution into which people can pay money so that it can be held there and earn interest. [1]
A negotiable certificate issued by a bank, trust company or depository institution that represents a certain number of ordinary shares and is backed by physical stock held in the issuer's vault.
A negotiable certificate issued by a bank, trust company or depository institution that represents a certain number of ordinary shares and is backed by physical stock held in the issuer's vault.
A place where large quantities of goods, equipment, or materials are stored until they are needed.A place where buses or trains are kept until they are needed, and often repaired and maintained.
The number of years over which the cost of something that goes down in value, especially a fixed asset, can be claimed against tax. [1]

To decrease in value over a period of time. If a currency depreciates, it goes down in value compared to the currencies of other countries.  To reduce the value of a fixed asset over the particular period of time allowed under tax law.[1]
The original cost of a fixed asset less the total amount that has been claimed against tax for depreciation. [1]

A fall in the market value of an asset, or of one currency with respect to another. The opposite of appreciation. Also the writing down of the value of an asset in a company's books to reflect its loss of value through age and use.

A business account in which the amount of depreciation on a fixed asset is entered in the debit side and then also added to the account as a credit, allowing the asset's value to be reduced by the correct amount each year. [1]
An amount that can be taken off a business's profit figure when calculating tax, to allow for the fact that an asset has lost part of its value during a particular period of time. [1]

A fund set up by a company to provide money to buy new fixed assets. Every year, the fund invests an amount of money equal to an existing asset's depreciation allowance in gilt-edged securities, giving the company money that can be used to buy new assets. [1]
One of several methods used to calculate the cost of an asset over its expected life. The cost appears in the depreciation account and is used to calculate the depreciation allowance. [1]
The rate at which an asset is calculated to go down in value each year, especially in the annual accounts of a business. [1]
To prevent an economy, industry, market etc from working properly or being as active as it usually is.To reduce the value of something such as prices or wages. [1]
An economy or industry that is depressed does not have enough manufacturing or business activity.If the price of something is depressed, it is lower than normal. [1]
An area in a large city or a part of a country where houses and other buildings are in a bad condition, the level of unemployment is high, and a lot of people are poor. [1]
A prolonged severe drop in economic output accompanied by sustained deflation.

The amount a business would lose if an asset was lost or damaged etc. This amount represents what it would cost to replace the asset or the amount a business would have received from the asset's sale. [1]
An interview to find out what products someone buys and why. It may be done in several separate meetings over a long period of time. [1]
The extent to which units of a stock can be bought or sold without causing a sharp price movement. A stock in which there is a deep market is normally highly liquid.
Someone in an organization who is immediately below the rank of another important person, and who is officially in charge when that other person is not there. [1]
Someone who is directly below a chairman in rank. [1]
To remove or reduce the number of government controls on a particular business activity, done to make companies work more effectively and to increase competition. [1]
Substantial easing of government restrictions in a particular industry, normally in order to boost competition.

If a company derisks, it increases the range of goods or services it produces or increases the number of countries in which it does business in order to reduce the risk that something bad might happen. [1]
An arrangement in which a person renting a property with a lease arranges another lease on the same property, allowing another person to rent the property from them. [1]

A financial product such as a future or option rather than the actual shares, currencies etc that they relate to. Options give the buyer the right to buy shares etc at a fixed price within a particular period of time, and futures allow the buyer to buy a fixed amount of a currency, farm product etc at a fixed price for delivery later. [1]

A financial instrument whose value is based on the performance of underlying assets such as stocks, bonds currency exchange rates, real estate. The main categories of derivatives are futures, options and swaps. [1] Derivatives are financial instruments whose value is derived from the value of an underlying asset (such as gold, wheat or other commodities) or other financial instruments including bonds, or market benchmarks such as interest rates. [2]ExampleThe value of the derivative is set out in a derivative contract, which can either be traded on an exchange, in what is called exchange-traded contracts, or traded off-exchange, in the over-the-counter market. [3] Those traded on exchanges, such as interest rate futures, allow traders to speculate on the future direction of interest rates, and those privately negotiated between two parties are known as over-the-counter (OTC) derivatives. [4]
Demand for a type of goods or services that depends on demand for another type of goods or services. [1]
A type of crane, used especially for loading and unloading ships. A tall tower built over an oil well, used to raise and lower the drill.[1]
When salt is removed from sea water so that the water can be used in homes and factories, and on farm crops. [1]
When useful land, especially farm land, becomes dry and gradually turns into a desert. [1]

The design attitude contrasts with or compliments a decision attitude. The decision attitude operates from the assumption that, in managing, the difficult task to be performed is to select among alternatives. A design attitude assumes, instead, that the real challenge is often to generate better alternatives. In an analysis of designers, Kamil Michlewski identified the qualities associated with a design attitude. They included empathy, a willingness to embrace ambiguity, the desire to engage and use one s senses to learn, explore and express oneself, an appreciation for the way that complex things have qualities that go beyond their parts, and an interest in actually making things. His results were published in the 2008 Organizations Studies article Uncovering Design Attitude: Inside the Culture of Designers. Example The shift from a decision to a design attitude can be seen in the treatment of the classic inventory control problem. This is the process of ensuring that the amount of raw materials and finished products are being managed efficiently to meet demand. To solve the inventory problem, the decision-oriented approach would create buffers so that at any given point there would be a surplus of supply to meet the most likely levels of demand. For thirty years, research and teaching extended and refined this model. As a consequence, we were blinded for decades to the possibility that inventories (unsold goods and raw materials) could be minimised by other means, such as rethinking the design of the production system, such as using just-in-time (JIT) inventories (having the right goods in stock just before they are required to reduce storage costs). [1]
A set of instructions about what a new product should look like or what features it should have. [1]

At the beginning of the 20th century design was principally about communication (graphic design) and artifacts (industrial design). As the century drew to a close, more and more designers were working on the design of interactions, often, but not always, involving computers and other systems. Recently design skills have been applied to solving problems at the level of organisations and society. In response to the need for a new term to describe these broader applications of design some have used the phrase  design thinking . It is meant to suggest that while many of the skills that designers have developed are relevant, the problems are not within their exclusive area as traditionally defined. Some people have issues with the phrase in that it de-emphasises the important making aspect of design, reducing it to a cognitive process. Among other things, design thinking calls for reframing problems (how the problem is described) to find solutions that others have overlooked. Example In the 1950s, most people who were trying to speed up oceanic shipping were focused on the time it took to move cargo across the ocean. By improving the ship s engines or the shape of its hull they were sometimes able to take hours or days off for each crossing. Malcolm McLean, owner of a trucking company, recast the problem to focus on the time it took to move cargo on and off ships. His innovation, container shipping, eventually reduced cargo s total time in transit by weeks rather than hours or days. [1]

To choose someone or something for a particular job or purpose.A word used after the name of an official job showing that someone has been chosen for that job but has not yet officially started work. [1]
Someone who represents someone or does a job in their place. [1]
The act of choosing someone or something for a particular purpose, or of giving them a particular description.A name or title. [1]
Designer clothes are fashionable and expensive and have been designed by a well-known fashion designer.Someone whose job is to design products, equipment, furniture, clothes etc. [1]
A company that makes fashionable expensive clothes with its own well-known name on them. [1]

Someone who does all their work at a desk in an office. [1]

Having no money, no food, and nowhere to live. [1]

A warrant sold as part of the issue of another security, but which can be traded separately on the secondary market.
A house or garage that is detached is not joined to another building on any side. [1]

Official lowering by monetary authorities of the value of a country's currency in relationship to the currencies of one or more other countries. For this to occur, the currency being devalued would have to have a fixed exchange rate against another currency or a basket of currencies. Devaluation should not be confused with depreciation, which is a fall in the market value of a currency without formal adjustment of its exchange rate.
To cause something to lose its value.When a country devalues its currency against other currencies, it decreases its value for economic reasons, for example to make its exports cheaper.
Developed countries are generally considered to be the more industrialised nations, with higher income levels and collectively referred to as the North because most are in the northern hemisphere.
Land that houses etc have been built on or land used for industrial purposes. [1]
A person or company that works on the planning and design of new products.A person or company whose business is buying land and building on it. [1]
Developing countries, generally those lacking a high degree of industrialisation, are collectively referred to as the South.

The growth or improvement of something, so that it becomes bigger or more advanced. The process of planning and making new products or providing new services.  The process of planning and building new houses, offices etc, or improving existing ones.  The process of creating a plan, policy, or idea.  The using of a natural substance or product in order to make a profit.  A new event or piece of news that will have an effect on the present situation.[1]
Financial help given by richer countries to poorer ones to help their industrial and economic development. [1]
A relatively poor area that the government tries to make richer by attracting industry, for example by offering money, lower taxes etc to businesses that move there. [1]
A bank that gives loans to help increase business, trade, and industrial activity in a particular country or area. [1]

Using dishonest tricks and deceiving people to get what you want. [1]
To give land or buildings to someone after you die by writing it in a will. [1]
When a national government or a large organization gives some or all of its power to a smaller group or an organization at a more local level. [1]
To give work, responsibility, or power to someone at a lower or more local level.If land, goods etc devolve to someone they become the property of that person when their owner dies. [1]

The Scotland Act 2012 provides for a Scottish rate of income tax to be set by the Scottish Parliament, from April 2016. It also fully devolves the power to raise tax on land transactions (the Land and buildings transactions tax) as well as waste disposal to landfill (Scottish Landfill Tax), with powers for additional taxes to be devolved and new taxes to be created in Scotland. Certain taxes are also to be devolved to Northern Ireland and Wales as part of the ongoing devolution debate. [1]
Diagnostic software tests how effectively a computer or computer system is operating, looks for problems with the computer's processes, and shows you the results of the tests and checks it does. [1]
A drawing or plan that shows where something is, what it looks like, or how it works. [1]
Showing in a drawing or plan exactly where something is, what it looks like, or how it works. [1]

A box that appears on your computer screen when particular programs are running, which asks you a question before it continues to do something. You clickon one part of the box to give your answer. [1]
To say words for someone else to write down.An order, rule, or principle that you have to obey. [1]
To get money from someone by deceiving them. [1]
The amount of difference that there is between two things.Based on or depending on a difference between two things. [1]
A system of pay that is supposed to show the relative importance of two jobs by paying different amounts for each job. [1]

When a company differentiates its products, it shows how they are different from each other and from competing products, for example in its advertising. This is done to show buyers the advantages of one product over another. [1]
The process of showing or seeing that one thing is different from something else. [1]
People who understand computers well and who are confident about their skill in using them. [1]
Digital electronic equipment receives sound and pictures from binary electrical signals (signals using the numbers 0 and 1). Relating to a business activity that uses the Internet.[1]
The difference between the people that own computers and know how to use the Internet and those that do not. [1]

The switchover from analogue to digital terrestrial television (DTT), expected to be completed in Europe by the end of 2012, will free up a large amount of radiofrequency spectrum. For the same number of broadcast television programs, only a fraction   about one quarter to one tenth depending on the level of compression and standard   of the spectrum is required by DTT. This is known as the  Digital Dividend : for the same number of television channels, less spectrum is needed and the respective frequencies can be made available for other uses, such as mobile telephony. This spectrum offers a unique opportunity to meet new demands for services and to support the European agenda for innovation. Most importantly, it could have a significant impact on the EU economy, driving innovation, job growth, productivity and competitiveness. What is key is how the  Digital Dividend  will be allocated. Governments should resist the temptation to please broadcasters and let them have this dividend for nothing. Instead they should let the market decide, possibly via auction mechanism. It is likely that it will end up in the hands of operators supplying new wireless communications services. This would be far more beneficial for the EU economy because the contribution to productivity and GDP from investment in telecoms and especially mobile is much greater than anything else, as confirmed by a range of economic modelling studies. Example Italy completed the latest round of spectrum auctions in September 2011, which included the sale of licences in the 800-MHz  digital dividend  frequencies. The auction brought in some EUR 4 billion (USD 5.4 billion), paid by cellular operators who will use these frequencies, previously allocated to analogue TV, to deploy the new generation of high-speed mobile communications (4G). [1]

The marketing of products or services using digital channels to reach consumers. The key objective is to promote brands through various forms of digital media. Digital marketing extends beyond internet marketing to include channels that do not require the use of the internet. It includes mobile phones (both SMS and MMS), social media marketing, display advertising, search engine marketing, and any other form of digital media. Most experts believe that 'digital' is not just yet another channel for marketing. It requires a new approach to marketing and a new understanding of customer behaviour. For example, it requires companies to analyse and quantify the value of downloads of apps on mobile devices, tweets on Twitter, likes on Facebook and so on. Example One successful digital media campaign was by Pizza Hut, which created an app that allowed customers to create their own pizza by dragging their chosen toppings onto a graphical pizza base. The iPhone would then determine which of the chain's thousands of locations the customer happened to be nearest. The company advertised the new app online, in print, and on television - even winning a placement in Apple's own iPhone commercial. Within two weeks, the Pizza Hut app was downloaded 100,000 times and within three months iPhone users ordered $1m worth of pizza. The app now has millions of users across the iPhone, iPad, and Android platforms. [1]

The idea, suggested by Bill Gates, that networks of computers in companies should act like the human body's nervous system (system that sends brain messages), passing information between them so that companies can work more effectively. [1]
Equipment, codes, or actions that are designed to prevent people from illegally copying software or things such as records or films from the Internet. [1]
Information on an electronic message that proves who the person sending the message or information is. [1]
Software that stores information about you and your bank or credit card account and provides this information to a seller when you buy something using the Internet. [1]
Money you have to pay if you damage a house that you are renting. [1]
