Care that someone in a position of responsibility takes with their work.The duty that the owners of a ship have to do everything they can to make sure that the ship and the people and goods on it are safe. [1]
If a company dilutes its shares or the earnings on its shares, it increases the number of its shares that are available and so reduces the amount that each share will earn. [1]

Diluted market capitalisation is the total market value of a company's outstanding shares factoring in the impact of dilutive securities such as options, restricted stock units and convertible securities. It is calculated by multiplying a company's diluted shares outstanding by the current market price for one share. While market cap (also known as equity value and market value) is often used in the finance world, a more thorough analysis factors in the impact of potential shares   that is, securities that are currently not in the share count, but could become shares in the future. The impact of potential dilutive securities such as options given to employees as compensation can be large. A case in point is Twitter. At the $45.10 opening price after its November 2013 intitial public offering and based on 555m shares outstanding, many people would say Twitter had a $25bn market capitalisation ($45.10 x 555m   $25bn). However, factoring in 149m potential shares from securities such as options and restricted stock units granted to employees, Twitter has approximately 704m diluted shares giving it a diluted market capitalisation of $32bn ($45.10 x 704m). A smart investor factors in all potential dilutive securities, so a more thorough analysis focuses on the $32bn number.[1]
All the shares of a company considered together, especially after a share issue (when new shares are made available and sold), and dividends are spread over a larger number of shares. [1]
All the stock of a company considered together, especially after a share issue (when new shares are made available and sold), and dividends are spread over a larger number of shares. [1]
The fall in the value of existing shareholders' stock following an increase in issued capital, the conversion of convertible securities, or the exercise of options and warrants.

Measures implemented by a company to protect shareholders from excessive dilution of their holdings. This could include adjustment of the conversion ratio of a convertible bond, or a change in the terms of a stock options contract.
Which has a dilution effect. But also used more generally to mean a negative effect on earnings per share.

A dim sum bond is a bond denominated in renminbi but issued outside China. The first dim sum bonds were issued in Hong Kong, which is where they received their name. Dim sum is a form of Chinese food served in small bite-sized portions.    dim sum bonds in the news In February 2013 it was reported that appetite had returned for dim sum bonds. The market had underperformed in 2012 because the renminbi dropped 1.6 per cent against the US dollar between March and July shattering assumptions that it would inexorably rise due to being undervalued. The fall in the renminbi led to subdued interest in the dim sum bond market as many investors had been using the bonds as a currency play. By February 2013, the renminbi had risen to a fresh high against the US dollar and although expectations for further appreciation in 2013 looked muted there was renewed enthusiasm for investment in China. Renminbi bond prices rose and yields had fallen to 4.1 per cent from 4.6 per cent in December.
A coin used in the US and Canada, worth ten cents (one tenth of a dollar). [1]
A shop that sells many different kinds of cheap goods, especially for the house. [1]
The size of something, especially when this is given as its length, height, and width. [1]
The theory that after a certain stage of development, returns begin to get smaller for each increment of capital one adds to the production process.
The theory that after a certain stage of development, returns begin to get smaller for each increment of capital one adds to the production process.

Dink stands for dual income, no kids. Dink couples are of special interest to wealth managers because of the perception that they could have more discretionary income to invest, but financial planning can become difficult, especially if the couple is same sex.   Dinks in the news In November 2013 it was reported that banks were jostling to offer services to the same sex couple market, particularly because the majority are dinks   dual income no kids couples   with discretionary income to invest. The situation was made more complex with same sex couples in the US, however, because fewer than a third of US states recognised their unions.

A minor, short-term fall in a price following a sustained rise. A stock market investor may have a strategy to "buy on dips", which means to take advantage of a momentary cheapening of a stock in the knowledge that it will resume its rise.
A system of storing information on a computer which makes it possible to go directly to a particular piece of information without sorting through all the records. [1]
Anything other than talking that is done by an organized group of people in order to try and change something or to get what they want, for example striking. [1]

Advertising that uses traditional methods such as television or magazine advertisements advertising that involves contacting people directly, for example by writing to them, to tell them about a product or service. [1]
A cost related to a particular product or service rather than to general costs related to buildings, equipment etc. [1]
See standing order
A method for paying someone's wages directly into their bank account, or the amount paid in. [1]
When one currency is exchanged directly for another, without using that of a third country. [1]
Money that is spent directly on making one particular product or performing one particular service, rather than money spent on general costs, such as management costs. [1]
Selling goods directly to consumers in other countries. [1]
A loan transaction with no intermediary between borrower and lender.
See investment

Workers such as those who operate machines, who are directly involved in the production of goods or services, rather than those involved in organizing or managing the cost of employing workers to make a particular product or provide a particular service. This does not include other costs such as the amount spent on materials etc in Britain, workers who are employed directly by an organization such as a local government authority, rather than being employed through a separate company. [1]
Advertisements that are sent to people in the post, often people who have been chosen because they might be interested in the product. [1]
A marketer that sells directly to buyers through mailings (advertising sent by post), telephone selling etc. [1]
Any form of marketing where possible customers are contacted directly by the seller, for example by telephone or post. [1]
A cost such as rent or electricity that is included in the total cost of making a particular product when calculating costs. [1]
See direct financingSee private placement

Pricing strategy that charges different prices relative to costs according to buyer s type for the same good or service.  It is designed to elicit higher profit margins from buyers with higher willingness to pay. By using direct price discrimination, the seller can raise profit.  However, if the discrimination is not precise, the seller might lose some sales by setting a price above the customer s willingness to pay.  Direct price discrimination requires detailed information about each customer segment s willingness to pay. Example For instance, cinemas charge higher prices to adults than children as adults tend to have a decent level of disposable income.   Tourist attractions in some countries charge higher prices to overseas visitors than locals, as tourists are willing to pay more to make the most of their time on holiday.  Tourist attractions also charge a lower rate to students as they do not generally have high incomes. [1]

When someone produces all the things they need using their own efforts and skills, without the advantages of specialization (concentrating on producing only one product) or the division of labour (using different people to do different jobs). Direct production is more an economic model than a real production method. [1]
In relation to mutual funds, the purchase by an investor of shares or units in a fund directly from the fund company without the intervention of a financial planner or broker.
In foreign exchange, when one unit of a domestic currency is valued in terms of several units of a foreign currency. The opposite of indirect quote.

Direct recovery of debts (DRD), or more accurately enforcement by deduction from accounts, is a regime that will allow HMRC to recover tax and tax credits directly from debtors  bank, building society or ISA accounts. This is subject to a number of safeguards to protect taxpayers. [1]

Direct recovery of debts (DRD), or more accurately enforcement by deduction from accounts, is a regime that will allow HMRC to recover tax and tax credits directly from debtors  bank, building society or ISA accounts. This is subject to a number of safeguards to protect taxpayers. [1]
Advertising which a customer has to respond to directly, by returning a form, making a phone call etc rather than simply going to a shop to buy the product. [1]

A sale made by a manufacturer or importer direct to a shop, rather than through a wholesaler or a distributor. A sale made by a wholesaler or distributor direct to the public, rather than through shops. When a company sells goods directly to shops, rather than using another company to distribute its goods.[1]
When a company sells goods directly to shops, rather than using another company to distribute its goods.  [1]
When a company or manufacturer offers its products, services etc directly to customers, rather than through shops. [1]
Taxes levied on the earnings of an individual or company and paid directly to the government. Examples include income tax, corporate profits tax and capital gains tax.
A marketer that sells directly to buyers through mailings (information sent by post). [1]

The term is used to describe electronic trading facilities that provide buy side firms with a way to execute trades at lower costs by allowing them access to the order book of an exchange. The order book is typically only accessed by broker-dealers and market makers that are exchange members. In essence, direct market access allows firms to use the buy side firm s exchange access, but still control the way the transaction is managed.
A mortgage in which part of the interest and part of the amount borrowed is paid off with each payment. [1]
Advertising on television or in newspapers etc for medicines and drugs that people can buy in shops, rather than those they get from a doctor. [1]

A practice in which a fund adviser, at the behest of its client, directs a trade to a specific broker-dealer for execution in return for some sort of benefit. Such benefits can include services or payments. Unlike soft dollar arrangements, the benefits are realized by the client, not the adviser. [1]
An official order or instruction. [1]
One of the committee of top managers who control a company. Financial/ Sales/ Personnel etc director: someone who is in charge of a particular department of an organization.[1]
The committee in charge of an organization, especially a government organization. [1]
The pay, benefits etc that a company's directors receive, and the records of these that a company must keep by law. [1]
In Britain, the official list of the directors of a company, which must by law be sent to the Registrar of Companies. [1]
A statement by a company's directors in its annual accounts giving the directors' opinion of the state of the company, and how much should be paid to people owning shares in the company. [1]
The position of being director of a company or organization. [1]
A book or list of names, facts etc, usually arranged in alphabetical order. Part of a computer's memory where information is stored, containing one or more files.[1]
The telephone service that provides telephone numbers to people who ask for them. [1]
The idea that a government should be very active in planning and running a country's economy. [1]
Unfair or dishonest. [1]
Another name for an unclean bill of lading. [1]
See clean floatSee managed float
In bond trading, the value of a bond including accrued interest.
A tanker that has not yet been cleaned out and so is not ready to take another load. [1]
When people spend the money they have saved. [1]

Also disablement: a physical problem that makes someone unable to use a part of their body. Money that is given by the government to people who have a physical disability.  When someone is unable to use parts of their body properly.[1]
Money provided by the government to people who need extra help or cannot work because they cannot use part of their body properly. [1]
Insurance against someone not being able to work through illness or an accident, often taken out by employers to cover their workers, especially in the US. [1]
A payment made to people who are ill, injured etc. [1]
A pension paid to someone who cannot work any more because they are ill or injured. [1]
The lowest percentage of jobs that an organization must give to people who have a disability. [1]
The process of repairing a computer system that has stopped working completely or has been badly damaged by a storm, fire, or other sudden accident. [1]
To officially give or pay money to someone. [1]
A payment of money made by a professional person such as a lawyer when doing work for their client. The professional person can then claim the money back from their client later. [1]
Another name for a paying agent. [1]
A compact disc. A computer disk.[1]

Verb To officially allow or tell someone to leave hospital, the army, a job etc. To remove someone from their job.  Discharge a duty/ responsibility/ function etc: to do properly everything that is part of a particular duty etc.  Discharge a debt/ claim/ liability etc: To completely pay an amount that is owed.  To send out gas, liquid, smoke etc, or allow it to escape.  To take goods off a ship, plane etc.  To state officially that someone who was bankrupt has obeyed the court and can do business again.  Noun When someone is officially allowed or told to leave hospital, the army, a job etc.  When someone is removed from their job.  When someone performs a duty, responsibility etc properly and thoroughly.  When an amount such as a debt or money claimed on an insurance policy is completely paid.  When gas, liquid, smoke etc is sent out or allowed to escape.  When goods are taken off a ship, plane etc.[1]

When a debtor who has been declared bankrupt is released from the constraints imposed on him, provided it is clear to the court that he has done everything reasonably possible to settle his debts, with any amounts still unpaid usually wiped out.

When the duties that someone has under a contract are ended, for example because they have carried out those duties, because there has been an agreement to end the contract, or because someone has broken the contract. [1]
Someone who has been declared bankrupt in the past but has obeyed the orders of the court and can now do business again. [1]
A bill of exchange that has been paid. [1]
Concerned with how people in an organization or group should behave, and how they should be punished if they do not obey the rules. [1]
A meeting between senior people at a company and a worker who has done something wrong in order to judge the case and decide what his or her punishment will be. [1]
A statement that you are not responsible for something or not connected with it. [1]
The public release by companies of information required by regulators.

column1: disclosure of tax avoidance schemes  DoTAS
column2: Certain UK tax planning has to be disclosed to HMRC. The disclosure is usually made by a  promoter  although in some situations the disclosure must be made by the taxpayer. A  promoter  is a person who is involved in the provision of tax services in relation to the planning. A promoter may also be a bank or a securities house. The legislation currently applies to income tax, corporation tax, capital gains tax, stamp duty land tax, stamp duty reserve tax, the annual tax on enveloped dwellings and national insurance contributions. In broad terms, it applies where there are arrangements which generate a tax advantage and where the arrangements fall within one or more specific hallmarks. Similar rules apply to inheritance tax when a person makes or amends their will or codicil or property is transferred into trust. Different disclosure rules also apply to certain VAT arrangements. [1]
An accounting term used to describe a part of a business that has been closed down or disposed of.

Discontinuous innovations cause a paradigm shift in science or technology and/or the market structure of an industry. As they are entirely new-to-the world products, made to perform a function for which no product has previously existed, discontinuous innovation requires a good deal of learning for the incumbent organisation and its value network, including the user. Discontinuous innovations disrupt established routine and may even require a very different set of capabilities and new behaviour patterns. The notion of novelty is relative so a discontinuous innovation for one organisation might be an incremental one for another. Radical innovation and discontinuous innovation are synonyms. Disruptive innovation used to be a synonym until 1997. Since then the term has been strongly associated with Christensen s model. Incremental innovation is the opposite of radical innovation. [1]

The amount by which a product's sale or market price is lower than a reference market price. In the case of a bond or money market instrument, by how much it is sold or is trading below par value. The opposite of premium. In the money markets, to discount a bill means to buy it at a discount. The term is also used to denote the absorption by investors of information that might influence the movement of a particular stock or the market as a whole. Once news has been discounted, it no longer affects the stock.
A bank that buys bills of exchange documents ordering someone to pay a particular amount on a fixed date, often relating to trade. [1]
A bond that sells below its par value.
A brokerage house that executes buy and sell orders at lower commissions that charged by full-service brokers.
A brokerage that buys and sells investments for its clients, without offering them investment advice. [1]

In the UK, an institution that specialises in discounting bills of exchange, Treasury bills and short-dated government bonds in order to help the Bank of England counteract shortages of day-to-day funds in the interbank market.
A loan on which the interest and other charges are taken away from the total before the loan is given to the borrower. [1]
In Britain, the money market between the Bank of England, money marketmakers and commercial banks. [1]
A price which is particularly cheap, or lower than the normal price. [1]
When prices of a company's products are lower than normal. [1]

The interest rate charged by a central bank to commercial banks when lending short-term funds (by discounting government paper or using government paper as collateral). In the US, the discount rate, which acts as a reference rate for commercial banks' own lending rates, is one of the two key rates manipulated by the Federal Reserve to control money supply (the other being the Federal funds rate).  The discount rate is also the interest rate at which commercial banks discount bills of exchange. The term also refers to the interest rate used to calculate discounted cashflow.
A shop selling goods at much lower prices than elsewhere. [1]

When commercial banks borrow from the central bank at the discount rate, they are using the discount window. In some countries, the central bank only allows this facility to be used when it acts as a lender of last resort.
Annual yield on a security sold at a discount. Also called bank discount yield or bank discount basis.
A bill of exchange that has been bought by a bank for less than it will be worth when it becomes due for payment. [1]

The discounted payback is defined as the time period that is required for an investment's discounted cash flows to cover the initial outlay. Therefore, the shorter the discounted payback period, the more desirable the investment. [1]
A shop or business that sells goods or services at lower prices than normal. A large shop that has very low prices and a limited number of different products. [1]
The activity of buying a bill of exchange for less than the amount that will be paid on it on a fixed date in the future.[1]

Discovery-driven business planning is a method of analysing the economic feasibility of new business ventures. Professors Rita G. McGrath and Ian C. MacMillan introduced the method in their Harvard Business Review article in 1995. Before discovery-driven planning, entrepreneurs or managers focused primarily on conventional business planning whereby they calculated how much profit a new venture could earn if it achieved the targeted growth rate in the future, which inevitably turned out to be inaccurate following the venture s launch.  Discovery-driven planning turns this process on its head: the analysis focuses on figuring out what costs the venture can afford to incur in order to reach pre-specified financial goals, by generating a  reverse income statement .  In this process, one asks:  If the new venture needs to bring in a certain amount of revenues and profits, how many customers should it serve, and what would it cost to serve those customers   If the allowable costs, benchmarked with real data, are smaller than required revenues, the new venture appears to be feasible, and the next phase of discovery driven-planning can begin.  The second phase of discovery-driven planning involves creating a roadmap of the practical steps that need to be taken in order to test the important cost- and revenue-related assumptions made while building the reverse income statement. Each industry has its own key performance indicators which impact costs and revenues (such as the customer retention rate or the production yield rate). The practical steps to test these key performance indicators are scheduled as early as possible during the rollout of the new venture s products and services. Building a prototype product, pre-launch user testing and measuring customer response (purchase / no purchase, repeat / abandon) will help entrepreneurs to figure out whether the venture is able to meet or exceed its benchmarks. The third phase of discovery planning involves carrying out sensitivity analyses. For example, what would happen if the number of units that can be sold at the target market price turns out to be 20 per cent lower in reality   Or, what if the customer retention rate is only half as high  Using simulation software, the entrepreneur can explore whether such scenarios would put the economic feasibility of the venture in jeopardy. In this process, the most important cost and revenue assumptions also become apparent: they are the ones where small discrepancies relative to the targets would result in the greatest damage to profits. [1]
A difference between two numbers, amounts, details etc that ought to be the same. [1]
The ability, right, or freedom that someone has to take decisions in a particular situation. [1]
An account that gives a broker, bank or financial adviser the power to buy and sell securities - sometimes within stated limits - without seeking permission from the account holder.
Company costs that managers can easily increase or reduce, such as those for advertising or developing new products. [1]
An amount of money that can be used for purposes to be decided later. [1]
Income that you can spend on things that are not completely necessary for living. [1]
An instruction from an investor giving a broker company that buys and sells shares, bonds etc for other people the authority to choose the time and price at which to buy and sell. [1]

Spending by consumers on things that they want to buy rather than on things they need such as housing or food spending by a company or organization that can easily be increased or reduced, for example on advertising or developing new products. [1]
A personal trust that allows the trustees to use their discretion on managing assets and distributing income and capital to beneficiaries.
To behave unfairly towards one group of people or one type of company or product. [1]
A tax on goods brought into a country which varies according to the country that the goods are coming from. [1]
Another name for multiple tariff. [1]

The process of treating one market, country, type of product etc differently from another.When a worker in a company is treated unfairly because of their race, sex, age etc, especially by not being considered for a job. This is illegal in many countries. [1]
Treating a person or a group of people differently from other people, in an unfair way. [1]
A tax on particular producers intended to make it easier for other producers to compete a tax on a particular activity that some people think is unfair. [1]
Taxation using discriminatory taxes. [1]
Extra costs that make something less profitable. [1]
When average cost increases as a manufacturing operation expands. The opposite of economies of scale.
To get off a ship or plane.To put people or goods onto land from a ship or plane. [1]
Instability in the economy caused by an imbalance in the relationship between supply and demand.

Although aimed at tax avoidance by employers   in particular tax avoidance involving loans and trusts   the legislation on  disguised remuneration  is complex and quite widely drawn. The legislation refers to the provision of  rewards, recognition or loans  through  third parties , in other words, entities other than the employer and employee. [1]
Another name for hidden unemployment. [1]
When money or goods that have been kept are brought back into the economy, for example when people invest or spend money rather than save it. [2]

If a bank dishonours a cheque, it refuses to pay out money for it, usually because the person who has written it does not have enough money in their account. If someone dishonours a bill of exchange, they do not accept it when it is presented, or do not pay it after they have accepted it.[1]
Something that makes people less willing to do something. [1]

Disinflation is a sustained slowing down in price increases (in the rate of inflation). Disinflation is not to be confused with deflation, which is a sustained fall in prices.   disinflation in the news In January 2014 the Eurozone confirmed that disinflation was underway with core inflation, excluding food and energy, running at 0.7 per cent in December, a new low. An FT writer commented that the most dangerous period, so far as investors are concerned, is just before deflation strikes which is when shares tend to plunge in anticipation.                    However, a commentator from HSBC on January 1 2014 said that the best way for UK households to start feeling better off would be if the UK was to join the disinflation club.
When a group of producers stops producing particular products themselves and start buying them from other producers. [1]
The avoidance of intermediaries or middlemen. The term has been used lately in particular reference to the growing trend of investors and borrowers bypassing banks to tap capital markets.
To invest less or to stop investing in an activity or area of business. [1]
The process of reducing capital investment by disposing of capital goods or not replacing them when they wear out. Not to be confused with divestment, which is the sale of an investment.
A flat circular piece of plastic or metal used for storing computer information. [1]
A piece of equipment in a computer system used to pass information to or from a disk. [1]
Basic software that is loaded onto a computer system to make all the different parts work together. [1]

To remove someone from their job, usually because they have done something wrong.To state officially that a court case cannot continue because there is not enough evidence against the accused person. [1]
When someone is removed from their job by their employer. [1]
To send something or someone to a place. [1]
See advice note.
Someone whose job is to make sure that goods or workers are sent out at the right time.The person, company etc that has sent a package, goods etc. [1]
If a machine dispenses something, it gives it to someone who puts in money, a special number etc.To sell or give medicines to people. [1]

Dispersion is a term used in equities markets to refer to the gap between the best and the worst stocks. It is of great interest to stock pickers because the greater the dispersion the better those who make the right calls will look. For example, during the crash of 2007-2008, correlation was high, as all stocks fell at once, but returns were highly dispersed   banks did far worse than the rest as they led the market down. Therefore, those who avoided bank stocks, or sold them short, showed superior performance, even in an environment of high correlation.   dispersion in the news In December 2013 an FT writer commented on research by S&P; Indices which had found that dispersion was correlated with volatility. As volatility levels were low, all stocks were moving in a close range of one another which meant there were fewer opportunities for out-performance.
A specially made box, used to show goods that are on sale in shops. [1]
Intended to be used once or for a short time and then thrown away.Available to be used. [1]
Personal income that remains after direct taxes and government charges have been paid.
When someone gets rid of something they no longer need or want.[1]
The sale of an asset or investment.
To get rid of something that is no longer needed or wanted. [1]

The tendency of investors to hold losers too long and sell winners too soon. Investors are willing to realise gains but are reluctant to realise losses. The effect is observed in experiments and over different investor types, time periods, asset classes, and countries. It is considered an irrational behavior, because selling and holding decisions should depend on the perceived future value of a security, but not the purchase price. Some studies have documented that stocks investors sell due to the disposition effect (winners) outperform those they hold (losers); this means that investors would be better off by holding winners for longer and selling losers sooner. The disposition effect is shown to be inconsistent with explanations based on information, rebalancing, or tax considerations. [1]
To take property or land away from someone, often illegally. [1]

A serious disagreement between two groups of people, especially a disagreement between workers and their employers in which the workers take action to protest. Be in dispute (with somebody): if two groups of people are in dispute, they are involved in a disagreement.[1]
An official process that a company follows in order to find a satisfactory way of dealing with a serious disagreement between people within the company or between the company and its workers. [1]
To officially or legally stop someone being allowed to do something, because they have done something wrong. [1]
To prevent a situation, event, system etc from working in the normal way. [1]

Being  disruptive , when expressed by a start-up s founder, refers to the act of forcing one s way into a niche, bludgeoning the existing competition with a new method of delivering a service and generally injecting greater efficiency into something people have done or used since time immemorial. In this sense, the word  disruption  can be paired with any industry and the start-up team will sound plausible, such has been the effect of the internet in scaring corporate bosses in even the most low tech of businesses.   disruption in the news Disruption fits an age where the internet is changing everything, from the way we shop   Asos has disrupted high street fashion, for instance   to how we move around, as in the case of Zipcar and Uber s disruption of the car and taxi markets. The worldwide web is the ultimate disruptive change in this context. While this may all sound great, a problem arises when it seems every start-up is using the word to describe what it does. [1]

A term linked to entrepreneurship. In pitching an idea, entrepreneurs often describe their products and services as disruptive. This term comes from Clayton Christensen s writing on the challenges big companies face in developing new ideas. Christensen s argument is that large incumbent companies are focused on delivering value to their existing customers and  thus do not always pursue innovations that could potentially attract new customers. This gap presents an opportunity for entrepreneurs to develop products and services that meet this unsatisfied demand and upend the competitive structure of the entire industry. Disruptive innovation can come in the form of: - novel organisational practices like Nucor s pay-for-performance schemes - new business models like Southwest s low-cost approach to flying - cutting edge technologies like Intuitive s Da Vinci surgical robot. For entrepreneurs, market research that gauges the interest of 'latent' customers, who are not yet participating in a market, can be especially valuable in developing disruptive innovation. Disruptive products need not be high tech; Nintendo s Wii was a low-tech game console with intuitive controls and great gameplay that drew in younger gamers and brought back older aficionados who grew up with Super Mario. [1]
The termination of a company's legal existence once its assets have been sold and its debts have been paid.
To bring a company or partnership to an end officially. [1]
To take goods from someone to be sold in order to pay rent that is owed. [1]
When someone's goods are taken with the permission of a court of law so that they can be sold to pay unpaid rent, bills etc. [1]
When a person or company is forced to borrow money because they are in need of money or just in order to keep going or keep trading. [1]
When a person or company is forced to sell something because they are in need of money. [1]

An asset that is put on sale, usually at a cheap price, because its owner is forced to sell it. There could be various reasons for this, including bankruptcy, excessive debt and regulatory constraints. Debt itself can be sold on to a new owner at below face value (distressed debt).
See distressed asset.
Property bought with a loan on which repayments are no longer being made. [1]
Profit earned during a particular period of time that a company pays to shareholders. [1]

To make goods available to customers after they have been produced. To divide up a company's profits for a particular period of time and give them to shareholders in the form of dividends or new shares.[1]

A distributed denial of service, or DDoS, attack uses many computers and many internet connections to flood a targeted server or network resource with requests, or packets of information, rendering it unavailable to users, or in come cases crashing the network. A DDoS attack differs from a denial service (DoS) attack which uses just one computer and one internet connection to flood a targeted server.   DDoS in the news In March 2013 it was reported that hackers had hit a European anti-spam group with a cyber attack so large that experts said it could slow down the whole internet. According to security companies monitoring the attack, it had risen in scale from 10 gigabits per second of data to 300Gbps, making it one of the largest of its kind and about six times the size of most such incidents. Cloudflare, a security company hired by Spamhaus   which had been subject to large-scale DDoS attacks   to fight off the bombardment, said the attack ceased on March 21 but resumed the next day with increased power, targeting Cloudflare s network providers in an effort to neutralise the defence.
When a computer system processes data (information) at various places, instead of using one central computer. [1]
See distributable profit.

The actions involved in making goods available to customers after they have been produced, for example moving, storing, and selling the goods. When a company's profits are divided up and given to shareholders in the form of dividends or new shares.  The way in which wealth is divided among people in a particular economy.[1]
The sale of a large amount of stock, which typically does not move the price very much but is a signal that the price will soon fall.
A stock's trading range below which sellers will not sell.
A warehouse from which goods that arrive from factories or suppliers are sent on to factories, shops, or customers. [1]
The series of organizations that are involved in passing products from manufacturers to the public. [1]
A system for moving goods from producers to buyers, and the people and organizations involved. [1]
A sum of money charged by a film-making company to make a film available to cinemas. [1]
The period between when a dividend is declared (the declaration date) and when shareholders must own stock to be entitled to the payout (the date of record). Usually just a few days.
A warehouse in which goods that are ready to be sent to shops or direct to customers are stored. [1]
Connected with or relating to distribution. [1]
Industries involved in distribution, for example those involved in moving, storing, or selling goods. [1]
A person or business responsible for making goods available to customers after they have been produced, either one that sells directly to the public or one that sells to shops etc. [1]
A lawyer in the US who is responsible for bringing charges against people who are accused of crimes in a particular area. [1]
In Britain, someone whose job is to make sure that local government finance is run as it should be according to law. [1]
In the US, a federal court at which a trial is first heard. [1]
A judge in a district court in the US. [1]
The trouble or lack of satisfaction caused by having too much of something. [1]
A mark (") that you write beneath a word in a list so that you do not have to write the same word again. [1]
If two or more rates of interest, unemployment etc diverge, the difference between them becomes larger. [1]

With increasing globalisation, many organisations face tougher competition at the same time they are working in a more complex environment, needing to coordinate geographically dispersed operations and a cross-cultural workforce. This leads to diverse teams becoming more common at all levels of the organisation. Diversity can be based on various characteristics such as gender, age, nationality, ethnic and/ or cultural group etc, or on indicators of cognitive diversity such as international experience, education, industry and work experience that can all lead to different perspectives. Research shows that diversity results in better performance on complex decisions and problems, just the type of challenges faced by global firms. Also, diversity has a bigger impact on organisations with greater managerial discretion such as the high-tech sector or when undertaking new initiatives. Diversity is increasingly necessary for working globally, to ensure a global mindset, and for long-term cultural agility. In much of the literature, diversity is seen as balancing the tendency for homogenous groups to think in similar ways. If differing views can be combined in problem-solving or decision-making, the outcome is usually better than that of a single view, this is the synergy of working with diverse groups. However, diverse teams can also experience their differences as barriers to communication, so that reaching a common understanding or outcome takes more time and effort, and raises the transaction costs of teamwork. Many studies assume that a global mindset, often defined as openness and global knowledge, is key to executives and organisations succeeding in a highly interlinked world. Example In 2011, Nokia s leadership group is an example of a diverse team of thirteen members.  This includes three women, one non-white, six Finns, four Americans, one Canadian, one British and one Australian. Three were born in the  50s, one in the 70 s and the rest in the  60s. Their work experience covers Europe, North American and East Asia and their educational backgrounds include engineering, technology, psychology, law, economics and finance from a variety of institutions while the team members represent many functions. It remains to be seen whether they can make successful decisions that profit from their diverse perspectives and experiences without getting into the conflicts that can arise when people have different assumptions about how things work. [1] View BASF set for  1bn China investment

In relation to portfolio management, when investors spread risk by holding different classes of assets. In corporate activity, when a company operates in different business areas in an effort to increase sources of income and spread risk.  [1] Diversification   not putting all your eggs in one basket. The theory says adding risks which are not correlated to each other allows you to add expected return without increasing the risk. The problem is that asset class correlations are not stable.  [2]
Shares in diversified companies. [1]

If a company or economy diversifies, it increases the range of goods or services it produces.To start to put your money into different types of investments in addition to the investments you already have. [1]
When money stops being spent in one area of business or on one type of product, and starts being spent on another. [1]

Company initiatives undertaken to include all employees in company programmes and informal social networks. Organisations seeking global relevance cannot ignore the impact of workforce diversity on their ability to problem-solve, innovate, and cultivate diverse markets. Diversity management goes far beyond simply hiring demographically diverse employees. It encompasses everything a company does that signals its genuine attitude toward employees  diverse perspectives and backgrounds. Company programmes and processes, as well as managers  behaviour, create a palpable climate around diversity, so that employees develop a strong sense of whether or not it is truly acceptable for them to bring their full selves to work. Without diversity management, managers and employees may unthinkingly act on prejudices and feel threatened by differences among employees. Diversity management is intended to foster appreciation for the diverse ideas and personal histories that employees bring to the workplace. When employees value each others  diversity and learn to connect and communicate across lines of difference, employees feel safe sharing their distinctive ideas, which fuel innovation. Diversity management is also crucial for sustainable business growth because the increasingly diverse public evaluates organisations on their diversity management. If an organisation is found to be culturally insensitive, its ethics and ability to function in the global marketplace will be called into question. Example IBM has embraced diversity management as an essential strategy for running its business and expanding its global presence. Its leaders have crafted diverse teams that understand local markets, and promoted the appreciation of diversity broadly defined within IBM s employee communities. These attempts to cultivate a positive diversity climate have helped IBM to continue driving innovation. [1]
To spend money or make an effort in a new area of business or a new product. [1]

Diverted profits tax was introduced from 1 April 2015. It is charged at 25% when the UK tax base is reduced, either by segregating UK and non-UK activities to avoid creating a permanent establishment, or by making payments to low tax entities, where there is a lack of economic substance. [1]

If a group divests one of the companies that it owns, it gets rid of it by selling it.If a company divests assets, it sells them, for example because it needs cash for another activity or to repay debts.
The sale of an investment. Not to be confused with disinvestment, which is a reduction in a company's capital goods.
An informal word for a dividend. [1]

The part of a company's earnings that is distributed to shareholders. It can be in the form of cash or shares. A company is under no obligation to pay a dividend, and its board may decide to omit a payout if it feels cash flow is insufficient or should be used for other purposes, such as to reduce debt. In some countries, dividends are paid quarterly; in others they are paid once or twice a year.
The American word for dividend warrant. [1]
The number of times a company's most recent dividend can be paid out of its annual earnings.
Model used to determine a share's valuation based on expected future dividend payments that have been discounted to reflect the cost of carrying the stock.
Accumulated unpaid dividends due on cumulative preferred stock and payable to the current holder.
A payment of a part of a company's profits to its shareholders (the people who own shares in it). [1]
The amount that a company pays out to shareholders in dividends as a percentage of its profits. This calculation is used especially in the US. [1]
The dividend paid out by a company for each of its shares. [1]
An arrangement to allow shareholders to automatically use all or part of their dividends to buy new shares in the company, sometimes at a discounted price.
When shares are bought in order to get a dividend payment and then sold again. [1]
Buying a stock before its ex-dividend date, and selling it afterwards (once it has risen above the purchase price) in order to gain from the capital appreciation as well as the dividend payout.

The UK s dividend tax allowance will be introduced from 1 April 2016, and is an amount of dividends which would otherwise be subject to income tax and which will attract tax at 0%. In other words, it will effectively be an exemption from tax for an amount up to a specified level of UK dividend income. It replaces the dividend tax credit, which provides partial relief from income tax on UK dividend income, effectively making the tax rate on the dividend amount: 0% for basic rate taxpayers, 25% for higher rate taxpayers and 30.56% for additional rate taxpayers. The allowance will initially be set at  5,000 a year, with rates of tax on dividend income above the allowance of 7.5% for basic rate taxpayers, 32.5% for higher rate taxpayers and 38.1% for additional rate taxpayers. [1]   dividend tax allowance The change is expected to raise more than  2bn a year, making it one of the biggest revenue-raisers mentioned in the UK Summer Budget 2015. Small investors with dividend income of less than  5,000 a year will see little change, and should also find it easier to fill in their tax returns. But investors with larger portfolios held outside tax wrappers could be hit hard. [2]
A cheque sent by a company to a shareholder in payment of dividends. [1]
Annual return from holding a stock, determined by dividing the company's total dividends for the year by the current share price (adjusted for any share splits).
A company's dividend (the amount of profit it pays to shareholders in a particular period of time) as a percentage of its share price. [1]
When someone sells shares just before a dividend payment and buys them again after the payment in order to avoid paying tax on the dividend. [1]
A figure included in a company's accounts showing the amount that has been or will be paid in dividends for a particular period of time. [1]
One of the large parts into which a large organization or company is divided. [1]
The idea that it is more productive and cost-effective to have each worker in a manufacturing operation specialise in one activity than perform many different tasks.
Connected with a division of an organization, company etc. [1]
When an organization, company etc is divided into several divisions or separate companies. [1]
Another spelling of DIVI. [1]
See DIY.

NounA place in a port where ships are loaded and unloaded. Docks: a port area.  The dock: the part of a law court where the person who is accused of a crime stands.  VerbIf a ship docks, it sails into a dock.  Dock somebody's wages/ pay: to reduce the amount of money you pay someone, usually as a punishment.[1]
A company that owns and operates a port. [1]
Charges paid to a port by a shipping company that uses it to load or unload goods. [1]
A document giving details of goods left at a port for loading. [1]
Someone whose job is loading and unloading ships. [1]
A document giving details of goods that have been sold or delivered, the contents of a package etc.A list of legal cases that will take place in a particular court. [1]
A piece of equipment into which you connect a laptopcomputer, with connections that allow you to operate other equipment, such as a printer, using the laptop. [1]
An area of a city that contains or used to contain docks. Docklands: an area of London formerly containing docks and now a centre for business with many office buildings.[1]
The area around the place in a port where ships are loaded and unloaded. [1]
A place where ships are built or repaired. [1]
The highest university degree. [1]
A document that shows the ownership of property or that gives the person possessing it the right to deal with the property as if they owned it. [1]
When a computer system allows different people to read or make changes at the same time to a document stored on the system. [1]
A method of financing international trade where a bank agrees to pay the exporter when it receives the related trade documents. [1]
Documents that are used to prove that something is true or correct, or as a record of something.Documents that explain how a piece of equipment works. [1]
An arrangement in which an importer does not receive the documents giving them ownership of goods until they have accepted and promised to pay the related bill of exchange. [1]
An arrangement in which an importer will be given the documents giving them ownership of goods only after paying the related bill of exchange. [1]

A bill of exchange addressed to a person such as an importer who is due to receive goods. The person must accept the bill of exchange before the bank will give them the documents needed to get possession of the goods. [1]

A bill of exchange addressed to a person such as an importer who is due to receive goods. The person must pay the bill of exchange before the bank will give them the documents needed to get possession of the goods. [1]
To deliberately avoid doing something, especially paying for something.Something dishonest that is done to avoid a rule or law. [1]
Tax/ licence dodger: someone who uses dishonest methods to avoid paying taxes. [1]
Likely to cause problems.Dishonest or illegal. [1]
In the growth/share matrix, a product with low market share in a low-growth market. [1]
Someone who is given the uninteresting or unpleasant jobs to do. [1]
Written abbreviation for dollar. [1]
If an industry or market is in the doldrums, there is very little increase in prices or very little trade taking place. [1]
In Britain, money that the government gives to people who are looking for work. [1]
Used to refer to the number of people who are unemployed. [1]

The name of the currency unit used in the United States, Australia, New Zealand, Hong Kong, Singapore, and some other countries. The symbol for the dollar is $. A piece of paper money of this value.  The dollar: the value of US money in relation to the money of other countries.[1]
The countries of the world where the US dollar is used as the main currency or where the value of the currency is directly connected to the US dollar. [1]
A market that trades on the expectation that the US dollar will fall in value against other currencies. The opposite is a dollar bull market.
A market that trades on the expectation that the US dollar will rise in value against other currencies. The opposite is a dollar bear market.

When a small amount of money is invested in the same stock over a period of time. [1]  A system of accumulating shares or investment fund units by investing a fixed amount of money at set intervals. This means the investor buys more shares/units when the price is low, and fewer when the price is high. The theory is that this is less costly than a system that involves buying a fixed number of shares/units at set intervals. Also called constant dollar plan.
Since most bonds are in US dollars, the term dollar bond is normally specified when dollar-denominated bonds are issued outside the US, or are issued inside the US by foreign companies.

A method of calculating a portfolio return that looks at the total dollar values at the beginning and at the end of an investment, including any additions or withdrawals of funds, as well as the income and capital gains or losses.
When the US dollar replaces a country's own currency. This can be a government decision or a move by the market (the general public) to protect itself against the risk of holding the local currency.
Written abbreviation for dollars. [1]

An area of activity, interest, or knowledge. Somebody's/ something's domain: an activity controlled by one person, organization, industry etc.  An area of land or property owned and controlled by one person or organization.  The public domain: if information or property is in the public domain, it is available for everyone to use and not kept secret, or not kept as the property of a particular person or organization.[1]

The address of a computer network connected to the Internet. A domain name is followed by an abbreviation which could show its type, for example .com for a company, or its country of origin, for example .uk for the United Kingdom. [1]
Relating to the home or the family.Relating to the country you live in, rather than abroad. [1]
Goods and services consumed in the country where they are produced. [1]

A way of measuring growth in the total amount of money in a country's economy at a particular time. It includes bank loans to private customers in the UK and abroad, and the public sector borrowing requirement (the amount of money the government will need to borrow in the future for all its different departments). It does not include the amount of money owed by the government to private companies. [1]
The currency of the home country of a particular user. [1]
Demand from within a particular country, not from abroad. [1]
Investment in your own country rather than abroad. [1]
The country you live in or where a company is based, seen as a place where goods or services can be sold. [1]
Government policy concerned with education, health, and other issues that affect its own country. [1]
The place where a person or company establishes residence for tax purposes.
Be domiciled in: if a person is domiciled in a particular country, they live there, and it is thought of as their permanent home. [1]
A company with such a strong position it can effectively control prices within its market or industry.
US market jargon advising investors not to trade against a market trend. "Tape" refers to the ticker tape, which relays real-time US stock quotations to brokers and investors.
To give money or something valuable to a person or organization in order to help them. [1]
See donated stock.
Stock in a company transferred by an outside party to that same company free of charge. The stock becomes part of the company's donated surplus or donated capital, as opposed to its paid-in capital.
See donated stock.

Donation-based crowdfunding plays a crucial role in the new wave of alternative finance and the future of our economy. It enables individuals to directly share their money with causes and projects that they feel strongly about and thereby empower others to create impact. This form of crowdfunding essentially involves backers donating varying sums of money to support a specific cause or project. Sometimes they will receive a simple "thank you" or a special mention   or even a physical item such as a postcard   however, the pledge is essentially a donation. This model differs from reward-based crowdfunding which is generally applied to the financing of new products, and provides an item with a clear monetary value in exchange for a pledge. Donation-based crowdfunding was established long before equity-based crowdfunding, where the donor invests money in return for equity in the venture (e.g. CrowdCube) and credit-based crowdfunding, also known as peer-to-peer lending, where an investor will expect a financial return with interest (e.g. Funding Circle). The donation-based crowdfunding model is changing the face of education. Not only is it being added to the curriculum of many business schools, it is also providing vital additional funds for student fees (e.g. StudentFunder) and projects at both universities and schools (e.g. hubbub.net codeclub.co.uk). Only 1 per cent of all existing university alumni fundraising is done online, but around  882m is donated to UK universities by alumni. Donation-based crowdfunding makes alumni giving more efficient, transparent and social, so the opportunity to increase both the amount given, and the amount given online, is significant.[1]
Someone who receives money or other valuable things from another person. Someone who has been given a power of attorney.[1]
Someone who gives money or other valuable things to people who are ill, hungry, poor etc. [1]
Someone who works or goes door to door goes to each house in a street.Goods that are delivered door to door are brought from the factory to a person's home. [1]

Door-to-door sales, collections etc involve going to each house in a street in order sell something, to collect information etc.A door-to-door service delivers goods directly from a factory to a person's house. [1]
Something that is dormant has not been active for a long time, although it may become active in the future. [1]
A bank account that is still open but not being used. [1]
An area just outside a large town where many of the people working in the town live. [1]
Money. [1]
A collection of written papers which contain detailed information about a particular subject or person. [1]
A company that does business using the Internet or provides a service on the Internet. [1]
A company that does business using the Internet or provides a service on the Internet. [1]
See dot-com

This refers just to the mania around start-up internet companies, many of which went public without ever generating any revenue, achieved huge markets caps and then died. This was the most visible part of the broader tech bubble, which also included massive over-investment in telecoms and IT infrastructure (which consumed far larger amounts of capital.) It was all triggered by the rise of the Web. [1]
Sign on the dotted line: to agree officially to something by writing your name on an official or legal document. [1]

The double Irish, exploited by Google, Microsoft and Facebook, is the most controversial tax loophole. It allows multinationals that use Ireland as a foreign operating base to avoid its modest 12.5 per cent corporation tax. Profits are instead routed to a subsidiary in Bermuda. It depends on Ireland s permissive view that an Irish-registered business should be taxed where it is managed, even if that is an island where shorts are business attire. This irritates the US government, which would like its cut of the $1tn US companies have parked offshore, and the EU member states where the likes of Google make substantial sales booked in Ireland. But the double Irish has been a covert competitive advantage for the erstwhile Celtic tiger.   double Irish in the news To appease EU competition regulators, Ireland capitulated in its October budget and announced a phasing out of the loophole by 2020. This gives tax advisers time to dream up replacement schemes. Tax ruses come and go   the double Irish, for example, was once accompanied by a manoeuvre known as the  Dutch sandwich . What never changes is the opportunity for avoidance that is created by the differences between national systems. The willingness of governments to lure footloose businesses with tax breaks is another constant. The Faustian element is that governments will collectively lose more revenue than they gain from such competition. [1]
A term in technical analysis indicating a level of support for a stock, which hits a low, then rebounds, then hits the same low again.
Cheating and deceiving people. [1]

A method of calculating depreciation (the gradual loss in something's value) where twice the normal rate is subtracted in each period of time. For example, for an asset depreciated over five years, 40% of its remaining value is depreciated each year, not 20%. [1]
A double density computer disk has twice as much space for storing information as some earlier kinds of disk had. [1]
When someone receives money from two different sources for doing the same job. [1]

The accounting system in which each transaction is recorded twice, as a debit in one account and as a credit in another. For example, a sale is recorded as a credit in one account and the money owed by the buyer is recorded as a debit in another. [1]
The numbers between 10 and 99. [1]

Describes a practice where two or more companies pool their risk - by each placing capital in the other. Example A common example is when an insurance company purchases shares with a bank and, in return, the bank extends credit to the insurance firm. In this reciprocal arrangement, both institutions are leveraging their exposure to risk. [1]

Life insurance or personal accident insurance where the amount paid out is twice the normal amount if the insured person dies or is injured in certain types of accident, for example a road accident. [1]
When the same thing is insured with two different insurers, and where, if there is a claim, each insurer pays a part. [1]
An option that gives the holder the right either to buy or to sell the shares etc involved. [1]

In corporate affairs, when shareholders, as owners of a company, bear not only a tax on profits but also (in many countries) a tax on the dividends they receive.  In terms of national taxes, when an individual or company is taxed on the same earnings by more than one country.
A term in technical analysis indicating a level of upwards resistance for a stock, which hits a high, then dips, then hits the same high again.
To promise the same hotel room, seat in a theatre, table at a restaurant etc to more than one person by mistake. [1]
To press a button on a computer mouse twice in order to send an instruction to the computer. [1]
To cheat someone who you are involved in an illegal or dishonest activity with. [1]

A method of accelerated depreciation, approved in some countries, that allows companies to write off in the first year twice as much of the cost of a fixed asset as it would using the straight line depreciation method.
Relating to numbers between 10 and 99. [1]
When prices rise at between 10 and 99 per cent per year. [1]
When an economy goes into recession twice without having undergone a full recovery in between.
An arrangement between two countries so that someone does not pay tax twice, for example in the country where they work and in the country where they normally live. [1]

A time on a financial market when two types of futures (contracts to buy or sell shares etc at a fixed price on a fixed date) or options (rights to buy or sell shares etc at a fixed price within a fixed period of time) both expire (reach the end of their life) at the same time. [1]
A debt that is not likely to be repaid. [1]
Money. [1]

This refers to the migration of people, particularly shoppers, from the town centre, especially the main shopping location, to the periphery such as the outer suburbs. [1] ViewThe changing face of Britain s high streets

The Federal Reserve has a joint mandate to maximise employment and maintain low inflation. Actually, there is a third part to the mandate - to limit interest rate volatility - but that aspect rarely comes into play.  Given that monetary policy is fundamentally about the management of aggregate demand, any Fed policy that pushes toward one goal, for example higher employment, will move them away from the other goal. A dove is a FOMC (Federal Open Market Committee) member who puts more independent weight on the employment goal. This person would tend to be described as dovish. [1] The meaning of the term dove is opposite to hawk.
If an amount or the level of something goes down, it falls to a lower amount or level.  If a machine, system, or piece of electrical equipment is down, it is not working.  [1]
The first payment made in the repayment of a large debt, such as a mortgage. [1]
Time that a machine in a factory or a computer is not working properly and cannot be used time that a factory is not working, usually because there is not enough demand for its products. [1]
If the people who work in a factory down tools, they refuse to work. [1]
The lowering of a research analyst's recommendation on a stock or the credit rating on a bond.
If something that was successful is going downhill, it is starting to fail, and is getting gradually worse. [1]

To move computer software or information from one computer to another, usually from a large computer to a smaller one.A computer program or file that has been downloaded, or the process of doing this. [1]
A downloadable computer program or document can be copied from a computer network onto your own computer. [1]

Involving goods and services that are cheap and not very good quality compared to similar goods or services. Go/ move downmarket: to start buying or selling cheaper goods or services.  Take something downmarket: to change a product or a service, or people's ideas about it, so that it is cheaper or seems cheaper and more popular.[1]
Initial partial payment, as part of a mortgage or other purchase agreement.

To sell or buy cheaper goods of lower quality. Involving goods and services that are cheap and not very good quality compared to similar goods or services.  Go/ move downscale: to start buying or selling cheaper goods or services.  Take something downscale: to change a product or a service, or people's ideas about it, so that it is cheaper or seems cheaper and more popular.[1]
If someone downshifts, they willingly choose to do a less important, difficult, or stressful job, so that they are under less pressure and have more time to enjoy their life. [1]
Sometimes downside for short. The extent of a possible decline in the value of a security or other investment. The opposite of upside risk.
Reducing a company's workforce, normally as part of a restructuring to improve efficiency and profitability, which may also involve the spin-off of non-core operations.

A term used mainly in the oil industry to describe operations such as refining, petrol (gas) stations and marketing that are relatively close to the consumer, as opposed to exploration and exploitation of crude oil, which are described as upstream operations.

A term used mainly in the oil industry to describe operations such as refining, petrol (gas) stations and marketing that are relatively close to the consumer, as opposed to exploration and exploitation of crude oil, which are described as upstream operations.
Another name for a downturn. [1]
The sale of a stock when it is down one tick (the minimum possible change in market price) from the price of the previous sale. The opposite of uptick.

Time lost in producing goods because something has gone wrong, for example because a machine has broken or materials have not arrived. Time lost on a computer network (a system of connected computers) because the system is not working properly.[1]
The downtown area of a city is the main business district where many shops and offices are located. [1]
Downward trend in the movement of the price of a security. The opposite of uptrend.
The part of the economic cycle when prices or the value of stocks, shares etc fall. [1]
Towards a lower position or level. [1]
When official rules restrict the type of buildings allowed on a particular area of land, or on the type of work that can be done in those buildings. [1]

Money which is given by one company to a company it is trying to buy. The dowry is meant to encourage the second company to agree to the arrangement. Money or valuable gifts that in some cultures the family of a bride gives to her husband when she gets married.[1]
Written abbreviation for dozen. [1]
A group of twelve things. [1]
A measure of how clear the details of an image produced by a printer, scanneretc are. The more dots there are per inch, the clearer the image. [1]

A written order to pay money. A sight draft instructs the drawee to pay a specific amount to the payee (often also the drawer) on demand. A time draft fixes payment on a specific date or a stated time after the draft has been received.
The conditions of an agreement before they become final. [1]
A drain on something: something that continuously uses up a lot of money, time, or effort. To use too much of something so that there is not enough left.[1]

When a central bank decreases day-to-day money supply through money market operations, for instance by pushing up interbank rates (making it more costly for commercial banks to borrow money), or by issuing bills to commercial banks at attractive terms (persuading them to give more of their money to the central bank). Other possible measures, with a longer term impact on the amount of money in the system (draining reserves), include the raising of reserve requirements, forcing banks to maintain more money on deposit with the central bank.
A ship's draught is the distance from the bottom of the ship to the level of the water. This distance is the depth of water that a ship needs to float. [1]

Also draw out: to take money from your bank account. To receive an amount of money regularly from your employer or from the government.  To write out and sign a cheque or bank order.  To write a bill of exchange.[1]
To use up part of a credit facility made available by a financial institution.
Import duty rebate triggered by the re-export of goods that were initially imported.
When a stock or supply of something is used.When someone obtains money as part of a loan that has already been agreed or uses money that they have saved.

The bank that is given an instruction to pay a sum of money to someone when a person who has an account with that bank writes a cheque or bank draft. The person named on a bill of exchange who is expected to accept it and to pay it.[1]

A person who writes a cheque and so gives an instruction to his or her bank to pay a sum of money to someone. A person who signs a bill of exchange that gives an instruction to another person to pay a sum of money at a particular time.[1]
A company account from which partners or owners can take money for their own purposes. [1]
The act of collecting and delivering goods by road or rail, or the charge that a haulage contractor makes for doing this. [1]
The way that you are expected to dress in a particular situation, especially as an employee of a particular company. [1]
To go slowly up or down in value, without any particular direction.A slow change or development from one situtation, opinion etc to another. [1]
When advertisements for a product or service are shown repeatedly over a long period of time. [1]
A way of advertising a product or service in which advertisements are shown repeatedly over a long period of time. [1]
A way of selling goods or services to people by making regular telephone calls to them over a long period of time to persuade them to buy. [1]
A planned effort by an organization to achieve something.  A part of a computer that reads information from a disk.[1]
To succeed by arguing in a very determined way in making an agreement that is very much to your advantage. [1]
A drive-in restaurant, cinema, bank etc allows you to buy food, watch a film etc without leaving your car. [1]
A shop where people can do their shopping without getting out of their cars. [1]
A drive-through bank, restaurant etc is one that you can use without getting out of your car. [1]
A person who drives a car, bus, train etc.Something that has an important influence on other things.

Drones are unmanned aircraft, of any size or shape, used for both civilian and military purposes. There has been increasing discussion of the use of so-called unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in a commercial setting. Although Amazon's founder Jeff Bezos has said he could see drone deliveries inside five years (see news below) others have been more cautious and think using UAVs for delivery would be better suited to remote parts of Africa rather than dense, built-up environments such as US cities. To view the different kinds of drone available in 2013 click on the images in the graphic below.       drones in the news In October 2013 an FT report looked at the rising use of drones in the US military and disturbing proposals to increase spending on drones to provide 24-hour patrols of US borders. In December 2013 it was reported that Amazon was working on a project to provide same-day delivery of goods ordered online by drone.   View FT indepth page: The Drone Economy
If prices, sales etc droop, they start to fall. [1]

To fall to a lower level or amount. To stop doing or planning something.  To lose money in business, a game etc.  If there is a drop in the amount, level, or number of something, it goes down or becomes less.[1]
See drop-down menu.
A date by which it is very important that you have done or completed something, because after this date it is no longer worth doing or completing. [1]
A list of choices which appears on a computer screen when you click the right button of a mouse on an empty space on the screen. [1]
A bond or loan with an interest rate that changes but does not go below an agreed level. [1]
If there is a drop-off in the amount, level, or number of something, it goes down or becomes less.A delivery, or the place where something is delivered to. [1]

An arrangement between a company that sells goods and the supplier or producer of the goods. The goods are advertised and marketed by the company selling them, but delivered directly from the supplier or producer to the customer.When letters, packages etc are taken to a place nearer to the postal address before being posted, in order to save US postal service charges. [1]
Another name for drop-down menu. [1]
A medicine or substance for making medicines.An illegal substance that people take to make them feel happy or excited. [1]
A company that makes and sells medicines. [1]
A shop where you can buy medicines, beauty products etc. [1]
A large round container for storing liquids such as oil, chemicals etc. [1]
Cargo consisting of dry goods such as coal, iron, food grains, seeds etc. [1]
An enclosed place used for repairing or building ships, from which the water can be pumped in and out. [1]
Farming methods used in dry areas where there is very little water and no irrigation (way of supplying water to land). [1]
Goods such as tobacco, tea, coffee, and sugar that are not in liquid form things such as clothes, sheets, and curtains that are made from cotton or other cloth. [1]
A lease where an airline leases aircraft directly from their maker or from a leasing company, rather than from another airline. [1]
A system of units for measuring goods such as grain and sugar that are not liquids, or one of these units. [1]
A ship carrying goods such as tobacco and sugar that are not in liquid form. [1]
To no longer be available or active. [1]

When a marketmaker (financial institution that has supplies of shares to sell) is allowed to buy and sell shares for itself as well as for clients. This situation has existed on the London stockmarket since big bang. [1]

A bond that pays interest in one currency but is redeemed in another. The redemption currency is normally the US dollar, and the coupon is usually in a currency that allows the borrower to offer more attractive yields.
When a company is listed on more than one stock exchange. Also known as cross listing.

Publicly listed closed-end mutual fund which has preferred and common classes of shares. Preferred shareholders receive the income from the fund (dividends and interest), while common shareholders receive any capital gains.

Publicly listed closed-end mutual fund which has preferred and common classes of shares. Preferred shareholders receive the income from the fund (dividends and interest), while common shareholders receive any capital gains.
When a company has two suppliers for the same product so as to be sure that the product will always be available and to be able to compare the suppliers' prices etc. [1]
Something that is useless or of bad quality, especially because it does not work correctly. [1]
A cheque that cannot be paid because the person who wrote it has no money or not enough money in their bank account. [1]
If an amount of money is due, it must be paid now or at the stated time.Proper and expected by law. [1]
An amount of money that is owed. [1]
The date by which an amount of money must be paid, a document received etc. [1]

A detailed check of the financial and operational status of an acquisition target, supplier, or other potential business partner before a deal is finalised. The term is also used for when the underwriter of a new security issue, or brokers that will sell the securities onto investors, investigate the reliability of the issuer. This may involve a due diligence meeting between the issuer, the lead manager and other institutions connected to the issuer.
See due diligence.
The correct way to deal with a legal case. [1]
Regular payments made to an organization such as a professional association or trade union by its members. [1]
When dues for membership of a trade union are taken out of people's wages by their employer and paid directly to the union. [1]
If business on a financial market is dull, not many people are buying or selling. [1]
In the proper, expected, or legal way. [1]
A terminal that cannot be used by itself as a computer, but can be used to look at or work on information that is on a network or larger computer. [1]
To reduce the number of people working for a company to a level where it is no longer possible to do the work effectively or well. [1]
A product that is made to look like a real product and is used for testing, obtaining people's opinions etc.A test advertisement or design.

To put waste in a particular place, especially illegally. To sell something that you do not want.  To sell products cheaply in an export market, perhaps in order to increase your share of the market there.  To copy information from a computer onto another computer, or onto a tape or a disk.[1]

The sale of an imported commodity at a price lower than the cost of producing it in the exporting country.
