Unused parts of the airwaves previously reserved for television broadcasts are referred to as white space. White space technology allows mobile broadband to be carried over unused, and unlicensed, broadcast frequencies, which could be used by smartphones and tablets as well as a range of business applications. In effect, the technology fills in the gaps between the frequencies that are otherwise used to broadcast TV. Just as the words on a page are separated by white space, which prevents the sentences from overlapping, the white spaces in radio frequencies prevent clashes and interference from disrupting TV broadcasts. This is intended to fill the need for scarce spectrum, as mobile users become increasingly hungry for data on the move. Spectrum is the finite natural resource that that enables wireless technology to work. The amount of spectrum available for mobile use is limited, and owned by only a few major companies in many global markets. This means there is an escalating problem in trying to satisfy the demands of consumers who have come to expect fast downloading of applications and video without overloading the network. The technology uses signals that can travel large distances and through walls. This can lead to the creation of a faster and powerful wireless service which can benefit those living in rural areas or without access to broadband. Google co-founder Larry Page described this development as  WiFi on steroids .   white space in the news The UK is likely to be among the first to adopt wider white-space coverage. Ofcom, the communications watchdog in the UK, is leading the European agenda on white space, having unveiled plans in September 2013 to provide the regulatory backbone of a functioning network. The regulator will create a central database to help devices find the right space in which to operate without causing interference. The organisation has identified white space technology as an important means of meeting critical capacity shortages for mobile communications in future. More people are using bandwidth-hungry data services such as social media, video and gaming on the back of the rapid growth in smartphones and tablets. Ofcom warns that this could overload existing services   its experts predict an 80-fold increase in mobile data use by 2030   and has mapped out a strategy for the next decade to free up and share unused parts of a finite spectrum of available bandwidth. Google and Microsoft are also backing national trials of mobile services across fallow parts of the broadcast spectrum that could help avert a looming shortage of mobile frequencies. The two US technology groups, as well as British Telecom and other smaller British groups, will test out different consumer uses before a commercial rollout expected to take place in 2014. This includes the rollout by Microsoft of a free public WiFi service using white space in Glasgow, in Scotland, a city with the lowest rates of broadband uptake in the UK. [1]

Inventors can make great entrepreneurs, but this is not necessarily the case. For every James Dyson, turning a bagless vacuum cleaner into a multinational business, there is a Johannes Gutenberg, the pioneering 15th-century printer who changed the world of communication forever but died in poverty. This does not stop angel investors and venture capitalist firms trawling the planet for original ideas. The venture capitalists of Silicon Valley have a phrase for this type of investment:  white space . Backing completely new ideas may be risky, but the rewards are significantly greater, the VCs argue. Well, that is the theory.   white space investment in the news Experience shows that the best investments are often made in copycats. Facebook did not invent social networking, Apple did not invent the smartphone, the PC or the tablet computer, and search engines were around a long time before Google. The trick these businesses pulled off was to do better something that was already available. White space investments may be exciting, but it is better to back a business whose space is filled with paying customers. Imitation is not just the sincerest form of flattery, it is often the best way to create a business that will make money. [1]

A white squire defence is where a friendly company or investor purchases a large enough share of the target company to stop an unwelcome bidder from achieving its aim of taking over the target company. Once that unwelcome bidder has withdrawn its bid, the white squire will then typically sell its shares. A white squire defence helps a company fend off a hostile takeover, but has no intention of taking over the company itself. The term white squire arose in the 1980s as an alternative to white knight. The white knight is a company or individual that helps defend a company from an unwelcome bidder by buying the target itself. The problem for a target company in an M&A; bid which enlists the assistance of a 'white knight' is that the target gives up its independence, albeit to a preferred bidder (the white knight) instead of the initial bidder which the target did not like. So, in order to stop an unwelcome bidder whilst at the same time remaining independent, the concept of a white squire defence was developed.   white squire defence in the news A famous example of this defence was in 2005 when the attempt of Shareholders United to stop Malcolm Glazer's bid to take over Manchester United FC fully. They would have been able to achieve this if they had purchased approximately 8 per cent of the outstanding shares, but were unsuccessful in this. Another more recent example of a white squire defence can be found in the report: Carlos Slim s Am rica M vil threatens to drop  7.2bn KPN bid In 2013, Carlos Slim s Am rica M vil group threatened to drop its  7.2bn takeover bid for KPN after being blocked by an independent foundation. In this instance, the foundation entrusted with protecting the target company had blocking rights related to the Dutch telecoms company, KPN. In both these cases, it was not the intention, or not expected, that the owner of the shares obtained in the white squire defence would be used to take over the respective companies.[1]
White-coat ban/ rule: in the US, a law which makes it illegal to use a real doctor to help sell or advertise health products. [1]
White-collar workers work in offices, banks etc, rather than in factories, mines etc. [1]
Crimes by professional people that involve ways of illegally getting money. [1]
A worker who works in management or administration, rather than one who does physical work. [1]
Whole-life insurance contracts, arrangements etc are ones in which the person whose life is insured pays a fixed sum each year, and the insurance company pays out a sum when that person dies. [1]
Life insurance where the insurer pays out only when the insured person dies. [1]
The business of selling large quantities of goods at low prices to other businesses, rather than to the general public. [1]

A co-operative owned by a number of consumer co-operatives that buys or produces large quantities of goods and supplies them to its members and to other co-operatives. The profit it makes is shared between the members according to the value of the stock they have bought. [1]
Finished goods that are distributed in bulk to retailers. This is sometimes done by the producer itself, sometimes via an intermediate sales channel (the wholesaler).
Finished goods that are distributed in bulk to retailers. This is sometimes done by the producer itself, sometimes via an intermediate sales channel (the wholesaler).
A price paid by a wholesaler. [1]
An index showing the monthly change in the price of wholesale goods. An indicator of inflation. Similar to producer price index (PPI) in the US.
An index showing the monthly change in the price of wholesale goods. An indicator of inflation. Similar to producer price index (PPI) in the US.
The prices of wholesale goods. Similar to producer prices in the US.
See recommended retail priceSee wholesale goodsSee wholesale price
A company that is completely owned by another company. [1]

Popularised in the 1973 article Dilemmas in a General Theory of Planning by Horst Rittel and Melvin Webber, the term wicked problem refers to a complex problem for which there is no simple method of solution.Wicked problems are ones for which there is no clear stopping rule   you cannot say for sure that you are done with the problem. Working on it more might well bring forth a better solution. There is no single right answer and every attempt can matter because it affects the things people depend upon.ExampleWhen the music industry saw downloading audio files as a piracy problem, Apple saw it as a marketing problem. For Apple, the question moved from  how can we stop people from making digital copies of music   to  how can we get people to pay for making them   As a consequence they were able to start charging for music that only a short while before was being downloaded for free. [1]
On a stockmarket, a situation in which the difference between the selling and buying price of a share is larger than usual. [1]
Any small piece of equipment, used especially to talk about something that you do not know the name of.An imaginary product that a company might produce. [1]
Stock that is a very safe investment. [1]
The possibility of changing your plans or decisions in order to achieve what you want or to suit a different situation. [1]
Something that has an unexpected effect on a situation.A sign that can represent any letter in some computer commands. [1]
A wildcat oil well or discovery of oil is one that is in a place where no one has found oil before.To look for oil in a place where no one has found it yet. [1]
A strike in which workers suddenly stop working in order to protest about something, but which has not been approved by the union. [1]
An area of public land in the US where no buildings or roads are allowed to be built. [1]
A legal document that says who you want your money and property to be given to when you die. [1]
Used to describe a situation in which both sides involved gain something or are successful. [1]
An amount of money that a person or business gets unexpectedly. [1]
Often simple windfall. Income received due to an unforeseen event over which the recipient had no control.

Sudden and massive profits that come to an industrial or sales actor. These appear when there is a large gap between sourcing prices and selling prices. Windfall profits can be revealed thanks to a rapid rise of prices in a sector, where assets and capacity of production are fixed and already financed. A new regulation or tariff system can also lead to this phenomenon. These profits are unexpected and by nature not directly foreseen by the concerned actors. Windfall profits could be seen as a business opportunity. Regulators and government traditionally think about setting up specific taxes (called windfall profit taxes) to capture a part of this value creation. Example In the electricity industry, the rapid rise of European prices on the competitive market in 2004 and 2005 lead hydroelectric and nuclear power producers to a very attractive position. The debate also occurred a few years ago with the impact of free CO2 allocation in the electricity prices. It has been criticized for having generated windfall profits to power suppliers. [1] See Article: Nuclear industry windfall feared
A tax that must be paid by a company that has suddenly and unexpectedly earned a large amount of money, especially a large company that has recently been privatised (sold by the government). [1]
When a business or organization is closed down, especially because it cannot pay its debts. [1]
An order made by a court for a company to go into liquidation.

Deliberate actions by banks, broker-dealers, mutual funds and portfolio managers and institutional investors to divest of obscure, non glamorous and poorly performing stocks towards the end of the year. This is an effort to improve the structure of their stock portfolios just before they report to clients in their annual reports or before the end of a reporting period.ExampleA key aspect of managing other people s money is to keep your clients invested with you. Clients are typically happier if you show that you hold a basket of stocks that have performed well and that other people have invested in. Towards the end of the year and as the end of reporting period approaches, institutional investors sell underperforming and obscure stocks and move their money into more popular or well-known stocks. In the process, they depress these stocks  prices towards the end of the year. At the same time, this action can also increase the popularity of broadly-based, glamorous and outperforming stocks as portfolio managers gravitate towards strong performers to include in their reports to clients. [1]
When you go to look at things in shops, often without intending to buy anything. [1]
To send money electronically from one bank to another. Wire something up: to connect something to a computer system or another piece of equipment.[1]
An organization that sends news reports to newspapers, magazines, radio and television stations etc. [1]
Another name for telegraphic transfer. [1]

Originally named  wirehouses  because of an advanced communications system they employed, today the term simply refers to large financial institutions that offer multiple services in various locations, such as a bank. The term typically refers to full-service brokerages that offer research, order execution and investment advice all under the same roof. [1] A wirehouse is a large integrated broker with a national, as opposed to regional, business.  Wirehouses once collected trade orders from branch offices in distant cities using dedicated telegraph lines, hence the term wirehouse. Telegraphs were replaced by phones, which in turn were replaced by dedicated proprietary computer lines.  Now most traders routinely route their orders directly to their brokers over the internet.  The brokers at most wirehouses provide financial research and financial advice to their clients.  Many wirehouses also have investment banking divisions. More generally, the term wirehouse refers to any large financial institution that uses electronic systems to transmit information among its branches. Commercial banks and insurance companies that maintain multiple branch offices thus may be considered wirehouses, but the term now is rarely applied to financial institutions that do not have large brokerage operations. ExampleExamples of wirehouses include Morgan Stanley Smith Barney, Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Wells Fargo Advisors, UBS Wealth Management and Charles Schwab.  [2]
Wireless phones, systems etc use signals that pass through the air rather than using wires and cables. [1]
Communications that do not involve passing signals through electrical or telephone wires, for example mobile telephones. [1]
A wireless system which allows people to connect to the Internet using radio waves instead of phone lines.
Another name for telegraphic transfer. [1]
Relating to a system, piece of equipment etc that uses telephone wires. [1]
A with profits insurance policy pays a guaranteed amount in BONUSES( profits from the insurer's fund). [1]
A life insurance policy in Britain in which the policyholder is given a share of the profits of the insurance company. [1]

To take money out of a bank account. To remove something or take it back, often because of an official decision.  If a company withdraws a product or service, it stops making it available, either for a period of time or permanently.  Withraw a remark/ claim/ accusation: to say that something you said earlier was completely untrue.  To no longer take part in something or to no longer belong to a particular organization.[1]

The act of taking money from a bank account, or the amount you take out. The removal or stopping of something such as support, an offer, or a service.  Product withdrawal: when a product is made no longer available, either for a period of time or permanently.  When someone no longer takes part in an activity or is no longer a member of an organization.  When you say that something you previously said was in fact untrue.[1]
To refuse to let someone have something. Withhold facts/ evidence/ information: to refuse to give information.[1]

A tax that is deducted from salary or other income at source, i.e. before the income is received by the taxpayer. In some countries, dividend and interest income is subject to withholding tax, particularly when paid to non-residents.
A life insurance policy in Britain in which the sum insuredis fixed from the start of the contract and the policy holder has no share in the profits of the insurance company. [1]
Written abbreviation for week. [1]
Clothes for women; used especially in shops and manufacturing. [1]
Someone who works very hard, is very serious, and knows a lot about a particular subject. [1]

Word-of-mouth (WOM) marketing refers to promotional activities that leverage social interactions and word of mouth between consumers.  A distinction may be made between  active  and  passive  WOM marketing. Active WOM campaigns usually involve giving free samples to influential customers, or hiring professional  agents  to promote a brand, product or service. Passive WOM marketing activities usually consist of observing conversations that are naturally taking place, primarily on the internet. These observations may be qualitative or quantitative. Qualitative analysis of online social interactions relies on studying discussion boards, blogs, forums, review sites, newsgroups, social networks, etc. Quantitative analysis of online WOM consists in collecting various metrics on specific keywords, based on search volume, number of blog posts, number of tweets, etc. Such signals may be used to track, analyze and forecast the diffusion of a new product.ExamplesPassive WOM marketing services include Nielsen BuzzMetrics, Cymfony, Clarabridge, Collective Intellect, Nielsen Online, Google Trends / Google Insights for Search, BlogPulse, Networked Insights, Technorati and Twittorati.Active WOM marketing services include Electric Artists, DMC, Ivy Worldwide (previously Buzz Corps), Barbarian group, BzzAgent, Vocalpoint, SheSpeaks, Wildfire and Promojam. [1]
The process of measuring and calculating the time taken by a worker to do a particular job to a fixed standard or quality. [1]

The process of studying the activities of a group of workers or machines over a period of time, in order to find out how much time is spent on each activity that they do a method of finding out if someone is suitable for a job, by asking them to do an activity that is an important part of that job. [1]
The job or process of examining the way work is done in an organization, to see if it can be improved. [1]
A situation in which you are able to give the right amount of time and effort to your work and to your personal life outside work, for example to your family or to other interests. [1]

Individuals are engaged in multiple roles: for instance you may be a manager, a parent, a fund raiser for a charity and many other roles. You are likely to experience a work-life conflict when you cannot fully achieve your goals because of time constraints.  For example,  an important meeting can conflict with you attending a football game with your children; you experience diverging role expectations such as your personal values conflicting with your work values;  Work-life conflict is physical - as you will not be able to attend both the meeting and the football game - and psychological - you may not pay attention in the meeting because you are concerned about your children s reaction. However, you may experience work-life enrichment when you benefit from being engaged in multiple roles, because you may transfer skills and knowledge from one domain to another. For instance, you can use your fund raising skills to contribute to a project at work, or your professional planning skills to organise a family vacation. Your professional network can help your children find an internship, while your neighbour may prove a useful work contact. The skills and knowledge involved with bringing up children may be enhanced by your experience as a manager.  Also, your family may provide emotional support when you encounter problems at work. Most individuals experience both work-life conflict and work-life enrichment simultaneously. The extent to which one feels conflict and/or enrichment depends on the following five factors:  the quality of the roles the person is engaged in For instance, the satisfaction with one s job or the quality of one s relationships with partner and children.  If the person is highly satisfied with his/ her roles, s/he is more likely to cope with the demands of their responsibilities. the demands of the roles This involves job and household workload, or the emotional demands at work and at home.  The more demanding the role, the more challenging it may be for the person to deal with the pressure. the control one has over the roles For instance, schedule flexibility, or affordable back up child care. If a person has control and flexibility over their work schedule to fit in other commitments such as child care, then it may ease the pressure on him/ her. one s personalityFor instance, being efficient and confident are qualities to help manage work-life conflict.  the individual s ability to cope with the various roles This refers to the strategies individuals use to manage the demands of their roles, such as the ability to separate work and non-work, being assertive and taking up exercise such as yoga to reduce stress levels.  Example Some life stages are typically more prone to work-life conflict. The term  sandwiched  generation refers to individuals in the 30-50 age bracket who face both child and elderly care responsibilities (looking after ageing parents) while being employed. These individuals encounter work-life conflict more if they are also working to progress up the hierarchy as opposed to just holding a job. Work-life enrichment may be experienced in managerial, senior and junior professional roles, provided there is a sense of mutual benefit between work and life. For instance, your professional planning skills may help you plan your family holiday. [1]

Work-life culture can be defined as the set of beliefs and values shared within an organisation regarding maintaining a healthy and sustainable work-life balance. A supportive work-life culture is one where employees take up flexible working, such as teleworking or working flexible hours.  They do not suffer career penalties compared to employees who work regular or standard hours. Time expectations are an important component of work-life culture and take into account considerations such as:  Are employees expected to work long hours  How often should they take breaks  Is it acceptable that they may be off work for certain periods of time   Supervisor support is also important and considerations include:  Do supervisors value their employees being engaged in multiple roles and let them have flexible work options  Do they assess their employees  performance on results instead of time spent in the office  Are they sensitive to their employees work-life need and refer them to work-life programmes when necessary   ExampleAt Best Buy s headquarters, two HR professionals started the famous ROWE culture with stands for results only work environment. Work is measured in output, not hours. Performance reviews are based on results, not face time. When employees have a doctor s appointment or a parent-teacher meeting, they go ahead and make up for that time so that the work gets done. There are no mandatory meetings.  Gap outlets have also implemented ROWE. They have no meetings on Friday afternoons and provide employees with laptops so they could work from home. [1]

Work-life programmes are HR programmes provided by employers to help reduce work-life conflict and foster work-life enrichment. They typically include flexible working options as well as financial support, information (such as employee assistance programmes) and infrastructures (such as on-site childcare or gym) pertaining to four areas of life outside of work: health and well-being, child and elderly care, daily life (covering activities such as booking a holiday or finding a special gift) and personal projects (such as going back to school and taking up voluntary work). The most advanced practices emphasise supervisor training to raise supervisors  awareness of available policies and help them implement the policies. They also make an attempt to change the way the organisation works and the mindset of the workers, by encouraging them to assess performance based on results rather than time spent in the office for instance - see work-life culture. Well run work-life programmes help organisations attract and retain employees, reduce absenteeism, stress and burnout, plus enhance employee engagement and job satisfaction. ExamplesAt ATP Denmark, a pension and investment company, their employee benefits include providing home workstations, flexible working hours, take-home organic meals three times a week, a dry cleaning service, a gym that employees may use during working hours and a playroom for children if employees need to take their children to work for the day. Daimler offers all employees a community service day where they can take eight hours per year to devote themselves to a cause that is important to them (source: Great place to Work Institute). [1]
An occasion when people protest about a situation at work by doing their job less quickly or effectively, but without breaking their employer's rules or the terms of their contract. [1]
Someone who cannot seem to stop working, and does not have time for anything else. [1]
One of the people who work for an organization or business, and are below the level of manager. [1]
A principle, policy, or system of requiring people who are unemployed to work or train before they are allowed to receive WELFARE( money from the government). [1]
All the people who work in a particular country, industry, or factory. [1]
A machine or vehicle that can be used to do a lot of work. [1]
The amount of cash and other liquid assets a company holds in order to finance its day-to-day operations - effectively, the excess of current assets over current liabilities.
A committee that is formed to examine a particular situation or problem and suggest ways of dealing with it. [1]
An interest held by a company in a particular activity, especially the oil industry. [1]
An official document you need in the US in order to get a job if you are young or were born outside the US. [1]
A partner who takes an active part in the running of a business. [1]
A group of people with specialist knowledge, brought together by an official organization to give advice on a particular issue. [1]
Discussions between employers and employees that take place in order to reach an agreement about working conditions, pay etc. [1]
A way of running a company in which all employees are involved in making important decisions about the company. [1]
An organization in a company where employers and representatives of workers meet to discuss pay, working conditions etc. [1]
A language such as English that is used in many different parts of the world. [1]
Words per minute; used to show how fast someone can type or do SHORTHAND. [1]
The situation when a business activity, company, system etc fails to succeed. [1]
A document from a court that orders someone to do or not to do something. [1]

A writ to put into effect a court's judgement by forcing someone to pay an amount of money or do something. It is usually addressed to a court officer, ordering him or her to do something such as take property from the person. [1]
A writ ordering an officer to take and sell property belonging to someone who owes money, until the value of the property taken is equal to the amount of their debt. [1]
A way of starting a legal action by someone who has a claim against a particular person, that orders that person to come to court unless they admit the claim. [1]
To restore or increase the value of an asset on a balance sheet after a previous write-off or write-down.
To reduce the book value of an asset, for instance in the case of asset depreciation or amortisation. Similar to write off.

To reduce or eliminate the book value of an asset, for instance in the case of asset depreciation or amortisation, or to account for an increase in bad debt. The decrease in value is charged to the profit and loss account as an extraordinary loss (the amount written off is called a write-off).
To increase the book value of an asset. This term is used mainly in the US. Similar to write back.
When the value of an asset that had been written off or written down increases, for example when a debt that you thought would not be paid is unexpectedly paid. [1]
An official agreement stating that someone does not have to pay a debt.When all or part of the value of an asset as shown in a company's accounts is reduced.
To make it impossible for a computer user to write information onto a computer disk, or change the details of an existing file, so that information is not changed or destroyed. [1]
When the value of an asset is increased.A written opinion about a new product, book etc. [1]
When the value of an asset as shown in a company's accounts is reduced. [1]
Someone who sells PUT OPTIONand CALL OPTION contracts.A person or company that provides insurance contracts. [1]
In Britain, an amount allowed for DEPRECIATION( fall in value) of an asset that is not taxed. [1]
The value of an asset or group of assets in a company's financial records after depreciation (amounts to allow for their estimated loss of value as they get older, less productive etc). [1]
Written abbreviation for weight. [1]
The ability of a business to achieve the best results in the most economic way in relation to the number of employees, machines etc it has. [1]
When a business does not achieve the best results in the most economic way in relation to the number of employees, machines etc it has. [1]

Ex all; used after a share price to show that it is sold without any of the advantages that have been or will soon be available, for example dividends or rights issues (rights for existing shareholders to buy new shares). [1]

Ex capitalization; used after a share price to show that the buyer does not have the right to a bonus issue that has been or will soon be made, where existing shareholders are paid part of a company's profits in the form of new shares. [1]

Ex dividend; used after a share price to show that a dividend (payment of part of a company's profits to shareholders) has been announced but that the seller of the share will receive it, not the buyer. [1]
A certificate of deposit offered by non-American banks in the US. [1]
A unit for measuring length, equal to 3 feet or 0.9144 metres.An enclosed area next to a building or group of buildings, used for a special purpose, activity, or business. [1]
Something that you use to compare another thing with, in order to judge how good or successful it is. [1]
The period of time beginning on January 1 and ending on December 31.Any period of time equal to about 12 months. [1]
The end of a company's financial year. [1]

When measuring the difference between performance, prices, quantities or indeed any other value of something, it is common to measure the most recent value against the value measured exactly a year earlier. Year on year (yoy) is often used to avoid confusion with a change in value in the calendar year to date (ytd), or indeed the financial year to date (ytd). For example a company who reports, in June perhaps, that its share price has risen 5 per cent year on year, might have seen its share price jump by 10 per cent in the year to date, if most of the price movement had been in more recent months.   Year on year or YOY in the news At the end of 2012 analysts were observing that Chinese refined copper net imports had risen 73 per cent year on year (yoy). In another example of its use in January 2013, UK high street pub chain JD Wetherspoon warned that operating margins for the half year to January 27 would drop 1.1 per cent year on year to 8.2 per cent.
The period from the beginning of a calendar year or financial year until the present time, used especially to talk about the amount of sales or profit in a particular period. [1]
A book that is produced once a year, and to which the most recent information is added each year. [1]
Money borrowed by a local authority in the form of a bond that must be paid back within a year. [1]
Happening or appearing every year or once a year. [1]
The standard unit of money in Japan. [1]

Generally, the income generated by an asset on an annual basis, expressed as a percentage of the asset's purchase or market price. For stock investments, the yield is the total dividend for the latest year as a proportion  of the share price. For bonds, the yield is the same as the coupon rate (if the bond is purchased at par or is trading at par). Any increase or decrease of the yield relative to the coupon rate is roughly proportionate (though in the inverse direction) to any change in the bond price (yields fall as prices rise, and vice-versa). [1] Equity dividend yields may be calculated both net and gross. Most people and organisations use the net method.  The calculation for the yield is net dividend pence per share multiplied by 100 then divided by the share price. [2]
The additional yield earned by holding a company's convertible securities rather than its common shares.

A graphical representation of the relationship between the yields and maturities of different bonds of similar quality, currency denomination and risk (usually government bonds). Normally a yield curve slopes upwards (a positive or normal yield curve), as one would expect longer-dated bonds to have a higher yield than shorter-term ones (because an investor should expect to earn more for taking on longer-term risk). If that situation is reversed, for instance because of an unusually high supply of short-term paper, the curve slopes downward (an inverted or negative yield curve). A yield curve can also be flat (with little difference between short-term and long-term interest rates), depending on supply and demand or inflationary expectations. ViewYield curve watchers divided over bank powerUS yield curveShort View: US yield curve

A graphical representation of the relationship between the yields and maturities of different bonds of similar quality, currency denomination and risk (usually government bonds). Normally a yield curve slopes upwards (a positive or normal yield curve), as one would expect longer-dated bonds to have a higher yield than shorter-term ones (because an investor should expect to earn more for taking on longer-term risk). If that situation is reversed, for instance because of an unusually high supply of short-term paper, the curve slopes downward (an inverted or negative yield curve). A yield curve can also be flat (with little difference between short-term and long-term interest rates), depending on supply and demand or inflationary expectations. ViewYield curve watchers divided over bank powerUS yield curveShort View: US yield curve
See yield curve
When a TAX-EXEMPTinvestment ( one that is not taxed) and a taxable investment of a similar quality provide the same after-tax RETURN, at a particular INTEREST RATE. [1]
The difference between the yield on long-term government bonds and the yield on shares (dividend yield) at any given time.

The difference in the yields of comparable bonds. One way of gauging the performance of a recently issued bond is to compare its yield to that of a benchmark bond with a similar maturity. If the spread between two bond yields becomes larger, the spread is said to widen; if it becomes smaller, it is said to narrow.
Estimate of the yield that would be earned on a callable bond if it were redeemed by the issuer on the next call date. Calculated in a similar way as the yield to maturity (YTM)

Estimate of the yield that would be earned on a bond if it were held to its maturity date. The calculation assumes that the interest regularly received on the bond is re-invested and generates the same yield as the YTM.

Estimate of the yield that would be earned on a bond if it were held to its maturity date. The calculation assumes that the interest regularly received on the bond is re-invested and generates the same yield as the YTM.
Another name for yield to maturity. [1]
Estimate of the lowest possible yield that would be earned on a bond based on the terms of its indenture.

Young people, aged 18 to 21, who receive universal credit will be required, from April 2017, to participate in an intensive regime of support from day one of their benefit claim. After six months they will be expected to apply for an apprenticeship or traineeship, gain work-based skills, or go on a mandatory work placement to give them the skills they need to move into sustainable employment. [1]

Yuan, also known as Renminbi or Kuai, is the currency used in the People s Republic of China (PRC), but not Hong Kong and Macau.   The currency code is CNY or RMB.  The currency symbol is  , same as the Yen the Japanese currency. One yuan is equal to 10 jiao and one jiao is equal to 10 fen.  Mao is another word for jiao.  It is more informal than yuan and jiao but more widely used. The banknotes are available in multiples of one, five, 10, 20, 50 and 100.  [1]
A young person in a professional job with a high income, especially one who enjoys spending money and having a fashionable way of life. [1]
In Japan in former times, a group of related companies often owned by members of the same family, with a bank at its centre in which the companies owned shares. [1]
In Japan, when a company buys valuable paintings, objects etc in order to hide the profits it has made. [1]

Some companies aim to achieve zero-carbon status. Most carbon emissions come from energy use so by sourcing all of their energy from renewable or carbon-free sources companies could cut emissions drastically. However, to have none at all they need all of the products they use   from the paper in their printers to cleaning products   to come only from suppliers that also source all of their energy from renewables. [1] ViewHopes grow of green jobs bonanza
A type of bond that pays no interest but is issued at a substantial discount to face value. The yield is the capital gain realised by investors when the bond is redeemed at full value.
A type of bond that pays no interest but is issued at a substantial discount to face value. The yield is the capital gain realised by investors when the bond is redeemed at full value.
When a product or system has no faults at all, especially when this is the aim of the company making the product or using the system. [1]
See zero-minus tick

A zero interest rate policy or zirp is a route taken by a central bank to keep the base rate at zero per cent in an attempt to stimulate demand in the economy by making the supply of money cheaper. The term is also used to describe a near zero benchmark rate set by countries such as the UK in the post financial crisis years, which kept interest rates near to zero and accompanied that policy with measures such as quantitative easing.   zirp in the news In July 2012 the FT's markets blog, Alphaville, returned to a theme in which it argued against zirp policies. It argued such a rate policy could have a disastrous impact on collateral markets and money market funds, not to mention the net interest income of lending institutions. All of which could unleash a protracted deflationary spiral.
See zero-plus tick
A system of budgeting in which each department in a company must give the reasons why it needs the money it has asked for, rather than being given a regular amount every year. [1]
A bond bought at well below its actual value. It does not pay interest during its life, but the gain is made when it is resold. [1]

A zero hours contract is an employment contract used in the UK where workers are not guaranteed work but are expected to remain available. The amount of work can vary resulting in little or no pay. Employers can call in workers, those with contracts, when they need them, but do not need to pay them for hours that they remain available but have not been working. Employees on zero hours contracts typically receive few or no employee benefits such as holiday pay or sick pay and are not entitled to redundancy pay. For workers who might otherwise be unemployed, the advantage is that they can keep using their skills and they might end up fully employed.   zero hours contracts in the news In April 2013 it was reported that professionals in UK including doctors, lecturers and journalists were being put on zero hours contracts. The report referred to a British Labour Force survey which found that the total number of employees on zero hours contracts rose 25 per cent over 2012 and had risen more than 150 per cent since the autumn of 2005.

The price of a stock market transaction that is carried out at the same price as the most recent previous deal, but is cheaper than the last deal carried out at a different price. Also called zero downtick.

The price of a stock market transaction that is carried out at the same price as the most recent previous deal, but is cheaper than the last deal carried out at a different price. Also called zero downtick.

The price of a stock market transaction that is carried out at the same price as the most recent previous deal, but is more expensive than the last deal carried out at a different price. Also called zero uptick.

The price of a stock market transaction that is carried out at the same price as the most recent previous deal, but is more expensive than the last deal carried out at a different price. Also called zero uptick.
Zero-rated goods and services are those on which you do not have to pay VAT (a type of sales tax).  In Britain, most food and books are zero-rated. [1]
An economic transaction in which whatever is gained by one party must be lost by the other.

A bank/ company that is insolvent but continues to operate until its fate is resolved by closure or merger. [1] ExampleBeginning in 1990, Japan suffered a collapse in real estate and stock market prices that pushed major banks into insolvency. Rather than follow America's tough recommendation - and close or recapitalise these banks - Japan kept banks marginally functional through explicit or implicit guarantees and piecemeal government bail-outs. The resulting "zombie banks" - neither alive nor dead - could not support economic growth. A period of weak economic performance called Japan's "lost decade" resulted. [2] Scores of companies were cast into an  undead  state   in the sense of being too weak to flourish, but too complex and costly for their lenders to shut down.  Hence they remained half-alive, poisoning the corporate world by silently spreading a sense of stagnation and fear.  [3] During the lost decade, this was when property values fell by as much as 80 per cent and economic growth slid to the bottom of the G7 league as the country moved in and out of recession. Prices in general began to fall, heightening the debt burden of companies. Deflation stalked the land, with zombie companies kept alive by equally insolvent banks. [4] Japan s experience in the past two decades, in particular, make clear that a banking system populated by zombie banks is a major threat to recovery; banking systems remain dysfunctional until losses are fully recognised and disclosed; and procrastination increases the ultimate cost to the taxpayer. [5] View How Washington can prevent 'zombie banks' Insight: Zombie curse of Europe s CLOs Japan makes an odd curiosity Europe must take control of banking stress tests

A company that is kept alive by lenient creditors and low interest rates even though it is too weak to invest or expand.   zombie companies in the news In January 2013 UK entertainment retailer, HMV, called in administrators putting the jobs of its 4,000 employees at risk. The crisis at HMV came hot on the heels of trouble for other British high street retailers   Comet, Jessops, JJB, Clinton and Game   which had resulted in 15,000 redundancies in the preceding months. But some economists took the view that too few companies were going bust in Britain and these weak, "zombie companies" were holding back the UK's economic recovery. Bank of England data made available towards the end of 2012 appeared to support those economists' theory   about 30 per cent of British companies were lossmaking in 2010, a bigger proportion than in the 1990s recession, but corporate insolvency rates were lower.

This is a closed with-profits fund that no longer writes new business or policies. This can include pension and investment funds. [1] With-profits funds were for many years the mainstay of the financial services industry, being widely sold as a way of building up pension funds or to pay off a mortgage. But the amounts they repay investors is based on formulas so complicated that they puzzle financial advisers, let alone their clients. ExampleThere are two types of with-profits policies: a with-profits bond, which invests a lump sum payment; or an endowment, where you pay in a fixed amount every month. Both are long-term schemes and there are two components to the money you get back: a regular bonus, which is typically paid once a year, and a final, or maturity, bonus when your policy comes to an end. When you sign up, the contract will specify the length of the scheme, and may guarantee a level of bonus payments. Annual bonus rates are normally lower than interest rates on the more generous current accounts, let alone savings accounts. So whether your with-profits policy ends up being a good deal will depend on the size of your final bonus." [2] ViewHow to breathe some life into the  zombies Phoenix on track to meet cash flow target

Zombie households refer to homeowners who are in debt and who have seen the value of their homes and savings fall. Yet, they are saved from bankruptcy and reposession because the interest rates on their mortagages are so low. [1] However, if interest rates move back up to normal levels, it is possible that these individuals will not be able to service their debt. [2] ExampleBritain may face a long and difficult road to recovery because of an earlier housing and credit boom has led to a generation of  zombie households  among low-income groups who cannot save enough to ever repay their debts and begin spending again, according to a study conducted by the National Institute for Economic and Social Research in 2012. According to data from the Financial Services Authority (FSA), over 40 per cent of mortgages generated in the years before the boom are interest-only and those borrowers are no further towards repaying their debts than they were five years ago. The FSA also estimates that between 5 to 8 per cent of all mortgages are only avoiding foreclosure because banks are showing  forbearance. The Office for Budget Responsibility and the Bank of England have remained broadly unconcerned about the level of household debt because it overwhelmingly was used to purchase housing, giving households a financial asset that offsets the debt. [3] ViewBoom left low-income groups in debt for ever
